PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: -Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--I inform the Senate that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, will be absent from the chamber today. Senator Evans is interstate on Government business. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Evans in relation to his portfolio should be directed to Senator Robert Ray.

—-Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate concerned that the reported decision of Caucus in relation to newspaper ownership will allow for concentration of media in very few hands? Is Senator Button concerned that the Caucus decision favours foreign and concentrated media ownership in preference to diversified and Australian media ownership? Are newspaper reports that the decision has been made to favour a proprietor who will benefit the ALP correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am not able or prepared to comment on what the Caucus resolution meant because ultimately, in respect of media ownership, the discretion in relation to foreign investment lies with the Treasurer. Indeed, two positions were put to the Caucus. Both, I think, were couched in terms of recommendations to the Treasurer. But ultimately the discretion lies with him.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as I am personally concerned, I am not concerned very much about issues of foreign ownership in the media in Australia. I am concerned about issues of concentration of media ownership; I always have been and will remain so, whether or not any change takes place in relation to the Fairfax matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I ask a supplementary question. If Senator Button is concerned, as he just said he was, why did he not vote on the issue when it came before Caucus?
—-It is a subject which has nothing to do with Senator Macdonald.

—-I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the article in today's Advertiser which states that the number of people queuing for food, clothing and shelter at Adelaide's voluntary care organisations has more than doubled in the past 12 months. I ask the Minister: firstly, when is unemployment in the country going to become the Government's principal focus; secondly, does the sort of evidence presented in today's Advertiser persuade the Government and the Treasurer that something is seriously wrong with their economic approach; and, finally, does the Minister agree that ordinary working Australians and their families are paying the price for the Government's over-emphasis on statistical goals with little regard for the human and social consequences?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have not read the article in the Adelaide Advertiser which is referred to by the honourable senator. However, in answers on this issue that I have given at numerous Question Times, I have expressed concern about the current levels of unemployment and that is the view of the Government. The Government is very concerned about current levels of unemployment. However, there are no magic wands which can be waved in order to alleviate that concern.
—-Keating thinks there are.
—-Open mouth on my left says, `Keating thinks there are'. I do not think Mr Keating has ever said that.
—-You can drop interest rates and that would help.
—-Senator Hill follows the impeccable illogicality of his Cardinal Richelieu sitting behind him and says, `You can drop interest rates' and that would be a magic wand.
—-No, I didn't say that. I said there were things that could be done.

—-The honourable senator did say that; he mentioned interest rates. I have news for those opposite--if they have not learnt it now it is about time they started to learn--a change in interest rate policy tomorrow would not do anything to alleviate the more immediate concerns which are raised in the honourable senator's question.
—-A change of government would help.
—-Senator Campbell interjects to say, `A change of government might help'.
—-You have to admit that we couldn't do worse.

—-I must say that the stance of the current electorate at this time, in my view--if I might be so bold to comment on that--is that it is a bit disappointed in us and it is horrified about those opposite. That is the current position in the Australian electorate, in my view. The point is that we can improve; those opposite will only get worse because they are locked in, in terms of their leadership, to a set of policies which is going out of fashion as fast as it possibly can. Who does not know about it? John Hewson and his collection of merry men in Australia do not know that the policies, which those opposite espouse like mindless sheep, are going out of fashion all around the world. Those brave little vegemites in the Liberal Party of Australia are sticking with it whatever happens.

ANSWER.PARA: Unemployment is a principal concern of the Government. I agree--and I have said this on numerous occasions--that people are paying the price for a variety of things including a misapplication of Government policy. We have said that on a number of occasions. A number of other things are contributing to that situation as well. But I am sure that unemployment is the prime concern of the Treasurer, as it is of all Ministers in this Government and members of the parliamentary Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister what he means by `a misapplication of Government policy'?

—-On a number of occasions it has been recognised by Government Ministers, including the former Treasurer and the Prime Minister, that we maintained a tight monetary policy longer than we might have done in different circumstances.
—-You were wrong.

—-The Opposition keeps interjecting about this. To me, those opposite have always looked like one big Manson family; they are starting to sound like one now, with all of these silly interjections. Honourable members opposite know perfectly well that they should follow the words of their leader in relation to monetary policy as applied by this Government. What did he say? Every time the Government took action on this issue, it was supported by the Leader of the Liberal Party. Those opposite know that; they cannot back away from that now. We are prepared to accept that; those opposite cannot back away from it.

—-I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to his answer to the question asked by Senator Macdonald concerning the remarks he made on the Sunday program about the decision of Caucus on foreign ownership and the concentration of ownership in the Australian media. Will that decision be reopened by Caucus? Will it be reopened while the Prime Minister is absent?

—-I have no idea about the answer to that question. Caucus, in one of the great cliches of Labor history in this country, is master of its own destiny. If it is decided that some people want to reopen the issue, that may happen--I do not know; I have no idea.

—-My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Assuming the Government had the information when it made the Budget Medicare decisions, will the Minister table in the Senate before it rises tonight, firstly, the percentage per capita growth for each quarter compared with the previous quarter, from March 1980 to June 1991, in general practice services for cardholders and non-cardholders separately; and, secondly, will he supply the absolute number for each quarter on the same basis? If, on the other hand, Cabinet made its decision ignorant of those critical facts, will he table them before the Senate rises on Thursday next? Finally, will he table the same figures for the September quarter 1991, which Cabinet obviously did not have when the decision was made?
—-I will ensure that a very full and comprehensive answer is tabled for Senator Walsh before the end of this week.

—-I refer to the concerns of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce that Australia's business tax system is inhibiting investment. The Minister has indicated that our trading partners in the Asian Pacific region have very different taxation systems. What are the specific features of these tax systems which may cause Australia to be uncompetitive in terms of international investment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I take it that Senator Kemp is referring to the Sunday program. The position that I put about this issue was that in the past four years, until the present fall off in investment, we have had better investment figures in Australia than we have had for many years, well above the historical average.
—-Where has it gone?

—-As a senator from Western Australia, Senator Crichton-Browne would probably be better able to tell us than some others. The point I was seeking to make about that is whether that improvement on historical performance is good enough compared with investment rates in other countries: for example, much higher rates of investment as a percentage of GDP in countries such as Japan and a number of the OECD countries, leaving aside Asian countries as Senator Kemp refers to them in generic form.

ANSWER.PARA: I said on the Sunday program that I am not sure whether the tax system is wrong but that we should look at it to make sure that it is up to date, and that it is up to date not only in comparison with OECD countries but also taking into account that we live in the Asia-Pacific region and that the majority of our major trading partners are now in the Asia-Pacific region. That seems to me to be a factor which we might appropriately have to take into account.

It is common knowledge that in terms of encouragement of investment in a number of Asian countries, there are all sorts of tax advantages offered, which I personally would regard as inappropriate in Australia, but which nonetheless affect the patterns of investment in those countries, albeit, I would suspect, only on a temporary basis. Those things are relevant in any consideration of the matter, I suspect.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Could Senator Button tell the Senate, in view of the fact that he has raised this issue in the public arena, whether there are any examples that he can offer as to the specific features of these tax systems which he may find particularly attractive.
—-There are none in terms of considering whether our tax system is internationally competitive. There are none that I would raise as specific models that I would like to follow.

—-My question is addressed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Collins. We are now within a few weeks of the first anniversary of the commencement of the Government's key micro-economic initiative to deregulate the interstate airlines industry. Considering the current economic climate and forecasts that very little would change, what is the outcome of deregulation so far?
—-Haven't you any idea?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Senator Walters certainly hasn't. Mr President, the reality is that a great deal has changed. I was able when opening the Australian Airport Owners Conference this morning in Devonport, Tasmania--where I met a lot of nice people--to indicate that following the deregulation of interstate air services in October last year by the Government, the domestic aviation industry has achieved record levels of performance.

ANSWER.PARA: The domestic airlines carried 4.7 million passengers in the September quarter, exceeding the previous record of four million which was set in the September 1988 quarter, which was the Bicentenary-Expo year. This record enabled the airlines to set another new mark for the number of passengers carried. The airlines carried 15.4 million passengers in the year ending 30 September. This is 8.6 per cent above the previous record of 14.2 million passengers set in the year ending 30 September 1988 when bicentennial and Expo activities were very powerful attractions. These results are even more remarkable, given the current economic climate.

Competition between the airlines has been vigorous to say the least, and demand for air travel and capacity offered by the airlines are at record levels, stimulated by deep fare discounting. The airlines have been offering a myriad of deep discounts and a range of special deals, the like of which were never seen before deregulation. A total of 5.1 billion revenue passenger kilometres were performed in the September 1991 quarter, an increase of 30 per cent on the previous record set in September 1988. A total of 6.4 billion available seat kilometres were flown in the September 1991 quarter, an increase of 34 per cent on the previous record set in the September 1988 quarter.

Given such results, it is reasonable to conclude that at this stage the Government's initiative to deregulate the interstate airlines industry is clearly providing significant benefits to consumers, tourism and the economy as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button. Is the Minister one of those reported in today's Australian Financial Review as believing that the risk for the economy next year is on the down side rather than on the up side? If so, which are the down side risks he has in mind?

—-The answer to that question is no. In referring to next year, Senator Short is talking about outcomes from what I would regard as short term economic management. A number of other issues have been intruded into this debate, including the question of business taxation, for example, which goes much more to questions of longer term economic management. So the answer to Senator Short's question is no.

—-I ask a supplementary question. In confirming that he is not one of the Ministers who is reported as believing that the economy has a downside risk next year rather than an upside risk, I also ask Senator Button whether he is one of those Ministers reported in today's press as believing that a one per cent further and early easing in interest rates would have a confidence boosting effect and strengthen business recovery next year.
—-I have answered that question already in the Senate--no.

—-My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport. I refer to a survey by Monash University in Melbourne which found that people aged 17 to 25 years account for a third of all road fatalities in Australia although they constitute only 14 per cent of the population. In asking this question, I understand that the Chairman of the Road Trauma Committee of the Royal Australian College of Surgeons, Professor Frank McDermott, has said that the number of deaths could be greatly reduced in Australia if a curfew were introduced on young drivers between the hours of 11 p.m. and 5 a.m., as apparently applies in parts of the United States. I therefore ask the Minister whether he agrees with the views of the professor and whether any steps are being taken to help reduce the number of road deaths among young people in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Land Transport, Mr Robert Brown, has provided me with the following response. The Government is aware of the serious overrepresentation of young drivers in road crashes. They represent 14 per cent of the population but account for 33 per cent of road deaths.

ANSWER.PARA: In the Prime Minister's 1990 road safety package, the Government required all States and Territories to introduce graduated licensing arrangements for young drivers. The purpose was to extend the learning period and ensure an extended period of driving under controlled conditions to reduce the number of accidents. The graduated licensing system requires all learner and novice drivers for the first three years after they obtain their licences to drive at a zero blood alcohol limit; a minimum learner period of six months; no issue of learner permits before 16 years of age; and no issue of probationary licences before 17 years of age.

South Australia, which had introduced its own graduated licensing scheme just prior to the national scheme being prescribed, will assess its success against the national scheme in 1993. As part of the Government's intensified road safety research and public education program for the three years from 1991, young drivers are to be the major focus group.

A major research study is being undertaken at the Monash University Accident Research Centre. This research will initially focus on the reasons for the high crash rates for young drivers and will develop methods for evaluating the effectiveness of the graduated licensing system that has been introduced. Depending on the outcome of the current research, further studies looking at countermeasures will be undertaken.

The public education program of the Federal Office of Road Safety has also given considerable emphasis to young drivers. This includes major road safety programs for young males in the bush, which in 1990-91 focused on seat belt wearing and this year will focus on driver fatigue. A school-based young drivers program is currently being developed. Major campaigns on drink driving have been and will continue to be promoted, and these will impact on young drivers. A separate major public education campaign for young drivers will be developed during the current fiscal year.

As part of the blackspot package, the Government attempted to introduce passenger restrictions for young drivers. This would have involved restrictions on young drivers carrying passengers from their own age group, thus minimising peer pressure. There was a great deal of opposition from the States and Territories to that measure and it was not proceeded with on the basis that its introduction would compromise the total package.

The introduction of curfews would impose significantly more restrictions on young drivers. The Government would not introduce such a measure without carefully examining the issue. It is understood that curfews in the United States and New Zealand essentially apply to drivers who are younger than our youngest drivers. It is intended that a report will examine this issue in some detail. In the meantime, the Government believes that the measures being introduced by the Commonwealth and State governments will act to reduce the number of crashes amongst young drivers. Road fatalities for young drivers fell 18 per cent between 1989 and 1990 and overall fatalities have fallen another 9 per cent this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It concerns the current anti-dumping inquiry into canned peaches and pears from Spain, Greece and the People's Republic of China, commenced over one year ago, in which the Anti-Dumping Authority has reversed the negative finding of Customs. In order to establish the normal value of goods in China for the final hearing, it is necessary for Australian Customs officials to obtain this information from China. Can the Minister advise the Senate whether his Department has received any requests from the Australian Customs Service or the Anti-Dumping Authority to facilitate an inspection of PRC canning arrangements in relation to this anti-dumping inquiry? Does the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade have a policy against supporting visits by government officials working on such anti-dumping and countervailing cases? As part of its trade policy activities, has the Department conducted any surveys of Chinese industry and costs in sectors where Australian industry has been injured from dumped or subsidised products? Does any unit within the Department intend to initiate any projects to measure Chinese farm production, its costs and related subsidies?

—-Mr President, this answer requires some considerable detail. I am assured by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade that it will have a comprehensive answer to the questions raised by Senator Boswell for Senator Gareth Evans to deliver after Question Time tomorrow.

—-I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Last month the Institution of Engineers issued a press release expressing concerns about Australia's dependence on international goodwill for continuing access to meteorological and land use data from satellites. Can the Minister inform the Senate what the Government is doing to address the concerns identified by the Institution and to encourage Australia's participation in the space industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I did see the comments by the Institution of Engineers, but the answer which one would of necessity give to a question of this kind is somewhat long. The committee of the Institution of Engineers consists of representatives from the major companies in the space industry, CSIRO and several experienced academics.

ANSWER.PARA: Recently the committee's primary focus has been on the level of public sector investment in the space industry and the direction of Australia's space policy. Its view is somewhat consistent with the report of the Madigan committee of inquiry conducted by the Academy of Technological Sciences in 1986, which recommended very substantial public sector expenditure on space related activities. To give an idea of the level of space related activities, in the 1991-92 Budget the allocation is in the order of $7m.

The area of space policy and development is very complex, embracing things such as remote sensing right up to the rocketry associated with the proposed international spaceport. Therefore, what the Institution of Engineers is saying is slightly misleading in that its own work parallels the Government's work without acknowledging some of the Government's input into these questions. The content of the engineers' press release is in some ways without foundation in that sense. All government agencies are aware of what that committee is saying and are working on solutions to it.

The spaceport in Queensland always obtains high public priority in relation to space related matters, but in fact the highest priority area is remote sensing. It is in those areas that the Government has been giving most attention.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to his concern at the level of investment in Australian industry. I refer him particularly to comments by Mr Keating when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Business investment remained exceptionally strong and was still raising the economy's capacity to produce despite the latest downturn.
Mr Keating has further said:
. . . what we're seeing today in these capital expectations data is the likelihood of another strong rise in investment in the financial year 1991. . .
He has also stated:
The current account problem is created by the new investment. It's not created by the Government's incapacity to deal with the underlying current account deficit.
Further:
We have an investment boom on. We haven't had an investment boom in Australia since the height of the mineral investment boom in the late seventies. But this one is in manufacturing and services.
Finally, he has said:

The fact that we are still dealing with a current account imbalance is not evidence of the fact that shifting our industrial structure is time consuming, it is evidence of the fact that we are now dealing with a massive investment surge as well.
I conclude by referring to Mr Keating's saying that:
Too much of a good thing can be still too much of a good thing. I mean, basically, the glass is too full and the effervescence is spilling over the sides. . .
I ask the Minister: who got it wrong? Was it the Minister or was it his choice for Prime Minister, Mr Keating?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I suppose that it is fairly typical of Senator Crichton-Browne to put a quotation into a question without telling us when it occurred and where it is from. Let me say that if Senator Crichton-Browne is pretending that it was a recent statement by the former Treasurer, I think it is very much a pretence. I am sure the former Treasurer knows that investment levels and anticipations in Australia are very low at present. When the former Treasurer made that statement, he was referring to what had been an historic change in investment rates and intentions which took place in the last two or three years of the 1980s and the first years of this decade when investment was considerably above the historical average in this country.
—-In milk bars.

—-No. I am comparing aggregate investment with aggregate investment. If Senator Campbell has a childish predilection for milk bars, he should stick with it. He can spend his time in milk bars while I deal with the investment figures. The fact of the matter is that when that statement was made it was true. Compared with the historic average in Australia, we were having high levels of investment.

ANSWER.PARA: More recently, I and some others have been asking, in an environment in which we have a much more open economy than we have had in the past, where there has been substantial restructuring in the Australian economy, and where we are competing for investment with a range of other countries, whether comparing ourselves with our historic average in investment is good enough or whether some other considerations should be taken into account in the current circumstances. I am not saying that that is right; I am saying that is an issue which should surely be looked at in the current environment. If some of Senator Crichton-Browne's colleagues opposite do not understand that--like poor old Senator Kemp who keeps nodding his head, and it is too early on a Monday to be nodding his head as he is--I hope that Senator Crichton-Brown will.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I ask a supplementary question. To the extent that we have been suffering, as has been described continuously by the previous Treasurer in reasonably recent and contemporary times, from a massive investment boom to the point where too much was too much, how is that investment boom reflected in the balance of payments figures, particularly in respect of the contribution of the manufacturing sector?
—-I cannot give precise figures on that, except to say that the past few years have seen record exports of manufactured products from this country.
—-What are you on about now?

—-Perhaps I ought to explain this to Senator Walters, given her interjection. I am on about, and have been on about all along, the fact that over time one needs to expand and diversify capacity in manufacturing and other activities in this country. I am in favour of that.

—-My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister seen reports of disquiet among sections of the diving industry, including pearl divers and scientific divers, about the development of an occupational diving standard? Is the Government addressing these concerns of pearl divers and scientific divers about the draft standard for controlling diving practices? What mechanisms are in place to overcome the concerns raised?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Yes, I have seen complaints and issues raised by industrial divers, particularly divers working in association with offshore oil exploration. As a consequence of their concerns in trying to form a working divers code in Australia, there have been further complaints by pearl divers and scientific divers that the standards being sought by industrial divers are too high, if they were to be applied to their industries as well. The Government is aware of all of these concerns.

ANSWER.PARA: There was a meeting on 17 September between the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission and the various sections of the diving fraternity with a view to looking at what best possible standards should be set. As a result, the Commission is now conducting an inquiry. Submissions close on 1 December and, as a result of those submissions, the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission will identify the issues involved and propose a standard for occupational diving. The paper will also recommend for the Commission's ratification a process to be followed to progress the development of that standard. I understand that the Commission is keeping all of the relevant parties involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Would the Minister please inform the Senate as to what specific legislative or regulatory impediment there is preventing Broome airport from becoming an international inbound port for the Kimberley region of Western Australia which, of course, would promote greater industry and tourism opportunities for the area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I assume that Senator Knowles has recently visited Broome.
—-It is in my electorate.

—-I know that it is in Senator Knowles's electorate and I assume she has recently visited there. The primary problem with establishing international airports is not regulatory or legislative, it is commercial. That is evidenced by the very large number of international airlines which have landing rights at various airports around Australia but which choose not to use them.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Hill interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-I cannot answer the question over the interjections of Senator Knowles's colleagues.
—-You don't understand.

—-Why does Senator Hill not answer the question? If there is a legislative or legal barrier to Broome airport, I will be happy to investigate it. I point out to Senator Knowles that it is not simply a question of establishing an international airport and then expecting that the air services are simply going to flow from that. As I said before, there are many officially designated international airports around Australia which have very few international flights--some none at all--where many airlines which have landing rights choose not to exercise them. If there is a legislative barrier to Broome airport of which I am not aware, I will have the matter investigated.

—-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister please advise the Senate accordingly if there is a legislative or regulatory problem that he finds out about as a consequence of that question?
—-Of course I will.

—-My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. In view of the fact that the Treasurer, Mr Kerin, has been quoted in today's Australian as now acknowledging that there is a strong push towards a more interventionist industry policy and that the Government is now required to take action to get the economy moving again, and the Minister's own statement regarding the need for some level of industry assistance and reassessment of the current tax regime to encourage business investment, I ask the Minister: what is his plan to boost industry assistance, and to promote investment in new industries, so that Australia's unemployment level may fall from its current disastrous double digit figure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have not read Mr Kerin's speech. My major concern in all these issues is that we should be competitive in everything we attempt to do and that we should be competitive in attracting investment. If there is anything in the tax structure which needs to be changed in order that we might be competitive in attracting investment, or anything in any other sphere of government activity which needs to be changed in order that we might be more competitive in attracting investment, that should be done.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of couching the debate in interventionist or non-interventionist terms, we are talking about measures of broad application which are applicable across industries and which I do not think fall within the classic description of interventionism which essentially relates to a particular industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —-What are you talking about?

—-If the honourable senator does not understand that, I will give him something to read. The honourable senator does not understand this? He has come out of that rusty, old think-tank in Melbourne. He ought to know about this. He ought to ask his dad about it. He writes about it much more lucidly than the honourable senator ever speaks about it. He knows what he is talking about much better than Senator Kemp does. We are talking about measures of broad application rather than what I think the Australian Democrats or most people would describe as interventionist measures which relate to particular industries. This Government has been interventionist in relation to some particular industries through its period in office. There are some policies which might still be described as interventionist.

—-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Judging by the Minister's remarks on the Sunday program and as reported in the media, he clearly has some very specific measures in mind to boost industry assistance and promote investment. I ask the Minister whether he would be prepared to tell the Senate what they are.

—-I do not think there is anything I said on the Sunday program which would suggest to anybody other than the honourable senator that I have some specific measures in mind. I will try to give the simple version of what I said on the Sunday program, for the benefit of Senators Kemp, Bishop and others. What I said on the Sunday program was essentially what I just said to Senator Sowada, that is, that we have to have a competitive tax structure amongst other things.
—-Tell us how. Give us the details.
—-It is not for me to give the honourable senator the details. I am asking that there be an examination of these matters; that is all.
—-The trouble with you is that you want a quid each way.

—-Senator Bishop interjected in terms of my answer about intervention or non-intervention that I may want something each way. Certainly, Senator. There is nothing wrong with that. One has to be fairly pragmatic about these things, as hundreds of thousands of people in New Zealand are learning at their cost. One has to be fairly pragmatic about it in Britain too, despite the complete rejection of Senator Bishop's mother heroine's views--Margaret Thatcher's views. It is no good Senator Bishop saying that people want it each way. If anybody wants it each way in this place, I think it is the honourable senator.

—-My question is also directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. With reference to the lead article in last Thursday's Australian, which reported Senator Button's concerns about the present taxation system hindering business development, I ask: has not the Government lost a valuable opportunity by not adopting the industry preferred definition of effective life in the recently announced government clarification of the meaning of effective life for depreciation purposes? Further, does not the Minister agree that the redefined cosmetic position of depreciation for both new and second-hand goods refutes the Government's concept of a clever country?

—-This Government last reviewed business taxation in 1988. That is something that the Opposition, when in government, never did. I think it is time to do it again in some areas. In respect of the honourable senator's specific question--if I can shout above the vocal mullahs of this Opposition--if in terms of investment we were to have industry's preferred definition of effective life it would be highly beneficial for investment, but it would be disastrous for the revenue base of this country. There are all sorts of anomalies in it. There is infinite capacity to--how shall I put it; I would not use a word such as `rort' in this place--extract benefits from the proposed definition, which I do not think could be countenanced. It is unfortunate that some formula could not have been derived which took account of the aspects from both definitions. But it was not possible to accept the business definition, although careful consideration was given to it.

—-I ask the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support whether he is aware that a second foreign flag ship, the Mulpha Taiping, entering Townsville harbour, has been refused permission to load cargo because of its poor condition.
—-Of course he is aware.

—-Is Senator Macdonald not concerned about the reef? What action is being taken in relation to this vessel? Furthermore, can a government surveyor be based in the north to monitor the conditions of ships travelling through sensitive Barrier Reef waters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I was in fact contacted on this matter by Senator Reynolds yesterday. I have not actually seen any press reports, but Senator Reynolds, as I understand it, personally carried out an inspection of the ship. Allegations have been made that it is in a very poor state. Allegations have also been made that the crew has not been paid for a period of some months--a matter that Senator Macdonald thinks is hilarious, as he would.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Maritime Safety Authority is currently acting on these reports. Reports have also been received from the Townsville harbour authorities about the condition of this ship and the non-payment of its crew. Under the State port control program an AMSA surveyor is to inspect the vessel today. Based on this report, AMSA will determine what repairs may be necessary to achieve acceptable safety standards on this ship.

Unfortunately, as I have advised the Senate before, this is not an isolated incident. TALK.START.PARA: —-I have an answer to a question from Senator Tambling with respect to the Administrator of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. The honourable senator will recall that he was informed at a Senate Estimates committee hearing on 4 September 1991 that the rate of pay for the position of Administrator of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands is set independently by the Remuneration Tribunal. The Tribunal increased the current rates within the Senior Executive Service band 2 classification in the Australian Public Service with effect from 1 July 1991. The district allowance, which is equivalent to APS grade D where a person is accompanied by one or more dependants, is also fixed independently by the Remuneration Tribunal.

ANSWER.PARA: In assessing the appropriate remuneration for the position the Tribunal took into account the diverse functions and responsibilities of the Administrator, including schools, the postal philatelic bureau, police, housing, environmental protection, electricity, the hospital and airfield operations. Local government functions on Commonwealth land in the Territory, such as the provision of water and sewerage, roads and waste disposal, are also part of the Administrator's responsibility. The Tribunal also took into account the considerable increase in the workload of the position of Administrator.

In March this year the Prime Minister signed with the Cocos community leaders a memorandum of understanding designed to bring conditions and standards of living on Cocos up to mainland standards. The MOU will result in a comprehensive overhaul of almost every aspect of community life within a relatively short timeframe and the Administrator will be the on-islands instigator of and driving force behind the most substantial structural, social and economic changes in Cocos history.

Implementation of these changes by 1 July 1992 is a task of some magnitude. In addition to ensuring the timely planning for and implementation of mainland standards, conditions and practices, the Administrator will also have an important role in ensuring that new and workable arrangements are put in place for future service provision and regulation.

The remuneration received by the Cocos Administrator is commensurate with the task ahead and is now comparable to the remuneration received by the Administrator of Christmas Island. In relation to tax rates, all employees on Cocos, including the Administrator, currently pay 50 per cent of the mainland tax rate and under the phasing in process set out in the MOU, mainland taxation will apply from 1 July 1992.

Dear Ms Giles,
Thank you for your letter of 16 August 1991 expressing concern at the apparent inconsistency in Regulation 27.5 of Statutory Rules No. 148 of 1991.

At the outset, I would explain that this regulation sets out pension valuation factors which are used to calculate the capital value of a pension which is payable for life for the purposes of the reasonable benefit limits.

I agree that there is an inconsistency in the new regulation in that the age ranges overlap, for example, 25 to 30, 30 to 36, 35 to 40 etc. I am advised that the Insurance and Superannuation Commission and the Attorney-General's Department have already discussed a possible amendment for my approval which would resolve this problem.

I would also point out that the pension valuation factors are used only by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission to calculate the capital value of a pension. This is done by multiplying the factor by the dollar value of the pension received in the first year. That capital amount is then compared with the person's reasonable benefit limit.

The factors are, I am advised, used in such a way that where a person falls into two ranges, for example 30 to 35 and 35 to 40 because he or she is aged 35, the range which produces the most advantageous result for the recipient is used. In all cases this is the higher of the two ranges which provides a pension valuation factor which may be lower but cannot be higher. This is because the factors are based on life expectancy and the higher the age range, the shorter the period for which the pension is likely to be paid and hence the lower its capital value. Consequently, I can assure you that there is no financial disadvantage possible to individuals.
I trust that these comments and the intended amendment of this regulation allay your concerns.
Yours sincerely,

Dear Minister,
I refer to the Migration Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1991 No. 201, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 15 August 1991.

The regulations introduce what appears to be a new concept into Australian migration law. This is the "risk factor", which relates to the possibility that an applicant for a visitor's visa may overstay. The risk factor has two alternative components. The first, in r.9A(1)(a), relates to particular individuals in that it is based on whether the applicant has applied for a permanent residence visa in the last five years. However, the second alternative does not relate to the applicant himself or herself, but, as defined in new r.9A(1)(b), applies if an applicant has one or more characteristics in common with a class. These characteristics, set out in r.9A(2), include:
(a) nationality
(b) marital status
(c) age
(d) sex
(e) occupation
(f) class of visa
(g) place of application

The Committee is concerned that broad categories such as nationality or sex are used as the basis for judging an individual. The criteria suggest that an applicant is not being judged on the basis of his or her own application, or on the basis of the applicant's personal conduct.

The Committee asks whether this important and sensitive change in the law, effected by actions of the executive, is expressly contemplated by the parent Act. The Committee would appreciate your advice on other aspects. If there is no express justification for judging people on the grounds of nationality, marital status and sex, what is the statutory basis for this kind of regulation? Will the classes and the statistics (which the regulations require the Secretary to keep) be made public, preferably by tabling in the Parliament? If not, the Committee would be grateful for the reasons.

The Committee, among other things, scrutinises each instrument of delegated legislation to ensure that it does not contain matter more appropriate for parliamentary enactment. The Committee considers that on the face of this instrument that it may breach the principles of the Committee on this ground.
The Committee would be grateful for your detailed advice.
Yours sincerely
Patricia Giles

Dear Senator,
I refer to your letter of 16 August 1991 concerning the Migration Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1991 No. 201, particularly in relation to Sub-Regulation 9A(1)(a) and (b).

The Government, as you will be aware, is conscious of the costs to the Australian taxpayer of the detection and enforced departure of overstayed visitors and these "risk factor" provisions of the Migration Regulations reflect that concern. Nevertheless, the provisions were inserted in the Regulations only after a great deal of careful and personal consideration by myself. In the course of this consideration numerous drafting changes were made to the provisions.

A person or body exercising powers under the Migration Act and Regulations in relation to visit applications must be satisfied--to the degree that prudence and management constraints require--that an applicant intends to make a genuine visit to Australia. In making that determination, the decision maker must have regard to all relevant requirements of the Act and Regulations. The risk factor determined with Regulation 9A is one of the considerations to be taken into account in assessing the individual merits of an application. It is not, of itself, a determining factor.

The effect of the new provisions is that particular persons who share particular characteristics with a "risk" group will be subject to a more careful and detailed assessment. It is important to emphasise, however, that applicants coming within a risk profile group will not be automatically denied a visa. Visas may still be issued provided the applicant satisfies the decisionmaker that the expressed intention to only visit Australia is genuine and, where a Regulation 9A risk factor applies, that, having regard to the applicants circumstances in their country of usual residence, there is very little likelihood that they will overstay. Regulations 88, 89 and 91 to 93 are relevant in this regard. Moreover, as part of the risk factor package, fast track review processes are provided where a refused application may relate to a special family event.

The recent amendments should not be viewed in isolation from existing regulations. Persons applying in the Visitor classes are all required to meet the specific requirements of the class along with the applicable criteria specified in Schedule 1 of the Migration Regulations. Criteria common to each visitor visa are:
assurance of support may be required;
the applicant meets relevant public interest criteria;
the applicant meets relevant health criteria;
the applicant intends to make a genuine visit to Australia and has adequate funds for his or her support during the period of the visit, and
the applicant seeks the visa in order to obtain temporary entry and does not intend to become a permanent resident of Australia.

The intention is that statistics on classes of persons who have overstayed in Australia, as specified in Regulation 9A, will be submitted to the Secretary of my Department for determination. The Secretary's determination will become a public document and will specify a group standard as a percentage against total arrivals. Statistics will be reviewed on a regular basis and, by issue of a new public determination by the Secretary, classes of overstayers may move between "high" and "low" risk categories and vice versa.

It is emphasised that I have not moved away from the concept of individual consideration of applications and that the risk factor is but one of the criteria to be addressed by decisionmakers. I am confident that these new provisions will provide adequate balance between the interests of individual visa applicants and the Australian community.
Should you or your committee have further queries, please contact me.
Yours sincerely,
Gerry Hand

I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate the Australian Maritime College for continuing to improve its worldwide reputation as a maritime college of outstanding quality. The college's report highlights its superb ability to provide outstanding study opportunities for those young Australians wishing to enter the industry. The best available education, training and applied research is anticipated and fulfilled as the college supplies the needs of young Australians and overseas students as its number one priority. Included as part of the report is a letter by Professor David H. Moreby, the recently retired Dean of Faculty of Maritime Studies at the Plymouth Polytechnic in the United Kingdom and currently the Visiting Fellow of the Asia Pacific Maritime Centre. This letter aptly summarises the changes occurring in the present and the possible needs of the college in the future. The Government powers that be would be wise to take note of his comments and ensure that any administrative and bureaucratic restrictions placed on the college as part of the new tertiary reform and amalgamations heed the Professor's brief comments.

As I stated in my comments in previous years on college reports, there is a strong case for examining whether the services of the Australian Maritime College would be better supplied if it continued as an autonomous college. The Australian Maritime College enjoys a unique position within the educational institutions in Australia. The Australian Government should never forget this when examining the funding arrangements for our tertiary institutions. The AMC is the Australian Commonwealth Government's national centre for maritime education and training.

As Professor Moreby notes, most of the well-known maritime schools throughout the world have been closed and those that have remained open find themselves with inadequate funds to re-equip or expand, especially those in the Eastern bloc. He further notes that the present shortage of officers worldwide is 50,000 and that by the year 2,000 there will be a global shortage of 200,000 officers and 60,000 ratings. A unique business opportunity exists here which the college should grasp. The Professor strongly encourages the college to take up the challenge. It is also encouraging to note the support from the ranks of the major shipping management companies, the biggest five of which may be managing 3,000 ships by the end of this century.

The Australian Maritime College is ideally situated to play a leading role in the future training of the world's seafarers, especially in terms of global shipping. The college may be geographically isolated from the rest of Australia but, according to Professor Moreby and already known to those who have an interest in the college, it is well sited globally. Modern shipping is now a global and highly competitive industry and the survival of a modern shipping industry will only occur if we think globally.

I would like to add my voice of encouragement for the college to grasp this business opportunity of providing places of learning for the many officers and ratings who will be needed. I further urge this present Government to recognise the opportunities and encourage the college to pursue this aim. The advantages of the college are many. It is not only superbly situated but, according to Professor Moreby, it is superbly equipped with a highly professional staff, with the added advantage of working under an incorruptible examination system. A visit to the campus by any member of this chamber will verify these comments.

Internally, the structure of the college's courses is also unique and reflects a necessary worldwide shipping change. All recruits--cadets and ratings--share a common first year at the college. Consequently, Australia is showing the world how to break away from the traditional, but now outdated, antisocial and costly division between officers and ratings aboard ship.

More importantly, Professor Moreby has noted that the college recognises and upgrades the professionalism of all its students, a feature well worth imparting to the many future maritime students. Not only would the college itself benefit from tapping into the business opportunities but so also would the economic life of the environs of Launceston. Launceston, with the northern campus of the University of Tasmania situated within its city limits, has the capacity and capability of becoming possibly the leading centre for tertiary studies Australia-wide. By pursuing the possibility of attracting further overseas students, the AMC will add positively to this.
In conclusion, I would like to reiterate Professor Moreby's comments that `the Australian Maritime College has within its grasp the crown of being the premier maritime college of the world'.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

I want to make a few comments on the 1990-91 annual report of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. I take this opportunity to highlight what appears to me to be the uncontrolled use by the ABS of outside consultants. The report for 1989-90 detailed the use of 53 outside consultancies at a total cost of $679,241. The report that is presented today lists 67 consultancies.

Whilst that is a reasonably small increase of only 14 consultants over the consultancies used last year, it is more important to note that the monetary value of that increase for the year 1990-91 is $1,500,721. This represents a massive increase in just 12 months of $821,472 or 121 per cent. One really has to ask what the reasons and the rationale behind such an increase are.

I suppose it could be said--as we as politicians are told from time to time--that the increased use of consultants is directly related to the desire to reduce existing staff. In this particular case, upon examination of the annual report it seems that in the last financial year the ABS had an average staff level of 3,356, whereas the number grew to 3,489 in 1990-91. In other words, whilst the ABS employed these extra consultants and increased its consultancy rate by 121 per cent, it also increased its staff level by 133.

Another matter of concern arising out of this report as far as I can see is the high number of outside consultancies which have been appointed without any kind of public tendering process or advertising. Of the 67 consultancies appointed by the Australian Bureau of Statistics during 1990-91, only three were publicly advertised. Quite frankly, I believe that is totally unacceptable. It means that during the year the Bureau saw fit to engage consultants worth $1.186m in a completely closed shop situation, without any advertising or outside tendering.

Under the circumstances in which these consultancies have been given, it is virtually impossible to guarantee that the Australian taxpayer has received the best deal possible. Anyone may be of the view that those consultancies let without public advertising may have been of a minor nature. I can assure the Senate that they were not and I would like to quote one or two examples to reinforce these claims. One particular outside consultancy of $169,460 went to the National Recording Studios Group Pty Ltd; another one of $219,953 was awarded to Rainbow Software Pty Ltd; another of $100,600 went to Reark Research Pty Ltd for market research on ABS products and service; and another of $48,722 went to the Communication Research Institute of Aust Inc. as consultants on work effectiveness.

It seems ridiculous to me that, even though there has been an increase in staff of 133, there has been a 121 per cent increase in consultancies and, most importantly, apart from three, all these in-house consultancies have been let without any public tendering system or any way in which the Parliament could query those particular tenders.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Australian Bureau of Statistics provides a very high quality, independent statistical service to the Australian community. I wish to comment on a few of the issues currently facing the Bureau. SPEECH.PARA: This so-called respondent burden is sometimes very heavy on small business, and this was recognised by the Beddall Committee report on small business. I would appreciate some statement on this matter, either by the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) or the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall), so that we can see what progress has been made and judge for ourselves what more may need to be done.

The second area is the harmonisation of the presentation of State Budgets and financial information. The Premiers Conference, which was held in May, agreed to seek the harmonisation of State financial reporting and the uniform adoption of the methodology of the Australian Bureau of Statistics in the preparation of the various State Budget documents. It is a sad commentary on this country that such harmonisation has taken over 90 years. But the Australian Democrats support this initiative and commend the States for their cooperation.

The third area I wish to comment on is that of environmental statistics. The Bureau has started to collect a variety of statistics by adding additional questions to the existing questionnaires which are distributed to business and other respondents. Examples include motor vehicle usage and the purpose of the purchase of the particular size of vehicle. Details on pollution abatement control costs in manufacturing and mining will also be collected this year, and some as yet undetermined questions concerning land care, land degradation and pesticide use will be included in the agricultural census. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

I rise to speak on the National Health and Medical Research Council's report of its 111th session from Brisbane in June 1991. In particular, I highlight the third last dot point on page 6. Under a list of things done by the executive committee in its report to the annual general meeting this year, there is a reference to the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance. It is the report of the Senate Select Committee which I chaired and which was presented to this place last December. Its principal recommendation was that further examination of quality health care in this country might properly be done by asking the National Health and Medical Research Council to conduct a debate with the community, a debate in public, about what we mean by quality care and how we order our priorities.

We are aware of the importance of the community being informed, not with emotional debates about any particular case as we see sometimes on television programs but with a thoughtful understanding of just what the costs involved are, particularly in the new high-tech medical areas; for example, some $75,000 to keep a premature baby alive in a humidicrib. Does the community want to spend that $75,000 on helping that one little baby or does it want, for example, to put that $75,000 towards the immunisation of all children?

We should look at the costs, whether of liver and heart-lung transplants, new technology procedures for organ replacement or other procedures. I do not think anybody begrudges the cost of microsurgery on the little baby's hand over the weekend, which took plastic surgeons--I do not know how many--12 hours. The cost of that must have been huge. Everybody is delighted that there is even a prospect that that child--I think it was a little boy--will keep his hand. But the cost of that to the community has to be considered. I do not think anyone would begrudge it. We all say, `If it were my child I hope that we could meet the cost', but somewhere along the line the community needs to know the cost. It needs to be asked to make decisions. It needs to know whether that dollar outlay contributes to the quality of health care.

We have recently seen a fairly significant return to the public agenda of Medicare. I was very disappointed to read in the Weekend Australian an article by a journalist--I think a Mr Lynch whose first name I cannot reliably remember--who seemed to suggest things about Medicare. I certainly want to dispute these with him, and I will do that this week.

First, it was said that anybody who wants to go to a public hospital cannot; that they are being filled by private patients; and that there is a huge increase in waiting lists in the public sector and yet there are unused beds in the private sector. These comments simply betray a failure to know the facts and a failure to understand the real issues in health care. For the record, over about the last three years the waiting lists have dropped from 100,000 to 70,000. They are agreed figures. Rubbery and all as those figures are, one admits that there has been a significant drop in the waiting lists for admission to public hospitals.

Secondly, the article suggests that many of those procedures cannot be done in the surplus beds in the private system, and that the private system is busy trying to remove some of those surplus beds. They are not just there waiting to be occupied. They are actually surplus to demand. The private hospital sector will tell people that it is also interested in selectively getting rid of some of them. Thirdly, the article suggests the private health insurance is in a state of total disarray, teetering on the edge of crisis and that it soon will no longer exist. That is also not the fact.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I am pleased to have the opportunity, because of your having taken the chair, to say a few words today about the Medicare debate. I urge people to try to find the facts and not run with the preferred fictions in this complex area. It will not help the health of the Australian community, it will not help the quality of medical practice if we keep arguing from falsehoods. We must get those facts right.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

In that event, I simply seek leave of the Senate to resume the debate on the procedure for the presentation of committee reports, which is the first item dealing with the second report of 1991 of the Procedure Committee.

—-An accusation has been made about me.
—-The accusation was that you were reading very fast and, if you would not mind, I will call you in a minute to speak to that.

—-I beg your pardon. I will be advised on the order in which we should proceed. If you wanted to speak, I understood that you would be able to speak. I thought Senator McMullan might clarify things to allow you then to speak in context. I call the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--I want to make it clear that I was astonished that no-one took up the first motion that I moved. —-I should like the record to note that the Minister's statement about being surprised that no-one made any comment is true. I shall ask Senator McMullan to comment and then we will tidy up things.

—-I acknowledge that the first motion is one we will have to deal with because Senator Lewis had previously indicated his interest. —-Could I suggest a procedure for next time, that is, that the series of motions that the Minister at the table intends to move in relation to the Procedure Committee be previously circulated.

I am suggesting that next time, if the series of motions that the Minister intends to move were circulated, we might overcome some of the difficulties that we are now presented with. Instead of honourable senators having on their Notice Paper that the subject is simply the debate of the Procedure Committee report, they could then see clearly what the Minister at the table intends to move and could relate that to the Procedure Committee report. We would not then get into the difficulties that we have had today. I offer that in good faith and in an effort to try to facilitate debate on the next occasion. I do not know why bad temper on the Government side was introduced. I am simply trying to help proceedings in the future.

—-by leave--I take it that this is what has happened. The proposals were that the recommendations as circulated be adopted. Senator Coates is indicating that that is the case, so I assume that is so. There were some matters I would like to have raised in regard to standing order 25 and the Estimates committees but, in view of what has happened, I shall not raise them. I simply ask for the recommittal of and debate on the first item of the report of the Procedure Committee, namely, the procedure for presentation of committee reports.

—-As I understand it, there was a suggestion from Senator McMullan that, as most of those recommendations have been put as motions, we should put them and then seek suspension to go back to only the ones of objection. It is also my recollection that I have not yet put the motion about recommendation No. 7.

—-I am attempting to ascertain precisely what item No. 7 is. As Senator Hill said, it would be helpful if a list were given to honourable senators. I only heard in my room, when I was engaged on other things, reference to motion No. 7. Now I am focusing on what that is. Am I to assume that a new standing order is proposed?
—-No, it is the modification on page 7.
—-That is new standing order 62, as I understand it.
—-It is an amendment to standing order 62, to insert the words that are in bold, `Government responses to such reports'.
—-Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President.

—-If there is no further comment or objection on item 7, I shall put the question that motion No. 7--I hope everyone knows we are talking about the motion to amend standing order 62--as moved by Senator Tate, be agreed to.

That motion No. 1 moved by Senator Tate be recommitted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —-I would like to give an explanation. It is proposed that when Senate committee reports come before the Senate the time limit for debate will be 30 minutes and no senator shall be allowed to speak for more than five minutes. I understand that the reason for this is to enable us to move on to other business.

SPEECH.PARA: If a report is of sufficient importance, it may very well be debated on another day. The first thing that leaps to mind is what one does with the very controversial reports that are sometimes tabled in the Senate. My mind goes back to the committees I was involved with which inquired into the conduct of a judge and television equalisation and the committee which looked at drugs in sport.

It has been put to me privately that the Whips would enter into an arrangement to extend the time for debate on such a report. Honourable senators would be able only to touch upon such reports if five minutes were afforded to each speaker and a total of 30 minutes were allowed for debate. Because some matters are so controversial and of such public interest, views have to be expressed when a report is presented. The problem is that, if senators who serve on such committees are not given adequate time to speak in the Senate, they may have to conduct press conferences of some sort in order to express their views.

I am a parliamentarian and I happen to believe in the Parliament and, in particular, the Senate. It is my view that the first responsibility of senators is to report to the Senate, not the Press Gallery. So it is my view that time for adequate debate ought to be given, especially in respect of those sorts of reports. One might say that in that event the Whips would agree to a longer debate. But, of course, a very subjective judgment has to be made in this respect. While senators who serve on the committee concerned may consider that a report warrants longer debate, others--the Whips and the party leaders--may think that it does not. So, while I understand the nature and purpose of the proposal, I have great difficulty in agreeing in the initial stages that we ought to go about it in the reverse way--in other words, that we ought to limit our debate to only 30 minutes all of the time, except when we make exceptions.

My view is that honourable senators have in fact behaved very well in regard to committee reports. Very frequently, senators have limited debate to five minutes per senator who wishes to speak and to 30 or perhaps 45 minutes for the debate. I think that is the way to go rather than to apply limitations in the way proposed.

If the recommendation had been more generous--perhaps limiting debate to 10, 12 or 15 minutes per person with no gross time limit of 30 minutes--I might have given it more serious consideration. But the proposal to squeeze the debating time to 30 minutes with not more than five minutes per speaker seems to me to be wrong and, therefore, I have to oppose it.

The Senate has always been of the view that its committees are a vital part of its procedures. We are very proud of our committee work. It seems to me that we would be derogating from the value of that work if we were to limit the time for debate in such a way. Some of the reports which committees are currently considering will clearly be of major interest to all senators.

Not only is the written report important but also the oral report which senators make to the Senate is of great importance. In particular, the oral report is of great value to those senators who have strictly obeyed the Standing Orders throughout a committee's inquiry. It has been my experience that when committees are inquiring into major controversial matters some senators, their staff or someone else who is involved in some way or another seem to communicate certain aspects of the inquiry to the media.

We know that that is contrary to Standing Orders but it happens frequently. As a result, the media can develop a slanted view of the nature of a report. Those senators who adhere strictly to the Standing Orders can be put in a position where they feel frustrated because they want to say to the media, `You are wrong. That is not the way I see the evidence and it is not the way we see the evidence on our side'. But because they have obeyed the Standing Orders they do not get a chance to say this until the report comes down. Then, for the first time, they have the opportunity to say publicly what they want to say. That is why I say that this proposal is far too restrictive.

The minority report of a report put down recently was not mentioned in the media in any way. This minority report was printed at the back of the report of the committee concerned. The journalists had read only the recommendations in the front, which did not include any reference to the minority report. So it was really of great importance, in that case, that there was proper debate within the Senate.

I say to the people who have recommended shortening the time for Senate debate on reports that they are going about it in the wrong way. It is far better to have the Whips limit the debate by arrangement rather than have them going about it the other way and extending the time for debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I would like to make a contribution to the discussion on this matter, as I had something to do with it getting this far--a fact that might put Senator Lewis off the proposal altogether. The purpose of the proposal is to give greater prominence to committee reports. At the moment, committee reports are tabled after a whole lot of other procedures have been dealt with--after Question Time, after any matter of public importance or urgency motion, after 30 minutes of discussing Government documents and after any stoushes that may occur. Often, a committee which has spent weeks, months and maybe years compiling a major report ends up tabling its report at 6.30 or 7 o'clock in the evening. Its efforts to get any recognition at all are totally frustrated because of the hour and the pressures on the Chair to incorporate the tabling statement in Hansard. By then it is too late to organise any sort of press coverage. So all of those months and years of work can disappear with no notice being taken of the report at all. The basic proposal is that committee reports be able to be tabled in the morning on Wednesdays and Thursdays before government business takes over the rest of the period.
—-Where does it say that?

—-No, it does not say that; this is a necessary requisite to that. For there to be a tabling of committee reports in the mornings so that a committee can confidently organise a press conference for the chair, the whole committee or whatever, and for there to be due recognition of the committee's work, there needs to be some acknowledgment that that process cannot always be open-ended; otherwise the whole morning might be taken up with committee reports without any opportunity for other business.
—-So the chair can't dash off to the Press Club.

—-Not just the chair; anybody can speak to the media about it. As honourable senators know, we are limited in that until the report is tabled. This proposal actually came to life because of an unfortunate episode concerning the tabling of a committee report--it was expected that the report would be tabled late in the afternoon on a particular day--when remarks were made to the media by a member of the committee. As it turned out, because of some delay in the proceedings of the Senate, the tabling of the report was not reached on that day; it was not tabled until the next day or maybe some days after that and, therefore, an issue of privilege arose.
—-It wasn't unfortunate; it was a blatant leaking to the media before the report was tabled. It wasn't unfortunate; it was gross misbehaviour.

—-I will not adopt Senator Crichton-Browne's portrayal of the matter. Yes, the senator concerned should not have spoken to the media before the report was actually tabled, but it was legitimately expected that it was going to be tabled. Of course, when there are deadlines concerned, people can be tempted, as on that occasion, into making assumptions about a report being tabled. This is a proposal not to downgrade committee reports but to upgrade them so that there is an agreed right to have committee reports tabled in the mornings, which would then allow the rest of the day for any media coverage.

SPEECH.PARA: On the issue of the limits of five minutes for each speaker and 30 minutes for the debate, those proposals are a necessary compromise. I agree that five minutes is a relatively short time but more often than not when a report is tabled, unless it is a really substantial report, the committee chair incorporates the tabling statement in Hansard, so no time is taken at all. This proposal for five minutes is to allow a basic statement to be made by each member of the committee--acknowledging the situation where minority positions are being taken--highlighting the contents of the report.

Honourable senators need to remember that we are not talking about debate on the report. That comes later because at that time nobody except the committee has seen the report. The substance of the report--whether the majority report or any minority report--is in the document and anybody who wants the whole argument ought to read the document. The time limit of five minutes was proposed to allow each member of the committee to state the basic outline of his or her position on the report, to highlight it and to attract interest in the report from other senators, the media and the public.

If we do not adopt this, we will effectively go back to the situation of having the right to speak for 30 minutes, but maybe well into the evening, if all those other processes have taken place. This is an attempt not to downgrade committee reports and the work of committees but to provide an opportunity for the reports to be tabled early in the day, for basic outlines of the position to be given to the Senate, so that the Senate is the first to hear what is in the reports and then to have the matter debated on the following Wednesday in accordance with the procedures. I ask those opposite not to represent this proposal as something that is contrary to the interests of Senate committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am very concerned about the time limit. I am not quite sure how the Procedure Committee could possibly adopt a limit of five minutes for each speech with a total of 30 minutes for the debate. A committee I am on has eight members. How do we resolve who speaks and who is excluded from that 30 minutes? We perhaps could have Senator Lees of the Australian Democrats completely excluded from putting her minority report view. The whole thing is too ridiculous for words.

SPEECH.PARA: Committees have sometimes spent a couple of years putting forward a report. I have been on a couple of those committees where the report has been very extensive, complicated and lengthy. It is no use Senator Coates saying that the first debate is not the full debate. Of course the first debate is the prominent one. Senator Coates has admitted that it is. Senator Coates is saying that the prominent debate is where the media can get the opportunity to have a full overview of the report. For Senator Coates to say that it is not the full debate and that we come to that stage later is a lot of rubbish. Firstly, we have to have more than five minutes and, secondly, the 30-minute total is just too ridiculous for words. As I have said, if there is one Democrat--as there is on one of the committees of which I am a member--he or she might be excluded altogether. The injustice of that would be extraordinary. To say that someone has five minutes to speak and to have a 30-minute full debate on a report that has taken two years to compile is ridiculous.

Senator Lewis has said very clearly that there has been general agreement that we have a short debate on a report, particularly if the committee reference has not been complicated and the committee has not gone into great detail. It appears that the Senate is forever trying to curtail the rights of senators in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —-You didn't listen to what I said, did you?

—-I did not believe a word of what Senator Coates said. What he said was a load of rubbish, I admit. I certainly listened to it. Senator Coates said that it is not the main debate. That is a load of rubbish. He then said, `It is the main debate that the media will take note of'. That is ludicrous. If we say that for media attention we should all make five-minute speeches, no wonder the media come forward with such superficial reports on committee reports. It is essential that if there are minority reports--there can be two minority reports, perhaps even three minority reports--if the committee works properly and not according to party lines, as has happened in the recent past since the Labor Government has been--
—-If the committee works properly there is probably no minority report.
—-Senator Faulkner does not understand the situation. I assure him that in the past there have been party divisions in reports on many issues.
—-Not until you fellows rorted the system and had nothing but party apparatchiks on it. We used to have some people with a bit of thought on that side of the chamber.

—-That is right. Indeed, in the very first committee that I sat on the report came down with two Labor members and one Liberal member on one side and two Liberal members and one Labor member on the other. That is how the committee system used to work. It now no longer works that way; we go down party lines all the way.
