SPEECH.PARA: Those opposite did divide the Senate on the video industry report in which I was involved. Some Labor members came over to our side to issue the majority report and the Chairman had to put forward a minority report. Surely Senator Coates would not for a moment think that his colleagues who had deserted their Chairman would not want to put forward an explanation of that to the media. Those people will want to explain their position. They will want to say why the Chairman is putting forward a minority report. For those opposite to say that this can only be done through a quick five-minute debate so that the media can get the hang of it is a lot of rubbish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I support what has been said by my colleagues Senator Lewis and Senator Walters. It is absurd to propose that this Parliament provide each member of a committee with a five-minute opportunity to reflect on the process of deliberation and ultimately the determination.

SPEECH.PARA: As I came out of my room to attend this debate, I had time to bring with me a copy of one report to which I made a modest contribution. Indeed, Mr Acting Deputy President, you made a more significant contribution because you were the Deputy Chairman of that Committee and I was but a humble member. The report to which I refer and which I have in my hand runs to over 700 pages and covers about two years' work. I remember that on countless occasions I was required to spend seven hours on aeroplanes flying from Perth to Canberra to participate in those contemplations and deliberations. At the end of that endurance test, at the end of the day, senators having contributed to the report an enormous amount of energy, time, effort and intellectual stimulation, we are now told that it is proposed that each participant, if he or she is lucky, will have five minutes to speak on the deliberations, the content of the report and the determinations.

I could instance the drugs in sport inquiry which we have heard much about. There were two reports on that subject running to 500 or 600 pages. Also, I could turn to the report on the resource potential of Kakadu National Park. The minority report on that topic, which I wrote, was about 150 pages. However, I am told that it is proposed I would have five minutes to discuss it.

TALK.START.PARA: —-If you were one of the speakers.

—-Yes, if I were one of the speakers and I got the call, I would have five minutes to explain beyond the written word why I disagreed with the majority report and to give substance to the arguments contained in the minority report. Such a suggestion is absurd. We are now told by Senator Coates, who seems to have some special knowledge that is not available to those of us on this side of the chamber, that part of the rationale is to ensure that the chairman or chairwoman can have a press conference.
—-Or any member of the committee.

—-If the distinction between `any member of the committee' and the chairman were not understood by Senator Coates, I would find him remarkably politically naive. We are told that the special hidden agenda is to allow the chairman of the committee to give a press conference, and, in view of the deadlines, the report would have to be tabled in the morning so that the chairman could salivate on his remarks next day.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought that the primary responsibility of members of a committee was to report to the Parliament; otherwise why bother? Apart from the question of libel or defamation, why not publish it to the community as a whole? Why bother to report back to the Parliament? We are now told that it is simply a mechanism to get the thing out and get it to the media. I find that profoundly obnoxious.

In my view it significantly downgrades and devalues the work and endeavours of these committees, which sometimes stretch over two years. The Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, for instance, has an international reputation for bipartisan quality and endeavour. Those reports will be devalued by simply being dropped in the Senate. Any reader of Hansard with an interest in the circumstances which led to the deliberations and ultimately to the findings in the report, either the minority or the majority report, will find a barrenness throughout the Hansard. It seems to me, as best I can tell from listening to the inadequacy of the debate from the other side, that this is simply about getting the chairman into a press conference beforehand. No intellectual argument has been put forward to give substance to the proposal to reduce such debate to five minutes.

With reports of this nature it would be quite impossible to say in five minutes anything of substance which could be sensibly interpreted later. I argue that the present process should prevail, that is, that each person be entitled to speak for 30 minutes. I have heard you, Mr Acting Deputy President, speak for 30 minutes on reports. When one has been living with a report for some time, it is important that the nuances, the circumstances and the matters that are not contained in the written word should be put into Hansard, not only to buttress but to supplement and add to the substance of the report. I find it absurd that again we are being asked to speak for only five minutes in an attempt to gag sensible and intelligent deliberation in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: -Manager of Government Business in the Senate (4.22 p.m.)

TALK.START.PARA: —-If the assumptions outlined by Senator Crichton-Browne at the conclusion of his remarks are accurate, the conclusions to which he came might be accurate. But the situation, as I was advised when we first dealt with this matter in the Procedure Committee and as has been confirmed subsequently, is not that we are here reducing to five minutes a right to a half-hour debate. We are introducing a right where no right exists. At present reports when tabled can be debated only by leave. Without leave they cannot be debated at all. Then the debate comes when it properly should come, which is when other senators have had a chance to look at the matter, and the Senate has a full debate.

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment we have no right; we have an opportunity to exercise by agreement a more comprehensive debate. We have here a proposal that there is a basic right which can as easily be extended by leave as is the case in the existing situation, where there is no right. Those opposite are operating on a false premise. There was no agenda in the Procedure Committee for the Government to seek to limit debate. This was a unanimous decision of the Procedure Committee. The conclusion, arrived at after some consideration, was that what we were doing was enhancing the situation for senators, not in any way restricting it, and in particular protecting the rights of the dissentients. By introducing the total time limit and the individual time limit for each senator so that a minimum of six would have an opportunity to speak, those in the minority cannot be excluded from taking part of that time.

The rationale for the two part recommendation is an overall time limit subdivided in such a way that any dissentient cannot be silenced by the ganging up of the majority, the Chair or somebody else to use up all the time. That is the rationale. The proposal is a conscious attempt to put in a right where no right exists and to ensure that that right cannot be abused by majorities to suppress the rights of minorities to make their initial opening remarks when they are tabling very comprehensive documents which, in the main, speak for themselves but about which people want to highlight the principal points and make some introductory remarks prior to their subsequent full speeches when the debates come before the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —-How long will they get then?

—-I assume it would be half an hour. We are not proposing to change anything with regard to that. This proposal does not relate to that matter; it explicitly says that people can speak again when the matter comes up under standing order 62. This does not limit any existing right. It creates a new right which can be enhanced by leave, the same leave that honourable senators need to exercise the right to speak at the moment. It was the understanding of everybody on the Procedure Committee that there would sometimes be circumstances where, on the very first day, there may need to be more debate. That would be done then, as it is now--by agreement, by leave.
—-But you would have to suspend Standing Orders then.

—-It is no harder. Now, unanimous agreement is needed because it is done by leave--any dissentient can stop somebody speaking. Under this proposal that cannot happen and a minimum right would be established. I do not want to start World War III over this because we are all trying to do the same thing. I assure those opposite that no-one on the Procedure Committee wanted in any way to impair the right of any senator.
—-Senator McMullan, I think you won't get 30 minutes the second time. The present standing order allows for 10 minutes, if I remember correctly.
—-Honourable senators will get whatever they currently get. All I am saying is that that is not affected by this motion.
—-What this motion does is take you from 30 minutes to five and maintains everything else.
—-No, speakers do not have 30 minutes at the moment.
—-You do by leave.

—-Yes, that is right and that is how they will get it in future. As I say, I do not want this to be the cause of any controversy because it was the unanimous intention of the Procedure Committee that this should enhance the rights of honourable senators and protect that minimum position. I want to make sure that we do not portray this debate as the Government somehow putting forward a proposal to stop the Opposition and others speaking. It was agreed on all sides because we all wanted to achieve the same objective. The recommendations put to us indicated that that was appropriate. I make it clear, as does the motion, that this was intended only as a trial for the remainder of this session--that is, it lasts until the end of 1991. The motion is explicit with regard to that.

SPEECH.PARA: If it is going to be a major cause of controversy, I will not have a division or anything like that over it because it is not worth that to me. It is simply an attempt to enhance the procedures of the Senate, not to limit them. I make this offer in advance: let us try it for the rest of this year with the assurance that if any major report needs greater debate it will be facilitated, as it would have been in the past. If, during the remainder of 1991, we find it is inadequate either because we do not need the motion at all or because the terms of the motion are inappropriate, by its very nature it will have to go back to the Procedure Committee because it expires at the end of this year.

I ask the Senate to accept that the unanimous decision of the Committee was taken to enhance the rights of honourable senators, not to limit them. There may be problems that none of us foresaw, although nothing I have heard until now persuades me that it will not work as intended. I accept the bona fides of the concerns of the people who raise it. They also want to protect the rights of honourable senators, and protect the status of their Committee reports and ensure that they can properly be debated.

The most appropriate procedure, given that we have come forward with this unanimous report, is that we carry the motion, try it until the end of the year and, if it does not work, it will go back to the Procedure Committee for further consideration. I am happy to give those opposite a bit more time to consider this because I do not want to force it to a division. It is not my intention to be in any way disruptive about it. I would hope that we can get an agreement to try it until the end of this year, at which stage it will come back to the Senate--and I do not need to give an undertaking that it will because the resolution, by its very nature, will expire. I have no desire to railroad this through, even if I could. All I want to do is put the unanimous proposal of the Procedure Committee to the Senate in the spirit in which it was intended, ask honourable senators to give it the trial for which it was intended and let us examine the outcome at that stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--I understand the point that Senator McMullan is making. I say to members of the Procedure Committee that from time to time they go down the wrong path. I understand that they might even do it unanimously, but from time to time it does happen that a Senate committee has gone down the wrong path. I can give a very good example in relation to metrication. A committee unanimously recommended that this country metricate at an enormous cost to the economy--approximately $2,000 billion--for no reason at all, so that we now travel in kilometres instead of miles.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to ask Senator McMullan--if we are considering amending the motion--to consider the proposition that every speaker be granted a time rather than have a limited number of speakers for up to 30 minutes. If every member of the Committee were able to speak, debate would be limited to a maximum of 40 minutes on the five-minute proposal anyway. The first proposition was that every member of the Committee be entitled to speak. Time after time, senators have had the opportunity to find out how much or how little they can fit into five minutes because we do that with regard to reports. That time limit is so brief that I put it to Senator McMullan that there should not be less than eight minutes, even at that early stage. What I am saying is: would the Committee reconsider the matter and bring it back to us along the lines that I am suggesting?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Acting Deputy President, as you know, we do not take a party position on matters that involve the business of the Senate. I am a member of the Procedure Committee. I supported this provision because I believed it would give honourable senators an added right to that which they have at the moment and may well facilitate their getting publication of important aspects of their reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, my colleagues who have spoken today have put forceful arguments. One that particularly brought me from my room was the reminder that some committees have eight members and this provision deals with an opportunity for only six to speak. The best course of action, particularly bearing in mind that the Senate has now had this matter before it for about an hour, would be to refer it back to the Procedure Committee for further consideration.
Motion (by Senator McMullan)--by leave--agreed to:
That resolution No. 1, relating to procedure for presentation of committee reports, be referred to the Procedure Committee for further consideration.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The three allied Bills that we are debating, namely, the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1991-92, the Appropriation Bill (No.1) 1991-92 and the Appropriation Bill No. 2 1991-92, constitute what is commonly known as the Budget Bills. These Bills are being brought down at a time when the Government is in the midst of the largest budgetary deterioration since at least the early 1950s, and arguably in our whole history.

SPEECH.PARA: Over a period of two short years there has been a deterioration in the Budget outcome of almost $13 billion. It has gone from a surplus of $8 billion in 1989-90 to an expected deficit of $4.7 billion in the current year. In fact, after taking into account the important transactions that are commonly described as `below the line', and which therefore do not appear in the Budget but which all have the same impact on the economy, the effect of the public sector on economic activity is much worse than the headline `Budget deficit $4.7 billion' suggests.

If we adjust for asset sales, the transfer of maturing debts to the States, net payments from government business enterprises, superannuation and profit transfers from the Reserve Bank and the Commonwealth Bank, the underlying Budget deficit in 1991-92 is about $10.7 billion, not the $4.7 billion shown in the Budget. Compared with an underlying Budget surplus, on a similar basis of calculation, in 1989-90 of $6.4 billion, on that measurement there has been an overall fiscal deterioration over the past two years alone of some $17 billion. As I said earlier, that is probably unprecedented in Australian history; if not, it is certainly unprecedented for many, many decades.

At a time when Australia is crying out for national leadership and budgetary leadership through the Budget and in other ways, all that the Government members can do is fight amongst themselves over who should lead the tattered remains of the tattered Australian Labor Party. At a time when every effort should be put into establishing the right climate for investment and jobs on a sustainable basis, this Budget is reduced to an exercise in protecting one job and one job alone, that is, the job of the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke.

Given the long term damage to the lives of millions of average Australians which the Government has caused, it is difficult to comprehend how a Party which calls itself the Labor Party and which once had a reputation--now nothing more than a distant memory--for concern for the well-being of working people could become such an instrument of destruction. That is an irony which must be profoundly depressing to philosophers of the labour movement. That does not seem to concern members of this Government. For one reason, they are not philosophers. For another, their focus is on preserving political power and their own privileges, not on the well-being of average Australians. That is the only reason one could give as an explanation for why they have so callously thrown one million people out of work.

As I said, this Budget has been brought down at a time when Australia is in the deepest recession that it has been in for 60 years. It is a Budget which should have been about growth and could have been about growth. It should have been and could have been about job creation and the alleviation of the misery and hardship incurred by the people of Australia over the last eight years of the Hawke-Keating Government. It should have been about jobs, jobs and more jobs. Instead, this Budget is about fewer jobs, more unemployment and more hardship for all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Hawke's job.

—-As my friend Senator Kemp said, and as I remarked earlier, this Budget is all about the preservation of one job; that is, the job of the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. The tragedy of this Budget is that it fails to do anything about the underlying causes of our problems. In fact, the Budget was dead in the water within hours of its release. The unravelling process has already started in just a few weeks since the Budget. A classic example and the most recent is the $70m deterioration in the Budget position--a further $70m that will be added to the Budget deficit this year as a result of the Government's failure to exert sufficient leadership to make the Medicare changes that were announced in the Budget stick. The Government has had to come to a very tacky compromise with its backbench on the Medicare proposal. As a result, the public purse will lose $70m this year--a year when the Budget deficit is, in any event, far too large.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget forecasts an increase in unemployment from a figure of around 10 per cent to a figure that will peak--according to the Government--at 10.75 per cent and which, for a year as a whole, will average 10.5 per cent. There are a couple of points to be made about that. Everyone knows that those figures are underestimates of the real level of unemployment in this country because, taking all factors into consideration, the number of unemployed in Australia today is well in excess of one million people.

The Budget forecasts include provision for an estimate of an average level of unemployment benefit recipients this year of 775,000 persons per month. The average level of recipients in the first three months of this year has been only 710,000. So the Budget is proposing--and the Budget forecasts contain--a further enormous increase to well over a peak of 775,000 in unemployment benefit recipients in the course of this year, in the months ahead. What is the situation? We have the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) and other senior Ministers telling us that the employment outlook will improve in the second half of 1991-92. The Budget figures belie that. The Government's own Budget figures indicate a further substantial increase in unemployment.

Since the Budget, and for months preceding it, in terms of government in this country we have seen nothing but division, leadership squabbles and leadership tensions and battles. That has absolutely obliterated from the public's mind any approach to rational economic policy, or any other policy, or any concern at all for the needs and sufferings of so many millions of Australians, as we have today. We have a bitterly divided Government. It is bitterly divided on the question of the leadership.

In this chamber alone, of the six most senior Government Ministers, three of them--Senator Gareth Evans, Senator Robert Ray and Senator Tate--supported the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, in the leadership battle. Another three Ministers, including the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, along with the numbers man, Senator Richardson--who used to be Prime Minister Hawke's numbers man--and Senator Cook, are supporting Paul Keating. So members of the Ministry are deeply divided as to who they think should be their leader, and that is reflecting indecision and divisiveness right across the board of policy making. The same applies to the subject of interest rates: we never know where Senator Button is on this issue, but people such as Mr Dawkins are advocating cuts in interest rates whereas the Prime Minister and the Treasurer are saying they do not want cuts.

There is a division in terms of tax policy. Only in the past few days there was the extraordinary spectacle of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, who is also the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, implying that the business tax environment in this country is not competitive. Yet in Bangkok over the weekend the Treasurer said, `Yes, it is'.

We have another deep division in the whole area of resources policy. In recent days the Medicare backflips, sideflips and every other sort of flip have shown that the Government is deeply divided on the health policy. As a whole, industry policy is in an awful mess. There are enormous gulfs between the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly, and other Ministers on environmental issues.

We have another extraordinary situation in the division in the Government ranks on media policy and the almost incomprehensible statement yesterday on television by Senator Button again that he abstained from voting in Cabinet last week on the question of the rules concerning media ownership because he did not believe that Ministers had been bound by a Cabinet decision. How on earth can the third most senior Minister in this country, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, say that he did not believe that Ministers were bound by a Cabinet decision? It is just another example of the tensions and the divisions that exist within the Government.

The list goes on in policy areas. The whole approach to the jobs policy is also a dreadful shambles. Government Ministers are deeply divided on that. On one hand we have the interventionists and on the other we have those who subscribe to a more free market approach, and we have a great shifting mass in the middle. No-one inside or outside of government knows just where the Government is heading on that.

We have deep divisions in the area of Commonwealth-State relations. The Prime Minister ostensibly wants to go down the route of a more rational division of Commonwealth, State and local government functions, with the Commonwealth Government getting out of some of its present areas of functioning and responsibility. Important senior Ministers such as Senator Richardson say, `No, we have to stick to the old centralist mode that we have had for so many years under this Government'. So, again, in a key area of potential micro-economic reform--indeed, arguably the most important area of micro-economic reform facing us over the next decade--the Government is deeply divided.

No wonder there is universal criticism within the business community of the policies of the Government. There is great confusion within the business community about the policy-making processes and decisions. There is great confusion because of the conflicting signals given by many Ministers--for example, by the Treasurer on interest rates. We have senior Ministers--Senator Button is perhaps the classic example, but he is not the only one--shooting their mouths off on policy issues and adding to the confusion. Last but not least, the business community is bitterly critical of the Government for the Government's failure to comprehend the seriousness and the desperation of the present situation confronting both business and individuals and its abject failure to come up with any appropriate policy responses.
The Opposition will not, of course, be opposing the Budget Bills--the Appropriation Bills. However, for the reasons I have outlined, on behalf of the Opposition, I move:
At end of motion, add ",but the Senate condemns the Government for:
(a) its economic mismanagement and fiscal irresponsibility revealed in the Budget;
(b) engineering the worst economic recession for 60 years;
(c) knowingly putting over one million people out of work;
(d) failing to implement necessary infrastructure reforms;
(e) imposing major obstacles to resource development;
(f) failing to provide a climate for increased national savings, investment, growth and jobs; and
(g) its continual divisions and leadership struggles resulting in no leadership, no example, and no hope to the people of Australia".

There are many things that can be done to correct the present situation. It should not be a situation of despair. We have a problem in Australia which has been engineered, created, by bad policy making. Anything that is caused by bad policy making can be corrected by proper policy making. But we have to get on with the task of adopting that proper approach to policy making. We have to set ourselves goals and targets to achieve the restoration of growth and activity and, most particularly of all, the creation of jobs in our community. At the end of the day, jobs determine how people live; the opportunities that are available; the esteem and confidence that individuals feel; and the comfort that families, the basic unit in our society, have. A necessary precondition to all of this is the ability of a nation to provide work for its people.

There are many things that we can and must do to make a start on getting back to that situation. It was not all that long ago--only a couple of decades--that kids leaving school knew that there was every probability, every certainty, that they would be able to get a job, that they would be able to make their way in the world. Today young people leaving school are almost in a state of despair. They are asking, `Where are the jobs that we need?'. There is no reason for that. This is one of the great tragedies that have occurred in Australia in the past 10 years and more, and it has to be corrected.

One of the things we have to do--this is an essential starting point--is to make a genuine commitment to price stability. This Government has shillyshallied over the question of whether inflation is a priority problem. The Government has lacked the confidence; it has lacked leadership; it has created confusion over that fundamental question right through its period in office. That whole question is now on the boil again as a result of the destabilising actions of the former Treasurer, Mr Keating.

As I said before, we need to address the whole area of Commonwealth-State financial relations. We need to rebuild the financial relations between the Commonwealth and the States. We need to take important steps along the road of reducing the level of industry protection in Australia, but only in association with tackling the real problems that required protection in the first place, namely, the cost disadvantages under which industry has had to operate in this country for far too long.

We must seriously tackle the whole question of labour market reform. We have to put unions and employees on the same legal footing as employers so that, if necessary, they can take action against each. We have to ensure voluntary unionism and we have to pave the way legally for enterprise-based unions.

We have to reform and restructure the Australian tax system. We need to put in place a broad-based goods and services tax as part of an essential overall package which includes the abolition of the inequitable, discriminatory and very costly wholesale sales tax that now exists. We have to put it in place with significant reductions in personal income tax rates, particularly for those middle income earners who have been so bludgeoned by the tax system in recent times. And we have to do it in terms of many other wider parts of the package.

We have to tackle seriously the question of infrastructure reform. Unless we reduce the cost disadvantages to those vital infrastructure industries--whether they be on the waterfront, in shipping, land transport, air transport, power generation, telecommunications or whatever--they will feed into the costs of tradeable goods, of marketable products, and therefore reduce our international competitiveness. As an overriding priority, we must aim to lower the costs in those areas.

We need to cut government spending--not just rationalise the distribution of it between the Commonwealth and the States but genuinely target spending to those who are most in need. Through all of that, we have to encourage more self-reliance as well as eliminating duplication between different levels of government. We have to take a full-blooded approach to privatisation of government business enterprises and not just the waffled and very small beer approach which the Government has taken. We have to put the privatisation of government business enterprises very high up in the order of priorities, thus increasing the competition to which those enterprises are subjected. The coalition has identified a program of nearly $100 billion worth of public sector enterprises which could be privatised. The commencement of that privatisation program will be a very important part of the incoming coalition government.

We need to streamline development applications. At the moment, major resource and other developmental projects are either stalled or massively delayed--with great cost impediments--by the improper processes of government regulation and stultification. Within the overall time span, we need to look at the question of wanting a larger population in Australia and welcoming a continuation of the positive immigration program over the years. At the moment, given the depth of the recession, there is a lower immigration intake because fewer people want to come here. We also have to recognise that, in the middle of the recession and with our massive debt problems, our capacity to absorb immigrants is at the moment constrained. That needs to be a matter for mature consideration by this Parliament and by the major parties.

Finally, if we are to make ourselves more competitive in an increasingly internationally competitive world, we have to do more to improve our international relations. Without any exaggeration, foreign policy in this country is a mess because it is being run on the basis of emotion and grandstanding. There are numerous examples of that. That is not going to do our ability to compete more and to be seen more favourably in the international climate and economic environment any good at all.

They are some of the things that need to be done. None of them have been addressed by this Government either in the Budget or in any of its surrounding and accompanying policy non-decisions. All we have had is a litany of mismanagement on the part of this Government which has cost Australia, and more particularly Australians, very dearly. I can do no better than to end with a quote from the Treasurer, who said in a speech to the Irish-Australian Chamber of Commerce just a few weeks ago:
. . . the most effective anti-poverty policy ever implemented has been sustained economic growth. It has brought increased social justice to hundreds of millions of people on our planet.

The one thing that I cannot understand, that the coalition cannot understand and that no Australian can understand is why on earth this Government seems so bent on acting totally contrary to that very laudable objective.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This afternoon we are debating Appropriation Bill (No. 1), Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1991-92 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill for the same year. Together, these constitute the Federal Government's Budget for the current financial year. The balance of payments current account in our overseas trading accounts has been and is the key focus of Government economic policy. Historically, the balance of payments has been the No. 1 constraint on economic growth in Australia. That is the historical lesson of Australia. The balance of payments has been the major limiter of our ability to create jobs in Australia in the medium and long term. To be able to create jobs, we have to be able to keep our balance of payments on the overseas transactions in some sort of check.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's policy in recent years has been to attempt to stabilise the position in the balance of payments and also to stabilise Australia's external debt levels in relation to our gross domestic product or the size of our national economy. There have been some important policy relaxations in recent times by the Government as it has responded to changing economic circumstances in the nation. I refer to January last year when the official cash interest rates were 18 per cent and the Government proposed to reduce those cash rates by one percentage point. At that time we had the spectacle of Dr Hewson, on behalf of the Opposition, saying that any reduction in interest rates at the time would be short-lived and that it would not be sustainable for the Government to reduce those official cash interest rates. We had Dr Hewson saying that the lower rates would be short-lived but, more recently, on 22 August, Senator Hill, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, making his Budget reply in this place, exhorted the Government to reduce interest rates more quickly. One has only to look at the Hansard of 22 August to see that there was a massive contradiction between Dr Hewson saying in January last year that any reduction in interest rates would not be sustainable--he is on the record as saying that--and Senator Hill saying more recently that the Government should be going faster to reduce interest rates.

Once again, we have caught out these people. Those opposite are not competent at running the economy; they are not competent economic managers. Here, in one very simple example, we have been able to document a total contradiction in policy. On the one hand, we have Dr Hewson saying that interest rates cannot be reduced because it is not sustainable and, on the other hand, we have Senator Hill in this place on 22 August saying that we should lower them faster. They cannot sort out their position on economic matters and economic policy. They are just not competent to run the Australian economy.

The Hawke Government has relaxed its fiscal policy, its revenue policies, in the Budget, which includes income tax cuts. The Government also brought down the March industry statement to help restructure the Australian economy. Some very important policy relaxations have occurred. Last year, the Budget outcome for the financial year just ended was a surplus of $1,800m--the fourth surplus in a row. I remind the Senate that this Government has brought down four Budget surpluses in a row--a record which those on the other side can only dream about.

Looking at the current Budget, I would like first to examine the economic indicators, the current context for the Budget being brought down. As I pointed out, the focus of policy was the current account deficit in the balance of payments. In 1989-90, the deficit was some $22,000m, but in the year just ended, at 30 June, that current account deficit was reduced to $15,000m--a big reduction. The total deficit was equivalent to 4 per cent of our gross domestic product or national income. That was down significantly, despite all the rhetoric of the other side in this place and despite all the rhetoric in the community from conservatives. The balance of payments deficit for the last financial year was 4 per cent of our gross domestic product.

In the last year the Liberals were in power--that is, in 1981-82--the balance of payments current account deficit was almost 6 per cent of our gross domestic product. We are actually succeeding in closing the gap on the balance of payments. Last year there was a 13 per cent rise in the volume of exports, which is a massive increase in anybody's terms, whereas the volume of imports was down 3 per cent. So there was a closing of the gap on both sides. Economic policy is clearly working to close the balance of payments deficit.

I point out that the volume of exports does not have any direct link to the state of the Australian economy. There is a 13 per cent rise in the volume of exports at the present time. I think the jewel in the crown has been the success of this Government in getting price rises down and cleansing inflation from the Australian system. I know, Madam Acting Deputy President, you have been actively interested in this subject through surveys and so forth of prices in the community.

The reality is that, in the 12 months to June this year, the consumer price index was 3.4 per cent in the Australian community. This is a tremendously low figure by the standards of those opposite who left government with 11 1/2 per cent inflation. Inflation is now at 3.4 per cent. Of course, a key contributor to that low rate has been falls in interest rates. We now have--and have had for a couple of years--interest rates as part of the base for measuring the consumer price index. Every time interest rates come down, that in turn helps to bring down the consumer price index.

TALK.START.PARA: —-We have some of the highest real interest rates in the world.

—-So we have envy and jealousy from those on the other side of the chamber who could never deliver such low inflation. Every time interest rates come down the CPI comes down. I remind them that, since the last consumer price index was released, there has been a one per cent reduction in interest rates. So let us have a look and see what happens when the next index is released at the end of this month. The important thing is that Australia is becoming more competitive. Our inflation rate is now very favourable compared with that of our trading partners. Recently, I saw that our trading partners had an average inflation rate of some 4.3 per cent, compared with our rate of 3.4 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to Dr Hewson again--the man who makes so many predictions which have proven so wrong so often. I refer to a press release issued by Dr Hewson in June last year when he actually attacked our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) by saying that the Prime Minister was wrong to say that inflation in Australia would reach 6 per cent by June this year. Dr Hewson said that. Of course, Dr Hewson was clearly wrong again. In the Melbourne Age on 22 December last year, Dr Hewson went public and said that inflation was clearly stuck between 7 and 8 per cent in Australia. He said that on the record in black and white in the Melbourne Age. But, of course, that was before we brought it down to 3.4 per cent.

On the international scene, Germany is a country which historically has focused on low inflation. For decades the German Government has focused policy on getting low inflation outcomes. The reality is that Australia's price rises are now on a par with those of Germany. This is a great achievement which helps make Australian industry more competitive. Relatively low inflation effectively has a similar impact to a currency devaluation in helping exports by making them more cost effective.

TALK.START.PARA: —-At the cost of jobs.

—-We have these inane comments from the other side of the chamber. Senator Panizza is somehow suggesting that our lower inflation rate has something to do with current economic conditions. I just pointed out to him a while ago that interest rates are now part of the base for the consumer price index. Every time interest rates come down, there is a mechanism built in for bringing down inflation further. These people on the other side of the chamber still do not understand it. They ignore the impact of deregulation in the aviation industry. In Question Time this afternoon, Senator Collins referred to the impact of deregulation on civil aviation. Air fares are part of the base for the consumer price index. Air fares have fallen. It has nothing to do with the state of the economy; it is to do with deregulation of the industry. Let us have none of this nonsense that, somehow because the Australian economy is in recession, we have inflation at 3.4 per cent. Look at the Opposition's record in 1982-83; there was double-digit unemployment and double-digit inflation.

SPEECH.PARA: I referred to official cash interest rates which were 18 per cent at the beginning of last year. This Government has reduced official cash interest rates time and time again to a level, when the Budget was brought down, of 10 1/2 per cent. So there have clearly been significant reductions in interest rates which are helping to get the economic fundamentals right and helping position the economy for better medium term and longer term growth.

I refer to the outline of the Budget for this financial year, which we are debating this evening. The proposed deficit of $4,700m is basically not a structural deficit; it is a cyclical one reflecting the current position on the economic cycle which we are at. It is not a deficit that is built in for the longer term. It does not reflect permanent changes in policy on the expenditure side or the revenue side of the Budget which would lock the Government in for years and years with higher levels of spending.

The Budget provides for total outlays this year to go up 2.6 per cent ahead of inflation; revenues to fall 4.1 per cent below inflation. So the net result is a deficit; the first Budget deficit in five years, as I pointed out. The four previous financial years saw Budget surpluses in Australia, which is something that the Liberals are totally envious about but could never deliver.

I would like to look at a bit of the history of Budgets over the last decade to take up a claim made by Senator Short here a while ago in debating these Bills. It is very interesting that Senator Short, for example, called for cuts in government spending. He applied the tired old conservative formula: when in doubt, cut government spending. It is interesting to look at the share of government spending through the Budget as a proportion of gross domestic product over the course of the 1980s. In the last year in which the Liberals were in charge of the bringing down of a Budget, total Commonwealth government spending was, in fact, 28.8 per cent of our gross domestic product--of our national income.

This year in the Budget, despite the rise in unemployment and in unemployment benefit payments, total government spending as a proportion of gross domestic product is estimated to be 25.7 per cent. That is a reduction of over three percentage points in the share of gross domestic product accounted for by government spending. Let us dispense with this nonsense that Senator Short comes in here and parrots off about--the tired old formula of cutting government spending. This Government has done it. We have got spending down from the Opposition's high levels in the early eighties to about a quarter of gross domestic product.

I would also like to refer to the revenue side of the Budget because that is very illuminating indeed. There is always rhetoric from conservative politicians that parties of the Centre and parties of the Left are somehow high tax parties. This accusation has been made against my Party time and time again. The reality is somewhat different. For example, in 1982-83 when Dr Hewson, I think, was advising the then conservative Government, taxes were 26 per cent of gross domestic product--over a quarter. In 1991-92, this financial year, total revenue in the Budget was 24 per cent. So there has been no increase. One certainly cannot sustain the claim that we, on this side, are somehow members of a high tax party when one looks at the historical record.

Referring to specifics of the Budget, in nominal terms, average spending will grow by 5.7 per cent. The priority areas in terms of higher growth are law, order and public safety, with a 29 per cent increase in expenditure. General and scientific research are up 17.3 per cent--in fact, three times the average of 5.7 per cent--reflecting a government priority to inject funds into the scientific and general research area. This financial year will see stages 1 and 2 of the Government's proposal for cooperative research centres at our tertiary institutions. Some $19.5m was provided for those centres in this Budget. That is one of the first steps towards helping Australia become the clever country that it must become to help establish long term industrial viability in this country.

Compared with the 5.7 per cent across the board growth in spending, there is a 10 per cent growth in education, showing that is also a priority area. Social security and welfare spending is up 12 per cent, partly reflecting the relaxation of income tests for the family allowance supplement and, of course, reflecting the increase in payments of unemployment benefit.

I note also that in housing and community amenities there is to be a 9 per cent growth in spending. That includes the first outlays under the better cities project to help revitalise parts of our metropolitan cities, provide better urban infrastructure and renew metropolitan facilities. Certainly those areas will have above average expenditure growth in the Budget.

I am delighted to see in the Budget this financial year an item of $100,000, part of a $2.85m four-year program to establish an Australia-India Council. This recommendation was one of the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade when it looked at our relationship with India several years ago. It recommended that a peak body, an across-the-board representative body, be established to help infuse new life into Australia's external relationship with India. I am delighted to see this money now provided in the Budget. I am sure that all members of my Committee would be delighted as well, and I would certainly like to congratulate Senator Evans, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, for making those funds available.

The Budget this year includes a number of important revenue measures. We have had the first round of the personal income tax cuts, which were made on 1 January. There have been two rounds of personal income tax cuts, with the lowest marginal tax rate being reduced to 20c in the dollar compared with the 30c in the dollar bottom tax rate that applied when the Liberals were in power.

The Budget also includes significant falls in sales tax revenue. As proposed, there will be legislation to exempt more business inputs for production. More items such as raw materials and equipment used in production will be exempted from sales tax. The Government estimates that the revenue loss will be some $200m this financial year, rising to $375m next financial year. Those items to be exempted from sales tax include hand tools used in agriculture and fishing; goods used in the storage, handling and dispatch of products; goods used in pre-production; and goods used in research, development, engineering and technical design.

Because this Budget will provide for a deficit, it will be taking less from the economy. There will be fewer funds going from the general economy into the Budget. Because revenue is down and expenditure will be up, as I pointed out, there will be a move from surplus to the cyclical Budget deficit that we are facing this year. A key part of that move is the impact of the so-called automatic stabilisers. They are indicators of how the Budget itself responds to changing economic activity in the economy generally. We can see that personal income tax collection will be down some $270m. Company tax collections will be down some $690m, reflecting lower private sector revenues, and there will be negative real growth in revenues.

On the outlays side, I pointed out a 2.6 per cent real outlays growth in the Budget. Of that, 2.1 percentage points are accounted for by growth in outlays on unemployment benefit payments. Of course, unemployment is of great concern on this side of the chamber. We do understand the plight of those out of work and the concerns of their families. I simply point out that the increased payment in unemployment benefit will certainly help cushion the recession's impact on many Australian families.

I think it is also relevant to ask what the Liberals would do at this particular point of time if they were in Government. They have talked about cutting out unemployment benefit to those who are still unemployed after nine months has elapsed. Would they in fact go ahead with this particular proposal? Would they create extra hardship for those out of work by terminating social security payments for unemployed persons after nine months? Would they cut out this important cushion against the impact of the economy?

I point out that since the Budget was brought down a number of important economic indicators have been released. Despite all the doom and gloom being talked on the other side of the chamber and all the knocking of the economy by conservative politicians, a number of positive indicators have been officially released in recent times. I think it is very important to get these on the record. For example, in regard to the vitally important housing and construction sector of our economy, the most up-to-date figures just released for new housing commencements show a significant rise in the June quarter. They show that over 30,000 new dwellings were commenced in the June quarter, compared with some 29,000 in the March quarter. This is very heartening news. Certainly there has been a significant rise in bricks and mortar work in the housing sector.

I also point to the turnover figures released last week for retail businesses. They show that for two months in a row there were strong rises in retail sales, in retail turnover. The reality is that in the 12 months to August this year there has been a 4 per cent growth in retail turnover. That compares with a consumer price index of 3.4 per cent. So, in fact, we are seeing real growth, growth ahead of inflation in retail sales now. For two months in a row, July and August, there were increased motor vehicle registrations. That is very welcome news indeed for the motor vehicle industry in Australia.

Since the Budget was brought down, official cash interest rates have been cut yet again. I pointed out earlier that they started at 18 per cent last year; they have now been cut to 9 1/2 per cent. Those cuts in interest rates should flow on to other sectors of the economy, to other interest rates, and will help boost consumer confidence. Those cuts in interest rates have been enabled by, first, the improving balance of payments and, secondly, the dramatic improvement in Australia's inflation rate, which has been very good news indeed.

I take the opportunity now of asking what the Opposition would do if it were in our shoes now? What would it do to help restore the health and vitality of the Australian economy? I notice that Mr Reith went on the record on 1 July calling for cuts in government spending. That is the type of call that was echoed here this afternoon by Senator Short. I would imagine that social security payments would be in the firing line in that particular area to give effect to these expenditure cuts. Certainly Dr Hewson is on record as talking about privatising the Department of Social Security.

One thing this Government will not be bringing in is a consumption tax. We will not be bringing in a goods and services tax or a VAT, value added tax, as those opposite propose. We will not be proposing a tax on all food, all clothing and footwear, as the people opposite propose to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Only selectively on some food!

—-Senator Baume is the specialist in selective activities. We will not be proposing the GST or, as I referred to it, a value added tax on food, clothing and footwear. Our Budget will not be making every Fletcher Jones and Sussan shop a branch office of the Australian Taxation Office. We will not be making every Williams the Shoeman store and every Betts and Betts shoe shop a branch office of the Australian Taxation Office. We reject this approach totally, utterly and unreservedly. We will not be levying a consumption tax. We will not be taxing the essential staples of life, as those opposite propose to do. We will not be making luxury cars cheaper, as the Opposition proposes to do. Look at the taxation of a luxury limousine at present. Under this Government--
—-You're not going to cut import duties?

—-Mr McLachlan is on the record as saying that the Opposition wants zero import duty. If Mr McLachlan had his way, the Opposition--the limousine Liberals--would reduce through the tax system the price of limousines and then bring tariffs down to zero.

SPEECH.PARA: At present, a motor vehicle retailing for over $45,462 is subject to a 30 per cent wholesale sales tax. Under the Liberals, under Dr Hewson, that motor vehicle would probably be taxed at a 15 per cent retail rate. Those opposite are basically proposing a Rolls Royce led recovery. They want to restore the health of the Australian economy by making luxury cars cheaper. They are the limousine Liberals.

I ask in all seriousness: how on earth can making luxury cars cheaper help the Australian economy? Most luxury motor vehicles--most of the vehicles retailing for over $45,462--are imported. Those opposite are going to give a kick-start to imports of luxury motor vehicles by proposing this tax reduction from 30 per cent to 15 per cent--an incredible gesture. All we would see is a kick-start to luxury car imports.

Then they go around the country parroting that somehow this new VAT they are going to bring in would get rid of paperwork. They are always rubbishing us and saying that we bring in red tape for business--they are the people who would create paperwork for small business in Australia. Senator Hill, for example, on 22 August said that a wholesale sales tax would be very complex to administer. The Liberal Party's own figures show that there would be 4,500 more tax inspectors for a VAT. Those opposite can correct me if I am wrong--I do not have access to their papers--but I understand from my sources that they admit there will be 4,500 more tax inspectors to police their new value added tax.

Why replace a tax as efficiently collected as the wholesale sales tax? The reality is that the present wholesale sales tax is one of the most efficient taxes devised. It costs a mere 49 cents for every $100 collected because it is collected from a few wholesale points only. I have seen one study, by contrast, of the VAT under Mrs Thatcher and Mr Major in the UK which suggests that it costs $2 for every $100 collected in the UK. I ask Senator Baume to correct me if I am wrong, but it costs $2 for every $100 collected, yet the present wholesale sales tax costs 49 cents to collect every $100.

Then we have these people trying to brainwash people in small business into believing that somehow this value added tax will be a panacea for the small business sector. Have they seen what the David Jones organisation has said? Admittedly, that is not a small business. It has already demanded that all of its accounting software changes and any required alterations to its cash register systems as a result of this crazy VAT proposal be met at government expense. David Jones knows what it means for business.

What about those businesses that have to sell on credit? This value added tax means that they would pay tax on the inputs into their production, but they would not get any revenue to pay that tax until they sold the product. They would have to finance the tax until they got revenue from their customers.

We will not embrace the New Zealand model. We will not rush over to New Zealand making a pilgrimage to sit at Mr Bolger's knee and find out how he did it--how he created the longest recession in OECD history. We will not do that. We certainly will not tax Australian books in the way the Liberals propose to do. All one has to do these days is look at the front cover of a magazine--the Bulletin or the Australian Women's Weekly. It is all in black and white as to how much the prices would go up. I simply refer to the back of paperbacks. Look at any paperback book published in the United Kingdom which has the Australian and New Zealand prices on the back. I have one in front of me--$9.95 in Australia, $19.99 in New Zealand `including GST' which, presumably, is the acronym for value added tax. That is the message these people want.

TALK.START.PARA: —-What's that got to do with it?

—-Senator Brownhill should look at the front page of the Australian Women's Weekly to see what the Liberals will do to the price of that. It is all in black and white. We reject these proposals. The Australian Budget this year will shift the economy in the right direction to reconstruct and reform Australia but to temper it with social justice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This afternoon I wish to raise an important matter that is crippling private enterprise in this country, and that is the mass of bureaucratic red tape and the inconsistencies that are strangling businesses in Australia. As I move around Victoria I continually come across examples of private businesses struggling to make a profit and receiving no assistance from the Hawke Government. I do not mean financial assistance--businesses are not looking for assistance in the monetary sense--but assistance in being able to compete with imports by not being tied down with masses of bureaucratic red tape.

SPEECH.PARA: One example I came across recently is the case of a therapeutic goods manufacturer. The company is a manufacturer of therapeutic goods for both domestic and overseas consumption. It is just what Australia needs--import replacement and exports. The only problem is that the company is being burdened by Government bureaucratic inefficiency and inconsistency.

Firstly, there have been considerable delays with the company's export products by the Therapeutic Goods Administration evaluating products being added to the therapeutic goods register. A deadline has been set--which is tomorrow--whereby all therapeutic goods for export must be on the register. Given the lack of resources in the Therapeutic Goods Administration there is no way that this deadline will be met. The company is expecting that there will be considerable delays in the export area because of the new listing requirements. It was fairly obvious during my questioning in the Estimates committee hearing that the Department was not really aware of how far behind it was in these approvals.

Secondly, the manufacture of therapeutic goods for domestic and export purposes must also comply with Australian good manufacturing practice standards. As long as imports are subjected to the same testing processes the trade exchange would be fair. In January this year the Minister said:
Imported grandfathered products which have not been granted import permits within 15 months prior to the introduction of the Act will be assessed for GMP--
or good manufacturing practice--
standards within 6 months from the commencement of the Act (i.e. 15th August 1991).
By 15th February 1992, all imported products on the ARTG will have been checked that their GMP standard of manufacture is equivalent to that of Australian manufacturers.

That is what the Minister said, but checks on the GMP standards of overseas manufacturers have, in general, not occurred. Why should Australian manufacturers have to comply with higher standards than importers have to? I know for a fact that this company is looking at the possibility of investing in plant in Australia and, because of the inconsistencies and the failure of the Government to comply with its own legislation in time, doubt has been cast on whether it is worth while making that investment in Australia.

That investment would mean jobs for Australians, jobs in Victoria--and, heaven knows, what we need in Victoria is jobs. The unemployment rate in Victoria is one of the highest in Australia, and here is a company willing, prepared and wanting to invest in Australia yet not able to have the confidence to believe that that investment will reap a benefit that is sufficient to warrant that investment. Here is an example of a company attempting to export and improve Australia's trade balance and it is having to compete with imports of goods not subject to the same rigid standards. The firm is not asking for any special type of industry assistance or for any handout. What it is asking for is to be able to compete fairly with imports.

Another company that I came across recently is having a similar problem--struggling under the inconsistencies of this Government's industry policy. I have mentioned this company in the Senate before. Late last session I asked Senator Button about a firm manufacturing LPG gas cylinders in Victoria. This is not a small backyard operation. McMillans Pty Ltd is Australia's largest producer of LPG gas cylinders. In accordance with Australian standards, every portable liquid petroleum gas cylinder manufactured in Australia is subjected to rigorous individual and group inspection by means of pressure testing, radiography and random destructive testing, and materials and personnel used in fabrication must be certificated and qualified. Full type testing of all designs is also required.

Cheap imports have flooded into Australia and McMillan Pty Ltd in rural Victoria has sacked 20 of its work force. Again, this is because imported goods are not required to be checked to the same level as the Australian-produced product. Imported LP gas cylinders are checked only randomly whereas all locally produced LPG cylinders are tested. This practice is jeopardising the operations of the company. The two companies in the examples I have outlined are not seeking a level playing field, to use that much abused term, in terms of income support; they are looking for a level playing field in terms of being able to compete with imports which are tested in the same way.

I have given another example in the Senate of specialty cheese manufacturing in Victoria and in other States as well. These small cheese manufacturers are being obstructed in their pursuit of export markets. I will reiterate the story of one manufacturer, the manufacturer of Gippsland blue cheese. It started up in the Gippsland area. A local dairy farmer had the vision of starting up a specialty cheese factory, hoping that other people in the valley would do the same and produce other cheeses. He had the foresight to build a small area where people could have afternoon tea and, through a window, watch the cheese being made. He hoped that people would come in bus loads to visit the cheese area just as people visit the wine areas of Victoria. It was a great vision, and he started manufacturing cheeses with the help of a young local lad who had completed a cheese maker's course.

I do not think they ever anticipated the bureaucratic claptrap they would encounter. Every batch of cheese, if it is to be exported, has to be tested and those tests cost a significant amount of money. This may not be a factor when one is exporting large quantities of cheese but, if one is exporting small batches, the cost of the test makes the cost of a kilogram of cheese prohibitive in terms of exports. I am told by the cheese manufacturers that the testing for cheese to be sold on the Australian market is not as stringent as that required for export cheese. Here again is another example of a company, like the other two I have mentioned, involved in producing what could be import replacement products which also have the potential for export. But those companies are not exporting.

I can tell the Senate about Timboon cheese, which comes from the other side of Victoria. I visited this area and found exactly the same problems as exist with Gippsland blue cheese. The manufacturers of Timboon cheese pride themselves on not using chemicals in any of its production. They grow the crops for the animals and I think the only time they use chemicals is in the sterilisation of the equipment used in the cheese making, which is a requirement by the health Department. It is an example of a cheese which would go well on the export market, especially given the sorts of problems that have been associated with some of the primary products in Europe which have been subjected to the fall-out from Chernobyl. Here we have a perfect example of Australia being able to produce a quality product which could compete internationally if it were allowed to.

Not only are the regulations for testing the cheeses stricter, but also I discovered when one of my staff spoke to Gippsland Blue Cheese again today that, besides that problem, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy is charging $204 an hour to go out and check the premises to make sure they are up to export standard. I would love to see the costings for that. How can the Department justify charging $204 an hour?

It has been estimated by Gippsland Blue that it would cost somewhere between $5,000 and $10,000 for this checking to be undertaken. This is an enormous disincentive to becoming a licensed exporter. Why would anyone bother? Why would anyone bother putting more money into the factory? Why would anyone bother fighting through the bureaucratic red tape? Why would anyone bother trying to create jobs for people in Gippsland and trying to add value to primary products, which is what we are being told is needed--value added primary products--if we are to compete?

Things are made so difficult for these manufacturers. They have so many organisations to deal with and so many regulatory requirements, which never seem to cease. The cheese manufacturers also told me that they are now having to employ consultants to handle the administration of superannuation arrangements. That is another cost and another disincentive for these small businesses. They were not complaining about the superannuation; they were complaining about the administration costs. Senator Maguire talked about the cost of administering a goods and services tax. Maybe he needs to look in his own backyard at the cost of enforcing some of the regulations about which I have just been talking, and the charge of $204 an hour for the primary industry Department to go out and check the premises to make sure that they are up to export standard. It seems to me to be a rather high fee.

If the Government does not undertake serious reform some of those industries will die. People will not be bothered. They can actually make more on their money by putting it into a bank account and collecting interest than by bothering to invest it in manufacturing. If honourable senators on the other side of the chamber were serious about creating jobs for the nearly one million unemployed they would do something about these problems, which are crippling businesses--crippling small businesses which are the largest employers in this country. Two of the businesses I referred to are located in rural areas and the other one is located in the south-eastern suburbs of Melbourne, which we have dubbed the `unemployment capital of Australia', as it has one of the highest unemployment rates in the country.

We need to look at the sorts of reforms that we are talking about, such as taxation reform. Senator Maguire failed to tell us about the invidious creep in the wholesale sales tax which has occurred since those opposite have been in government. Those opposite do not tell us about the things that are hidden. They have not told us how much the wholesale sales tax has increased in 8 1/2 years, because they can hide that. Those opposite do not tell us about the needed reforms in infrastructure: the improvements needed to our roads, in transport and on the waterfront. The situation is desperate for the cheese producers. They cannot have their cheese sitting on a wharf or at the airport. The therapeutic goods industry also needs reliable delivery and, even though it can produce its products competitively and could sell them competitively at the shopfront, their products are not competitive by the time they get there. As with the cheese companies, there is no incentive to become an exporter, given the red tape and the cost of getting a licence.

How many jobs could be provided for out of work Australians if only a fraction of the investments in the area of therapeutic goods and the investments which could take place in the development of specialty cheeses were allowed to go ahead? The people in the Gippsland valley have been put off. They have said to Gippsland Blue, `Why would we bother having value added to our products when we have seen what has happened to you?'. If only a fraction of these investments were allowed to go ahead and businesses were not strangled and choked by red tape, how many more jobs would we have for those one million people who are currently unemployed in Australia?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Whilst I commend Senator Patterson for her perceptive examination of why and how Australian industry finds it difficult to survive under this Government, I can find no words of commendation for Senator Maguire's extraordinary contribution. As usual, we heard Senator Maguire outline why everything is wonderful in this economy. There are no problems. Everything is being done as it should. The Government is perfect; its policies are ideal and everything is on track! It sounds a bit like Mr Keating in his `on track' days; the only problem is we did not know where the track was leading, and neither did he.

SPEECH.PARA: It is incredible to listen to Senator Maguire--at a time when unemployment has exceeded 10 per cent, when Australian industry is in a shambles, when the Government has no policies because of the massive internal divisions within it--who comes in here and tells us, `Everything is wonderful, there is no need to get excited; everything is properly on track, and bad luck to all you people who are unemployed, because everything is just the way it ought to be'? Quite frankly, I think the Australian people are sick and tired of political games being played with the economy. That applies to what both sides are saying. The people who are unemployed--the 10.2 per cent, the 29 per cent of young Australians under 20, who cannot find a job--do not want to hear this kind of sterile nonsense, this sort of tit-for-tat debating of, `When you were in government in 1982-83 this is what happened', and then the response, `But it is worse now because of these policy decisions' and so on.

The fact is that people are unemployed. The fact is that there is dissension within the Government's ranks about what to do about it at the highest levels. We have a leaderless Government, a policyless Government and internal division making it absolutely impossible even for a decision to be made about how much people should contribute to their health care--let alone whether there should be a major policy change to increase employment opportunities.

All over the newspapers at the moment we have evidence of that major disagreement. We have headlines such as `Jobless hurting ALP: Kerin' and `Government split widens over jobless' in the Telegraph Mirror; and `Ministers urge job creation' and `Leadership lures Keating to the rocks of populism' in the Sydney Morning Herald. This Government is divided over the central issue which is worrying most Australians--that is, unemployment. The Government does not have a policy; it does not have a clear leadership position; and we now have the most senior Government Ministers disagreeing about it.

I suppose we should look at what has actually happened and whether the Government's policies are right. If it is clear that the Government's policies have created the present disaster, there is a very good case for changing those policies. There is no doubt that the Government's policies that have been at work for the last eight years have created this very crisis that we are in. The man who created the crisis, Mr Keating, is now saying that we should totally change those policies. The way he wants to change them will make the problem even worse.

I draw the Senate's attention to today's Sydney Morning Herald where a very perceptive article by Max Walsh notes not only that the Government is in disarray over its policies but also that its present policies and the policies that Mr Keating wants to introduce will lead both to chaos and disaster. Mr Walsh states that Mr Keating:
. . . told the Labor Party dinner in Sydney on Friday that the Government needed to return to the priorities he had pursued for seven of the past 8 1/2 years--of creating jobs.
These are the policies which really did set Australia up for the recession it had to have--

The recession, of course, that Mr Keating engineered. Mr Walsh directs attention to these jobs that were created by Mr Keating, that Mr Keating takes the credit for and that the Government as a whole was party to. There is no doubt, as Mr Walsh says, that:
From 1983, until the spectre of banana republicanism shocked him, Mr Keating ran an excessively loose fiscal policy.
Then, having tightened fiscal policy just as the commodity cycle bounced, he began running a loose monetary policy.
Through these two policy cycles foreign borrowing was encouraged.
Jobs were created. . . but the quality of those jobs was something else.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Who said that?

—-This is what Max Walsh said in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald. It is a very perceptive article. I looked at the statistics to see just what the quality of these jobs was that Mr Keating so proudly says was the centrepiece of the priority he pursued for seven of the last 8 1/2 years. Sure, he was creating jobs. I notice that in public administration, for example, there is a 24 per cent increase in jobs. We would expect that with Labor governments all around Australia, including Canberra. Is that the sort of job creation we want: a 24 per cent increase in public administration--67,800 extra jobs in public administration in Australia between 1982-83 and 1990-91, according to the latest statistics?

SPEECH.PARA: I then look at where the rest of the increases have been. There has been a 30 per cent increase in wholesale and retail trades. This, by the way, comes out of a total increase in jobs over that period of something like 1.5 million. We find 382,000 of those increased jobs coming from the wholesale and retail sector; that is about a 30 per cent rise. In the community services sector, we see an increase of 367,000 jobs; in finance and property services, 325,000 increased jobs; and construction--a very up and down indicator, I might say--hit a peak of over 163,000 in 1989-90 but, of course, the figure is falling in the latest year.

We see recreation--in other words, tourism--as one of the very few areas of increased employment, which is up 181,000. It is one of the very few areas where there has been an increase in employment that will bring, if you like, any recovery, any improvement, in Australia's basic capacity to increase its export earnings--increase its contributions to the balance of payments, which Senator Maguire said is the key element. In his speech he stressed that the most important element of Government policy must be, and is, to fix up the balance of payments. Yet here we see almost a total ignoring of that area in this growth of jobs that Mr Keating said was central to his policy. By his own measure, it is a total failure; Mr Keating is a total failure; the Government's policies of job creation are a total failure. The Government's policies have cost Australia this huge increase in foreign debt, from something like $25 billion net to something like $135 billion. We have, at that cost, simply created jobs and, as Mr Walsh says, `The quality of those jobs was something else'. He is quite right, as I have just shown.

Let us look at manufacturing. As a result of this Government's endeavours over eight years, there are now 81,500 fewer people at work in the manufacturing industry in Australia than there were in 1981-82--the last full year of the Fraser Government. We have very little difference in mining, which is the basic sector in terms of trying to find extra earnings in Australia. In transport, there has only been a little bit; in communication, there has been hardly any; and agriculture is up by something like 4 per cent.
We see in this nation that the great achievement of Mr Keating has been to do nothing that is in the interests of the economy's long term health. Mr Walsh, I believe quite rightly, says:
The pattern of job growth was inimical to the economy's long term health.
He describes Mr Keating's let-it-rip approach as one that meant that:
Australia through the '80s built a milk-bar economy based on borrowed money.
He continues:

Now that the symptom of that dangerous economic lifestyle--double-digit unemployment--is on display, we hear Labor's Greek chorus--Keating, Kelty, Ferguson, Richardson, Button, Kirner, Goss and Carr--intone that the Government has to "do something" about job creation. Just what they have to do is not spelt out.
These demands are certain to become more strident as the labour market situation worsens.
He then says:
. . . this recession is very different from those of 1982-83 and 1974.
This recession is a direct result of a credit boom which raged through the second half of the 1980s.
