That credit boom was deliberately generated by Mr Keating, as he proudly says, because he had a priority over those seven years of creating jobs--no matter what the cost, no matter what the long term consequences. We are now feeling those long term consequences. Mr Walsh says:
So far we have not seen job shedding in these sectors at anywhere near the extent that one would expect given the way they bubbled during the last decade.
In other words, we shall see some continuing serious problems in unemployment, and one can see why.

The 1982-83 recession was created by Australia's worst drought for 50 years. When it rained there was a dramatic recovery in jobs, as the figures clearly show. They show that in Australia after a loss of 110,000 jobs in the worst recession year of 1982-83, in the following year after it rained there was an increase of 58,600 in the number of people at work. Maybe Government supporters will say that that was because Mr Hawke's particular skill at generating rain or teardrops or liquid of one sort or another led to the end of the drought. If we can thank Mr Hawke for the end of the drought, so be it, but the fact is that that recession could be corrected because it was simply the end of the drought.

The consequence of the Government's policies in putting jobs first created a serious disaster long term for Australia, as the Reserve Bank's annual report points out. This recently produced report makes the point:
The main task for monetary policy in 1991/92 is to peg the progress which has been made on inflation over the past year, preparatory to winding it back further.
Labor, of course, has cut inflation at the cost of huge job losses. The annual report continues:

Cyclical falls in inflation--where prices slow in response to weak activity--have occurred in the past, most recently in the early 1980s recession when inflation dropped from around 12 per cent in 1982 to a little over 5 per cent in 1984.

In other words, the recession brought a severe cut in inflation to only 5 per cent. There was then immense pain, but there was a benefit in that inflation was cut. But what happened? The Reserve Bank then tells us:
On that occasion much of the gain was lost within a couple of years, an outcome which policy-makers are determined to avoid on this occasion.

In other words, Mr Keating mucked it up. He was in charge of economic policy and, as the Reserve Bank says, policy makers are determined not to make the mistake that Mr Keating made when he lost that enormous advantage that we had in 1985. He bought temporary job rises at a cost to the Australian economy. Labor under Mr Keating and Mr Hawke destroyed our chances of a lasting recovery then, and we are feeling the consequences of that right now.
What is Mr Keating now proposing? He is proposing to make exactly the same mistake that he made in 1984 when he wiped out all the advances that we had.

TALK.START.PARA: —-He's not the Treasurer any more.

—-I hear Senator Sherry's interjection that he is not now the Treasurer. Many people would say amen to that, but I would be overjoyed to hear Senator Sherry's assurance that Mr Keating will not be in a position of power, such as that of Prime Minister, to repeat the disasters that he generated in our economy.

SPEECH.PARA: When we watch the Keating supporters, the wimps on the Labor Party side in economic policy terms who are pressing for curious policy changes, we note, as Mr Walsh does:

. . . that the very industries that the Victorian Premier, Joan Kirner. . . wants to encourage through protection, clothing and textiles, are those from which the successful East Asian economies are escaping.
Later in the article, Mr Walsh says:

While the East Asians are abandoning low-tech manufacturing and Japan is preparing to ease out of mid-tech manufacturing, we have a growing demand from Labor politicians under threat of election loss for Australia to head off in the opposite direction--to head backwards to our future.

That is what the big debate is all about at the moment. That is what the Labor Party leaders, the dissenters, are on about. They are destroying, as they destroyed in 1984--according to the Reserve Bank--any chance we have of a lasting economic recovery. They are destroying the chance of having interest rate falls or job growth that can be sustained. Only if we follow the policy prescriptions suggested by the Opposition, and suggested with great strength, can we see any hope of getting out of our economic disaster right now.
What is the Government doing? The Government is in disarray and in basic disagreement. We see Mr Dawkins's warning that:
. . . unemployment will stay high and living standards decline unless there is a change of focus in economic policy.
One has Resources Minister Alan Griffiths calling for `more Government initiatives to fight unemployment', and saying that `more could be done'. He added:
The Government has got to have the flexibility to respond to what in my electorate (in Melbourne) is nothing short of a human disaster.

We have also seen Senator Button calling for a wider range of economic policy to help to create more jobs. One has at the highest level a failure of the Government to agree on what its economic policies should be to get us out of this disaster. The coalition does have those economic policies.

Before I conclude with that policy prescription, I wish to seek approval of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard the figures showing what has happened in the labour market in individual industries from 1982-83 to now. This will demonstrate where the Government, Mr Keating and Mr Hawke--because in those days Mr Hawke was supporting Mr Keating, regarding him as the greatest Treasurer Australia has had and as the world's greatest Treasurer--have gone. TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the Senate. As I said, these figures show just how poor the quality was of the jobs created under this jobs-before-all-else approach and how ephemeral such job creation really is.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I want to say that I totally support the amendment that has been moved by the Opposition to this Bill. The amendment seeks to add the following words to the end of the second reading motion:
, but the Senate condemns the Government for:
(a) its economic mismanagement and fiscal irresponsibility revealed in the Budget;
(b) engineering the worst economic recession for 60 years;
We should remind ourselves that Mr Keating proudly said that he had engineered this recession. The amendment continues:
(c) knowingly putting over one million people out of work--
it will stay bad for a long time, according to every commentator--
(d) failing to implement necessary infrastructure reforms--
we note that the coalition has a positive set of policies to do that--
(e) imposing major obstacles to resource development;

We are all only too well aware that this Government makes it as hard as possible for any major development to go ahead. It creates those obstructions for purely short term political benefit. The amendment continues:
(f) failing to provide a climate for increased national savings, investment, growth and jobs; and
(g) its continual divisions and leadership struggles resulting in no leadership, no example, and no hope to the people of Australia.

The present Budget that we are dealing with in these Appropriation Bills has the highest level of mistakes. It is the most inaccurate Budget in Australia's history and goes nowhere near achieving the outcomes that it sets out to achieve. It is a disaster, just as Mr Keating's period as Treasurer was a disaster.

It is now clearly evident that Mr Keating stepped down from being the Treasurer and Deputy Prime Minister of this nation not because he had a chance of becoming leader in May but because it was desperate for his future hopes that he not be associated with a Budget that involved over a 10 per cent unemployment rate and was clearly a disaster.

Mr Keating had no chance. He did not have the numbers in May and he knew it. It was a stunt and, as usual, the Press Gallery fell for it. Mr Keating had to distance himself from disaster. That is what this is all about. That is why he resigned as Treasurer. As I said, he did not have the numbers. We on this side of chamber were told what the numbers were long before the vote was taken. There was never any prospect in May of Mr Keating winning. But he had to distance himself from this disaster that he had created with the help of the total Cabinet.

Sooner or later, by promising a whole range of policies, particularly creating jobs at any price, Mr Keating hopes to attract support from the dissidents in the Labor Party who are growing in number daily, particularly the left wing in Victoria, which has so far stuck with Mr Hawke but will no doubt eventually move to Mr Keating if the meat workers union supporters have anything to say about it. Knowing their method of persuasion, I would expect them to get some support within the trade union movement in Victoria.

The fact is that we are now at probably the most serious risk of further economic downturn and disaster while this leaderless, divided and split government remains in control. The problem is that, as the Reserve Bank says, the Government has been totally wrong in the past. It has no coherent policy prescriptions for the future and this Budget is a disaster.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My comments on the Budget cover two areas--namely, education and training, and superannuation and retirement income. Before I go into those areas in some detail, I would like to pick up a number of points that were made by Senator Baume.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I will make an admission to Senator Baume: this Government is not perfect and some mistakes have been made-- unlike all previous Liberal-National Party governments since World War II, with their mantle of perfect policy. We know how perfect those governments were in ensuring that this country was made uncompetitive by erecting enormous tariff barriers and by not tackling some of the fundamental restructuring issues such as our transport difficulties or our education infrastructure problems. We know how perfect those opposite are. They did very little during their time in government to correct some of the basic problems that this country has been experiencing since World War II. In a typically conservative way, they were happy to govern safely and leave things as they were. I will say one thing for those opposite: they have now adopted a different approach. Some of the policy initiatives that they are proposing would shake the country to pieces.

Some of the alleged facts that Senator Baume laid before us were fairly contradictory. For example, he alleged that the major recession of 1982-83 was brought about by a drought. It was a coincidence in timing that a drought occurred in 1982-83. For anyone to maintain that the drought caused the recession in this country in 1982-83 is utter nonsense.

Senator Baume then implied that there was enormous job growth after 1982-83, when a Labor Government came to power, because it rained. That is again utter nonsense. It is a highly shallow examination of what occurred at the time. Senator Baume is condemned by his own figures. He gave us figures relating to job growth in such areas as the services sector and the hospitality and retail industries. The fact that it rained in 1982-83 and the drought broke did not contribute very much to job growth in, for example, the tourism industry. The fact that we had enormous job growth in the tourism industry had more to do with the success of this Government's selling Australia overseas. The enormous growth in the numbers of visitors who came to this country and the enormous growth in tourism were significant contributing factors in the enormous job increases in the hospitality industry that occurred at that time and have continued right up to this day.

Like every other country in the Western world, this economy is going through a fundamental shift in the employment structure. There is an enormous shift away from jobs in manufacturing and mining. There is no growth in the jobs in those areas and there will not be because of technology and improved productivity. There will continue to be an increase in manufacturing output and exports but there will not be the job growth. There is nothing unusual about that. But there has been significant job growth in the services sector.

Our economy is undergoing a fundamental economic shift similar to that which began in most Western countries 30 or 40 years ago. One basic problem we face is that we did not go down the road to a shift in employment as we should have done 30 or 40 years ago because those opposite cocooned this country from the international economy behind high tariff walls. They did not adopt the sorts of policies that this Government has initiated over the last eight years to try to correct that problem. For example, almost overnight we were faced with removing tariff walls. Almost overnight we have to shift this economy from a manufacturing, agricultural, rural base to a services sector base in terms of employment. There has been very little positive contribution from those opposite.

I now turn to the two very important aspects of the Budget that I wish to concentrate on this evening: education and training, and superannuation and retirement income. It has been a continuing theme of this Hawke Labor Government to be an active reformist government in a whole range of policy areas, but these two areas highlight more than any other this Government's active reformism and the way in which it has appropriately intervened in the economy when it has been necessary. We have integrated economic policy with education and training and with superannuation and retirement.

To put education and training into its historical perspective, I referred earlier to the decades of lack of progress in tackling the basic problems in this country under Liberal-National Party governments. The structure of the education system in this country remained basically unchanged until the election of the Hawke Labor Government. For example, there was no national accreditation of education and training; there was no articulation between courses from universities to TAFEs; there was no articulation in training amongst the States in this country; and there were poor levels of retention in education--we had one of the poorest education retention levels of any advanced Western country.

If we are to expand our economy and maintain our standard of living by comparison with other advanced Western economies, we have to uplift our commitment to education and training. Every country in the world which has an advanced economic system or which has been progressing very rapidly over the past couple of decades has had a highly motivated, trained and educated work force. This is another area that had been neglected prior to the election of the Hawke Labor Government.

We had low levels of industry training. The fundamental structures of the deliverers of education and training in this country had not been looked at, in some cases, since the Middle Ages. The structure of universities had not been examined--and we have adopted an English tradition--since the founding of universities in England in the 1400s and the 1500s. We still have, although we are now tackling it, the apprenticeship system--a 1,000-year-old feudal system of training with a master-servant system of indenture. Those are the sorts of problems that this country faced and they are the problems this Government set out to tackle and has continued to tackle through the Budget. In order to maintain our competitive position we have adopted the very important theme--often derided by some opposite--of becoming the clever country. The link between training, career paths and wages and salaries is a very important link that this country has not developed in the past.

I will mention some of the policies that have been adopted by this Government over the last eight years and continued in the Budget. We have established the National Board of Employment, Education and Training and subsidiary councils to advise the Government on a whole range of policy initiatives that are being implemented. We have expanded university places and funding. In 1983 there were 250,000 persons at university; today there are 350,000--a massive increase. There is no comparable increase in student numbers at universities over a similar time period in the Western world.

We have reformed the structure of academic institutions. It has been a painful process. In many cases the universities and the TAFEs have been resistant to the amalgamation procedures and the structural changes we have made. We have established a national training board and a minimum Training Guarantee Act because, unfortunately, the private sector was not meeting its commitments to training. We have established Australian educational centres overseas so that we can turn our highly skilled education industry into a valuable export industry.

In this year's Budget we have continued to pick up the challenges and the pace of change. I will draw the attention of the Senate to a number of important initiatives in this year's Budget. The Budget contains significant increases in funding. Overall, the funding allocation for the activities of the Department of Employment, Education and Training --and this does not include Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander funding--will rise from $8,605m in 1990-91 to $9,808m in 1991-92. That represents an increase of $1,200m in one year, an increase in real terms of 10.8 per cent. That shows our commitment to the re-training and re-education of this country to keep us on a new path.

This Budget has identified higher education as a priority area. We are continuing the push in higher education with an additional $150m in the next financial year--$150m in one year alone. As to Aboriginal programs, we are ensuring that those less privileged in our society continue to receive assistance; we are providing an additional $6m in this area. There will be an additional package of student assistance over the next year of approximately $12m.

I will be going into the Australian language and literacy policy in some detail because I have a criticism of it. Again, I contrast the criticisms of those opposite. We are not a perfect government and there are some areas that I will openly and honestly criticise. We know what the problems of the country are and we are tackling them, unlike those opposite. The Budget has introduced a $12m package for labour market programs over the next year and a program of a quarter of a million dollars over the next triennium. Finally, there is a package of youth items amounting to $5m.

When looking at these programs in greater detail, one sees that there is to be a 10 per cent increase in funding to schools and a 10 per cent increase in funding in the higher education area. These are real increases. Again, there is a 10 per cent increase in the skills formation area. In the area of industry training, which is very important if we are to encourage our export industry, funding for entry level training will increase by $182m in the next financial year. In the past we have done very little in the area of recognition of overseas skills, but there will be an increase in expenditure from $.9m to $1.3m. That is a relatively small program, but a very important one. If this country is to become part of the international economy and become competitive, we have to be prepared to recognise the skills of those coming from overseas and vice versa. We have done very little in this area in the past.

Labour market assistance is so important given the high levels of unemployment. Of course, our program stands in stark contrast to the program of those opposite, whose basic attitude is, `After nine months, forget them. Drop them off the dole and forget them'.

TALK.START.PARA: —-That is wrong, and you know it.

—-Senator Panizza can protest, but even his rural supporters are urging a change of course with that policy. Not only is it an inhumane policy--that is the worst aspect of it--but also it is an appalling waste of human resources in this country to say to people after nine months, `That is the end of you. Go and fend for yourselves'. In terms of the labour market adjustment packages, we are increasing the funding allocation to employment access from $200m to $281m. The funding for community based strategies is being increased from $102m to $190m. These are specific and positive programs to try to overcome the fundamental difficulties that many people face in regaining entry to the labour market. Labour adjustment assistance has been increased from $6m to $31m.

SPEECH.PARA: I mentioned earlier the higher education funding over the next triennium. Looking at the breakdown of the packages and the funding provided, one sees that we have ensured the implementation of an appropriate career structure in the higher education field at a very significant cost, which we are funding--$126m in 1991-92 rising to $201m in 1994-95. We are providing for additional enrolment growth over and above that which has already occurred. We are also providing for advanced engineering centres--again, a fairly small Budget item in the overall context of education and training, but a very important measure.

By way of comment on these measures, the additional funds are providing for the supplementation of the higher education program to meet the costs of the salary increases that were recently awarded to academics. They are also providing for enrolment growth over and above the levels that were previously committed for 1992--some 13,000 additional new places. A pilot scheme has been established to encourage further industry involvement in higher education, with up to 600 places in 1992 and up to 700 places in both 1993 and 1994. The funding will also go towards the establishment of three advanced education centres to which I referred earlier. They are joint ventures between the Commonwealth, host institutions and industry, and are good examples of cooperation between the Government and private industry. These centres will focus on advanced undergraduate and postgraduate education and training.

Unlike those opposite, who in one breath talk about cutting expenditure and in the next talk about increasing expenditure in areas without coming up with the funding for them, this Government did bite the bullet in terms of the higher education contribution scheme. In this Budget we are increasing the funding by $144m to partly fund our education initiatives. Unlike those opposite, we are not full of rhetoric. We show where we will fund our initiatives, and those opposite ought to take up the challenge. It is a responsible approach, not the wishful thinking that we get from those opposite.

I will now turn to Australian language and literacy policy, which has been funded in this Budget and details of which were announced following the Budget. This is one area where I will make a criticism of one small aspect of the policy that has been adopted. We are the first Government to turn attention to the problem of illiteracy in this country. It is a monumental disgrace that between 7 per cent and 10 per cent of our work force are illiterate and up to 28 per cent are functionally illiterate.

I preface my remarks by saying that it is not because of the failure of the school system. If we are to ensure that our economy grows and that everyone has relatively equal access to the opportunities that we should be offering, we have to overcome the problems of illiteracy. I am pleased that in the Budget, programs have been announced to fund the sorts of initiatives needed to do that and the language and literacy policy that has been handed down.

There is to be increased funding--some $90m--over the next three years for a language policy. If we are to be relevant in terms of the international economy, we have to be able to communicate with the outside world. I have to say that it is an area in which this country has been a dismal failure. Our enrolments in foreign language courses rate very badly. If we are to maximise our trade and our competitiveness, particularly with Asia, we have to reorient the focus of our culture, at least in part, in terms of the languages that we teach. It is here that I make a criticism of the policy that has been adopted. We have adopted five core languages: French, German, Japanese, Chinese and Bahasa Indonesian.

TALK.START.PARA: —-You left one important one out.

—-They are the five languages that have been adopted, if Senator Panizza would care to read the policy. Of the five languages that have been adopted, it is interesting to note that in this country the No. 1 at year 12 and at higher education is still French. Of those studying foreign languages, 25 per cent are studying French. The next highest is Japanese with 12 per cent at year 12, and in higher education it is about 20 per cent. Then follow German, at 14 per cent, and Indonesian-Malay, at about 6 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: I find that quite appalling. We are proposing to perpetuate the orientation of our language policy around French, in particular, by continuing to fund French language courses. I find it appalling for three reasons. Let us look at the criteria that were used to come to the policy for the adoption of the five languages. The first is the migrant criterion. The French do not rate in migration to this country. They are not even in the top 10. In terms of the criterion based on migration, French should not rate. In terms of trade, six of the 10 major countries to which we export are in Asia. Where does France rate?
