TALK.START.PARA: —-Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was referring to the criteria on which we have developed the national language and literacy policy. I had made comment on the countries to which we export. In 1971-72, France rated No. 7 and received some 2.7 per cent of our exports. When that figure is compared to the 1989-90 year, France did not rate at all; it had dropped off the list and did not even fall into the top 12 receivers of our exports. In fact, one could argue that France is an economic enemy of Australia, but I will not develop that argument this evening. On the criteria of export performance, France does not rate.

SPEECH.PARA: In the area of tourism, it is also interesting that in the last year there was some 22,000 visitors from France to Australia. Comparatively, France was No. 26 on the list of countries which sends tourists to this country. Clearly, France was overtaken by Japan a long time ago. However, countries such as Korea and Thailand were for the first time exceeding France as a source of tourists.

On those criteria, I find it very difficult to understand why we have a policy that allocates one-quarter of our total foreign language expenditure to French. We should certainly be teaching French, but we should not be giving it the priority that we have outlined in the language policy or giving it the expenditure that is allocated in the Budget. At the Federal level, we are spending some $90m over three years. However, at the State level it will be some hundreds of millions of dollars. It would be more appropriate to spend our scarce language education dollars in the developing Asian markets such as Thailand and Korea, which are and will be of much more importance in the coming decades. I am sure the only reason French is given such importance is that--because of our English traditions--French, German and Latin were essentially the only languages taught in this country up until 15 or 20 years ago, and French is still a traditional hangover from that period.

The other issue I wish to comment on tonight is our superannuation and retirement policy. I will be fairly brief in this area because it is an issue about which I have spoken on other occasions. I am pleased to see the continuing development in this Budget of a comprehensive, secure and equitable retirement package. Up until the election of the Labor Government, there was a minority of people--who tended to be the much better off in terms of income--who received superannuation. At present, two out off every five persons are retired and the other three out of every five persons are required to support our retired population, and by the year 2020 three out of every five persons will be retired. With an increasing aged population, there will proportionally be a significant increase in the number of persons requiring superannuation and/or a government pension and, therefore, it is necessary to quickly develop a comprehensive retirement policy. That the Government has done.

This policy will end the tax rorts which benefited only the wealthy. That tax discount, where superannuation was taxed at 5 per cent, went only to those who had superannuation. Up until a few years ago, those persons who received superannuation were the better off in our society. The tax concession did little to encourage the spread of superannuation to the middle income and lower income areas, and particularly to disadvantaged groups such as women who did not receive any superannuation at all.

Let us looks at superannuation from its historical perspective. In 1986 there was the awarding of the 3 per cent productivity superannuation, as it became known, through the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. This has been developed but, unfortunately, it has not been adhered to legally as it should have been and there are still significant levels of non-compliance with that 3 per cent. However, with the very important policy announcements in the Budget which will fundamentally affect everyone who retires in this country over decades, there is a phasing-in of a contribution level equivalent to 9 per cent of earnings by the year 2000.

As a recognition of the problems facing small business, that phasing in will not affect employers with a payroll of less than $500,000 for another two years and will be phased in progressively up to the year 2000. Also taken into account are those employers who have been contributing over--in some cases significantly over--the 3 per cent level that currently applies. This new superannuation guarantee levy will underpin the Government's retirement incomes policy. Superannuation, which has been extended to the vast majority of the work force, will now be extended to all Australians for the first time in a significant and meaningful way because this 9 per cent figure will provide realistic superannuation entitlements. That is one of the most significant measures in the Budget on which I wish to comment.

Although those opposite have been quick to criticise superannuation as being allegedly a tax on employment--which I would refute--that money will be used for investment purposes. So it does have a productive and positive outcome. Those opposite have been quick to criticise but, like their tax policy, we are still waiting for their retirement and superannuation policy. Where is it? Whilst in government we have been conscious of developing a total range of policies in a whole range of areas. All those opposite can do is snipe and complain, yet on one of the most fundamental issues--retirement income policy--it has still not delivered a policy after eight years in opposition. One would think that those opposite would have learnt something in opposition, but they have learnt nothing. Those opposite will continue to sit where they are now.

This Government is a government of vision; it is a government of leadership; and it is a government of policies that will lead this country into the next century. Those opposite certainly have some vision--a vision of a new tax which will allegedly solve all our problems and a vision of an inequitable society which will create a larger pool of have-nots. Those opposite have an industrial relations policy that will put us back to the conditions of Victorian England. That is the sort of vision the Opposition has for this country. Its vision is not based on any positive or any socially just or equitable approach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-We are tonight discussing the Appropriation Bills. The foremost item of concern to thousands of ordinary Australians is the amount of direct personal tax that they pay under this Labor Government. It has been a source of absolute fascination, to say the least, to listen to Senator Sherry's contribution to this debate because, quite clearly, he does not understand the pressures Australians--not only as individuals rapidly losing their jobs but also as business operators trying to keep their heads above water to retain the jobs of individuals which are at grave risk--are under at the moment. To say the least, incentive is not helped when Australians on 60 per cent of average earnings--which is only $20,700--pay nearly 40c in the dollar in tax, the marginal rate on average earnings being 30 per cent when this Government came to office.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a government that claims to be the friend of the worker; yet it is this Government that has decided to increase that tax level to dramatic levels. Perhaps the likes of Senator Sherry might care to explain to the Senate why Australians need to earn no more than 1.7 times average weekly earnings before they pay the top marginal rate in tax. But Senator Sherry is not keen to hear this--he is now leaving the chamber. It does bear comparison that in 1951, the top marginal rate of tax was payable only on incomes which were 18 times average weekly earnings. Here we are in 1991 and that figure is now 1.7 times average weekly earnings. That is how much this tax junkie Government has put up personal levels of income tax.

It is a fact that Australians who earn more than $20,000 and less than $50,000 to $60,000 are, in fact, worse off under the Hawke Labor Government. We are talking, of course, about the great mass of middle Australians and the same great mass that the Hawke Labor Government purports to support. Equally, it is a fact--and Labor may get sick of hearing this--that indirect taxes have substantially increased since 1983. They are up 50 per cent per head without one cent of compensation.

In a debate last week, I was referring to exactly these figures as well. But I thought it was worth driving the point home because this Government refuses to answer the question as to why it has sought to increase the levels of sales tax as dramatically as it has. Then again, as we on this side could not help but interject when Senator Sherry made the comment that he is waiting for our retirement incomes policy, at least we have had such a policy at every election in this decade, which is more than the Labor Party has had in terms of tax policies, development policies, resource policies and environment policies. Therefore, I think it is rather cute that he should stand up in the Senate and ask where our tax policy is.

I might well ask the Labor Government where its tax policies were for the elections of 1983, 1984, 1987 and 1990. We have not yet seen one of them, so I suppose we may--with any degree of luck, but I would not hold my breath--see a taxation policy prior to the next election. It is rather fascinating that Government members should stand up in this chamber--and, of course, in the other chamber--and parade all around Australia saying that they want to see our tax policy. It is no wonder. If the Government does not have one of its own, then it looks at somebody else's. It is also no wonder that a government presiding over such an erosion of spending power should resort to the misrepresentation of the coalition's policies. Quite frankly, it is obviously far safer to do that than to depend upon its own record.

Unlike the Hawke Labor Government's policies, the Hewson coalition taxation policy has a very positive message of reform. It will be a tax on spending in preference to earnings and will bring some logic and equity into direct taxation. Of course, that will also enable people to be masters of their own destiny. They will have more money that they can decide how they want to spend. If there is one factor that we hear all the time wherever we go, it is that people are sick of being taxed as heavily as they are. They constantly tell us and they must be telling the Labor Party as well that it is not worth their time to work overtime because they lose it all in taxation. It is not worth their time to work longer and harder because all the extra money goes in taxation--personal levels of income tax.

As a nation, we must make sure that the incentive is returned for people to be able to earn more money and to be able to take home more of the money that they earn. They will then have a lower level of taxation and that taxation will be on spending. That is a fairer means of taxing. Consumers will pay less for some goods and probably the same for the majority of goods now covered by 20 per cent sales tax. As I say, at the level of 30 per cent, they will certainly be paying more. Admittedly--and we do not try to deny it at all--there will be an increase in prices of some goods. But the difference with our policy, as opposed to that of the Labor Government, will be that the taxpayers will obtain relief from the stifling current rates of income tax and any increase in the cost of some items will be offset by the huge reductions in personal levels of income tax, increases in welfare benefits and packages for those who are on superannuation.

Small business operators will discover that the refunding of inputs will give them a cash flow advantage, while under Labor, small business people unlucky enough to be caught in the sales tax net must wrestle with the pitfalls of self-assessment. But, of course, one of the great problems with the Labor Government is that most of its members have been trade union people who have never had to run a business of their own. They have never had to find the money to pay the wages at the end of the week. They have never had to find the money to pay for the rent, the telephone, the cost of their products, the payroll tax and all the other taxes that they face.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Some even get a government-paid driver.

—-That is quite correct, Senator Panizza. As the honourable senator quite rightly says, some do get a government-paid driver and they are not even producing other forms of income. We are not too sure as to how that happens but, of course, we are bound to find out. The problem is that if this Government continues along its line of just endorsing trade union hacks, then the understanding of how the imposts that this Government places on business and the flow-on effect that that has on the employment market will never be changed. Government members have never had to experience the problems that are associated with it.

SPEECH.PARA: Small business operators really have a problem with all of these tax measures and, as Senator Sherry commented a little while ago, we do believe that the superannuation imposts on the business community generally is just another form of tax because it is no more and no less. In the same way, the training guarantee levy is just another form of tax--a tax on employment. In fact, the training guarantee levy has worked in a counterproductive way with a number of organisations. They are now finding that they, in fact, have to spend less on their training costs than they had to in the past. Senator Sherry shakes his head. He would not have a clue because he has never got out there in the business community. He does not know what the business community has spent in the past on training because it is people like him who just believe that training happens at the click of the fingers. It is, in fact, a very well-planned operation by many organisations right throughout this country.

I take a further example of how a goods and services tax would be of benefit to a group in the business area such as the vegetable growers and processors in Western Australia who are trying to compete with New Zealand products. They will have a greater chance of level competition if Australia also has a goods and services tax that exempts both business inputs and exports--neither of which are exempt from sales tax at present. Therefore, these people are finding their lives pretty uncompetitive when compared with those of our New Zealand partners.

Not only do we need to query the stifling level of Labor taxes, but we also need to query how those taxes are spent. Of the revenue collected from PAYE taxpayers, 68 cents in each dollar was spent on the welfare sector in 1982. In 1991, the welfare sector is consuming 34 per cent of the Federal Budget and 86 cents of each PAYE dollar; it has increased from 68 cents back in 1982. I raise this not to blame the recipients of this money, so many of whom would want to work and be independent or, if retired, to have provided it for themselves but, like John Hewson, to point out that the best form of welfare that any person can get is to have a job. If the Government does not understand that, then the situation is even more tragic than any of us realised. I blame this Government that relies on the welfare net to sweep up the victims of its job destroying policies.

When 100,000 jobs disappear and inflation rises at least 2 per cent as a result of Labor's 5 per cent superannuation impost on employers, welfare spending, however disguised, rises further. What the Opposition is still saying is: do not just look at continuing to raise the levels of welfare. Look at creating employment policies that will create jobs to reduce the need for welfare.

Senator Sherry also said prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner that our dole policy is absolutely inhumane. How inhumane, I might ask, is an unemployment level of 10 per cent plus? I would think that is more inhumane than anything, because what we are talking about is creating jobs. Ultimately, the most humane and practical solution to the problem of relative poverty and dependency is to create a climate in which greater national wealth is generated and more Australians have jobs; in John Hewson's words, a steady job is the best form of welfare.

It is not inhumane after nine months to tell people who have not tried to get jobs or who will not accept work or retraining that they will no longer receive unemployment relief as income support. People do not starve in the streets in other Western nations where this discipline applies. We are not saying to those who do try hard to get a job, who can prove that they have tried hard to get a job and are prepared to take any job that is offered to them that they will be left on the scrap heap. The Government well and truly knows that, but it seeks to continue to misrepresent the policy and the position that we have taken.

We are not going to force taxpayers, who are struggling to make ends meet thanks to this Government's high taxation policies, to fork out more for those who simply do not want to work and who do not try to get work. It is not necessarily humane to emphasise the right to welfare rather than the right and duty to work, as the ultimate disaster for young Australians is to head towards middle life without experiencing paid employment in the open job market. It is positively inhumane to resist introducing the deregulated wage levels which the coalition seeks and which would give these people work experience.

I repeat the challenge of Dr Hewson: before well-intentioned Australians decry the coalition proposal for a genuine work test, are they prepared to endorse the justice of a system that allows able-bodied people to live indefinitely at the expense of PAYE taxpayers without making an effort on their own behalf? I think the overwhelming cry of all Australians would be that they are not prepared to keep paying higher and higher taxes to subsidise those who will not find work. They are quite happy to pay for those who are genuinely out of work, genuinely trying to find work and, as I said before, are prepared to take any job that is offered to them.

By its actions, or lack of them, the Hawke Labor Government has long made it clear that it is not going to take the necessary steps to tackle the silent menace of our accumulated $165 billion foreign debt, the social evil of lost job opportunities, and the imperative to increase national productivity. A government that was truly committed to productivity would not be giving its moral support to the union opponents of Robe River Iron in its continued drive for the elimination of those work practices that are absolutely counterproductive to productivity and to Australia's international reputation. Here we have a company that has increased real productivity by 320 per cent. In anyone's terms that is outstanding. It has done that in only four years, with production up from 10,000 tonnes to 32,000 tonnes per employee. To achieve this, 284 restrictive work practices had to be eliminated and 300 job classifications existing in 1987 were reduced to 10 employee and three management classifications. That is how you get productivity up; that is how you start making dollars for Australia; and that is how you start creating employment.

Nothing better illustrates the sectional, negative ethos of Labor than its denigration of this company, with the State Labor conference in Western Australia actually calling for the withdrawal of this company's export licence. It actually called for the withdrawal of an export licence of a company that has in four short years increased its production from 10,000 tonnes to 32,000 tonnes. It wants to pull out the rug from underneath it. It is a disgrace. To Labor, protection of union privilege, as we know, is a lot more important than earning export dollars for Australia.

Where the Hawke Labor Government has failed Australia disastrously is in its continued defence of a centralised, regulated industrial relations system, when it has properly brought in financial deregulation and moved towards freer trade.

Waterfront reform is a saga of too little, too late because this Labor Government will always squib a confrontation with the Waterside Workers Federation and the ACTU. We know that to be fact. It is not some pipedream of mine or anybody else; that is just fact. It is a national disgrace that while Australia remains 50 per cent as productive as European ports and 40 per cent as productive as those of Asia, New Zealand, under its Labour Government, bit the bullet, raised waterfront productivity by over 100 per cent and lowered costs to a level 60 per cent below our own. A New Zealand Labour Government was able to do that. Why cannot this Labor Government take a leaf out of its book? It does not have the courage or the ability to take on the Waterside Workers Federation or the ACTU.

This Labor Government thinks it is good enough that national exports and imports pay what is an industrial relations tax of up to $1 billion annually while 5,000 waterside workers earn $40,000 to $50,000 annually for 25 productive hours per week. Are there not an awful lot of Australians who would like to earn $40,000 to $50,000 annually for working 40 hours, even 80 hours, a week? But no! Waterside workers are getting that for working just 25 hours per week. This Labor Government sits back while double-manned cranes with the capacity to load 30 containers per hour load only 17 compared to 26 in Singapore and while only some 450 of 3,000 necessary redundancies have taken place.

Australia will never begin to solve its economic problems as long as we have a Labor Government that buys votes at the expense of wealth-creating industry, exemplified by the disgraceful decision against mining at Coronation Hill. A Government determined to buy Green preferences at all costs and stay in government at all costs seized upon the alleged sensibilities of one section of an Aboriginal community to deny a wealth-creating, job-creating project. Because the scientific grounds for prohibiting mining were not there, what did we find? Bula was suddenly and conveniently conjured up. Whether the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) actually believed his emotional claptrap about Bula--and it is the only way one can describe it--really matters little.

The Prime Minister sent the mining industry and the outside world a message about where his Government's priorities lie. He also succeeded in giving massive encouragement to extremists within the Aboriginal community to exercise obstruction and blackmail through the invention of sacred sites not recognised by genuine custodians. Of course, the Prime Minister's young son has probably given him a lot of information about that because, quite frankly, he is one of the white do-gooders in the Aboriginal community in the north of Western Australia who seek to undermine the efforts of the decent Aboriginal communities up there and also, of course, seek to undermine further development that can provide income for both black and white communities in those areas.

The attempts to thwart the Yakabindie project in Western Australia are an inevitable result of signals from a Federal Labor Government that anti-mining views expressed by Aboriginals are somehow more genuine than support for the mining that will give them a chance of breaking the cycle of poverty and dependence. Poverty and dependence indeed will be the fate of tens of thousands of Australians unless a coalition government is elected to implement radical reform, not only of taxation, but also of industrial relations so that the focus is clearly placed squarely on the enterprise and choice exists to opt out of the arbitration system.

Business, of course, will be unable to survive and create jobs if the Hawke-Labor Government allies itself with the fourth faction, the Australian Democrats, and enshrines the right to strike and takes away the vital protection afforded to small business by section 45D of the Trade Practices Act.

It is of concern to see the even greater left turn on which Senator Coulter is now taking the Democrats. They will keep turning left that hard that they will eventually come back to meet themselves. They do not understand what they stand for. They do not understand even whether they like each other, let alone what their policies are. But for a group of politicians whose foundation was `keeping the bastards honest', they are now proclaiming, ahead of an election, that they are going to try to stop us from being honest and stop us as a coalition from implementing the policies on which we will go to the electorate. So where do they stand on anything? Heaven only knows.

So long as this Labor Government condemns Australia to a union dominated industrial relations system, productivity in regard to motor vehicles will remain at two-thirds the rate in the United States. An employee in the United States will produce 5,000 tonnes of cement, while his Australian counterpart produces 2,000. Of course, I have conveniently ignored comparisons with Japan, quite frankly because they are far too embarrassing.

There is no humanity, only weakness and cowardice in the refusal of the Hawke Labor Government to implement the reforms that Australian enterprise and individual Australians need so badly. They want jobs, less tax and lesser burdens around their necks. It is about time a coalition government gave that to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Tonight we are debating the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1991-92 and the amendment moved by Senator Short. One should have thought that this would be the Budget brought down by the Government to try to turn things around in the next 12 months, a Budget to get us out of the worst recession or depression. We should have stopped using the term `recession' a long time ago and used `depression' instead. It is the worst spot we have been in since the 1930s. One should have thought that we would have a Budget to get us moving. What do we have instead? We have a Budget that will increase rather than decrease unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: If you do not believe this is the case, Mr Deputy President, then look at the unemployment figures in the last two months since the Budget was announced on approximately 20 August and see how those figures have taken off upwards. I cannot see those figures turning around for a mighty long time yet.

Tonight I will direct my remarks mainly towards Senator Short's amendment, paragraph (e) of which reads, `imposing major obstacles to resource development;' for which the Government stands condemned. It was the subject of debate last Thursday evening. Let me again remind the chamber that the only industry that will get Australia moving quickly is the resource development industry. We must increase the pace of the resource development we already have and start developing new resource industries. But what is the Government doing? It is only putting impediments in the road. If it is not putting impediments in the road of resource development, it is certainly not doing anything about removing those impediments that are already there.

I will start with land access and the approval process, which are two very fundamental aspects of getting a resource project going. They can briefly be broken down into three aspects: environment, Aboriginal heritage and the mode of processing applications. There are a lot of others but I will go into these in some detail first.

Unfortunately, environmental considerations are used to veto projects and usually influence the final decision. Nothing is done concurrently in project approval systems. There are probably 14 or 15 processes that must be gone through to get the simplest developments going. But it seems that the steps are done one by one and time is lost in this way. If the other stages are completed, the environmental authorities, aided by their lobby, bring everything to a halt and put it on hold forever, as happened at Coronation Hill. Then there are sovereign risks associated with the terms and conditions of exploration and mining leases.

We have export controls especially on the sand mining industry, where there is a requirement for annual approvals. How can any company that proposes a development be asked to spend upwards of $300m or $400m and then go back for an approval every 12 months? It is utterly impossible. One would not invest in one year $300m or $400m for an approval to get a project going and then, before even finishing the development budget, go back for another approval.

The way lobby groups--Green, Left and environmental lobby groups--work these days, a company would get caught between approvals or could spend the entire project money and then not be given the right to go ahead. There are a few projects like that, especially in Western Australia, that have been set up and mothballed straightaway. A further example is export taxes, reducing further development opportunities in coal.

The Foreign Investment Review Board does not have the right guidelines by which to work. These guidelines seem to change with the current mood of the Government. They should be brought into line with general guidelines. The current arrangements discourage foreign mining companies and so should be brought into line with the general thrust to get resource projects going rather than destroy them.

My colleague Senator Knowles ably pointed out that waterfront and shipping reform is needed in competitive market structures. Excess rail freights and cross-subsidisation issues are preventing project resources from proceeding in a profitable mode or are even preventing the development of new ones.

Electricity generation and distribution need to be open to private sector involvement. At Collie in Western Australia, the Western Australian Government has just signed an agreement for Australia's first private generation plant, yet the union power of Western Australia, and indeed of all of Australia, is trying to wreck it immediately. What gives any trade union movement the right to think that it will keep power generation in the public domain forever and a day, the result being that this country will not be internationally competitive because of the high cost of electricity to industry, especially in Western Australia?

What about fuel excise? Senator Sherry asked where the coalition's tax policy was. Here he was trying to defend the Government's Budget, yet he has probably never in his life risked a dollar of his own in business. If he has, I wish he would tell me because I would be very happy to be proved wrong on this matter. I doubt whether there is anyone on the Government benches who has risked a dollar in his or her life, except one who now sits on the back bench, the former Minister for Finance, Senator Peter Walsh. He is the only one who I know for sure has risked his own dollar. I do not hear any cries from anyone on the Government benches that I am on the wrong path, yet time and time again Government members come in here and ask where our tax policy is and tell us what we should be doing.

At least there are many Opposition members who have risked their own money in business ventures. In fact, Senator Knowles risked her own private dollars in a small business before she came into parliament. It is a lot better preparation for parliament to use one's pocket to make one's way through the world than to be on the payroll of a government enterprise or, worse, the trade union movement. But I have digressed. So, if we want to be internationally competitive, the cost of electricity generation in Australia has to be addressed.

I have mentioned fuel excise. Under our tax policy--under the goods and services tax--certain fuel excise will be removed. If the Government cannot see that that is the way to go, it could at least expand the fuel excise rebate system to accommodate this, as is done in the farming industry.

The three-mine uranium policy has been a platform of the Labor Party ever since I can remember. Senator McMullan has talked about this more than once. Once again, there has been a hold-up in the area of project development. We have to produce because the rural industry, mainly led by wheat and wool, is not in a position this time to get us out of this trough. There seems to have been a cycle over the years: every 10 or 15 years, each industry has a turn at bailing Australia out. In the 1930s it was the mining industry, in the 1950s it was primary industry and in the 1960s it was mining again. But now that the rural industry is not in a position to assist, we have to look to the mining industry--the resource sector--to do that.

I now turn to taxation issues, such as the depreciation regime not being related to the economic cost of capital and indirect taxes on business inputs. We on this side of the chamber have said time and time again that the March statement should have included something about accelerated depreciation, but it did not. Legislation on this matter has not been brought before this place. The other night I pointed out that quite a few measures--very small measures--which were contained in the March statement have not seen the light of day.

I have probably touched on the issue of excessive uncertainty caused by future environmental policy. This Government does not know where its environmental policy is going. The Government's environmental agenda is set according to whether its legislation is supported by the Australian Democrats and Senator Vallentine. That is who sets the Government's agenda on the environment, and nobody else.

As I said before, when a mining resource project is being evaluated everyone should work together so that we can reach the position where we can give it the go-ahead. Senator Button and Mr Griffiths, from the other House, have been saying for the last two or three weeks that we need fast tracking. Where is that fast tracking? Even if the hold-ups caused by the environmental lobby and the Aboriginal heritage claims were to disappear tomorrow, it would still take a long time to get any project going because the authorities do not work together. That has to be looked at. I have said before that the veto should not lie in the hands of any of those authorities. If a project is confirmed or destroyed, it should be done quickly and in unison so that the company which has money to invest in Australia can look at other places, generally, overseas.

I saw figures the other day to the effect that one of our largest mining companies is now conducting 75 per cent of its exploration overseas. At the present moment, its production in Australia is probably higher than it is overseas but its exploration dollar has gone overseas and this Government has to be blamed totally for that. I am sure no-one on the other side can go back eight years to blame the Fraser Government for that happening. As I said, we were helped out of the 1930s Depression by the mining industry, and that industry will get us out of this one. Last Thursday evening the Government was condemned in this very chamber for holding up development and for not fast tracking resources in Australia.
Sir Charles Court in Western Australia led the mining revival in the 1960s. Senator McMullan smiles at that, but can he tell me of any other person who got the iron ore industry of Australia going?

TALK.START.PARA: —-I didn't smile; I laughed.
—-It is the same thing. Can he tell me of any other person who did so much to get that industry going and Australia moving?
—-A lot of workers worked very hard.

—-I am sure a lot of workers worked very hard. A lot of workers in the Pilbara were very well paid, and these workers in the Pilbara are being very well paid right now. As Senator Knowles has pointed out, per worker the men and women of Robe River produce the highest amount of iron ore in the world. They are also the most highly paid iron ore workers. The honourable senator cannot say that that is not correct.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other areas in which Australia is not being competitive in meeting world standards. Let me turn to the area of land transport. Alongside everything else, an industry resource has to have an efficient transport system--whether it be by sea, land or air; but in our case, it is mostly land transport. There has been hardly any progress in the last 12 months in land transport reform, although there may have been some marginal reforms. The National Rail Corporation agreement was signed at least six months late. The Corporation was supposed to start hauling freight on 1 July; it has not started yet, although we have a promise. It is now rumoured that it will start in February 1992--seven months after it was supposed to start. Maybe it will get going then, but I am not holding my breath.

There has been a tacit, if shaky, agreement on national operating systems for road transport. But even that is looking uncertain. The benefits are outweighed by the negatives; and, even when there has been any progress, there have been as many or more negatives. This has created uncertainty in the industry. It has created confusion, delay, lack of direction and ridicule of opponents. That is all the National Rail Corporation has been doing. Of course, its opponent happens to be the road transport industry. There is one way to fix it if one is in government: tax it out of existence and impose unacceptable and possibly dangerous regulations--such as some of the Australian design rules, which I will not go into fully this evening.

This Budget saw road funding fall by over 2 per cent in real terms. We are supposed to be getting Australian roads up to top standard and into a condition where they can handle an improved transport network. But the Government is letting the condition of the roads go backwards. Funding for major roads fell by 4.4 per cent in real terms. Funding for arterials--the arterials that this Government was going to make sure were in place so that when the major highways reached the cities transport would be able to get to the ports quite easily--has fallen by 18 per cent in real terms. Yet no provision was made to allow the States to raise their own revenue to cover this fall--and we hear about that only by way of comment in this place.

Since 1983-84, road funding has fallen by 20 per cent in real terms under this Government. Revenue from fuel tax has increased by over 120 per cent in the same period. Expenditure on roads as a percentage of excise has gone down from 63.2 per cent to 23.3 per cent--assuming all councils spent all of the Federal money on roads. The road freight industry has been thrown into chaos because of this Government's handling of road reform in the transport area.

Anyone who gets around Australia as much as I do by road transport would note that there is confusion in the road industry among shire councils and industries that rely on road transport. In fact, we got a good serving of that last weekend at the conference in Broome. Broome is one of the areas that have no other modes of transport. Inland remote areas have no sea transport, of course, and no rail transport, so they are at the mercy of anyone who wants to have a go at them. Truck sales are the lowest in 30 years, with truck values literally having been halved. What is this Government doing about that?

There are a lot of other aspects I would like to address in this Budget, but my time is running out. What has this Government done? I turn to the rural industries to see what this Government has done for them. As I said earlier, we are at the lowest ebb since the 1930s, and we have a drought on our hands in the eastern States. This Government time and time again has blamed the 1981-82 recession fairly and squarely on the shoulders of Malcolm Fraser and his Government. That Government got into that position because of one almighty eastern States drought and a drought in Western Australia the year after.

There is now a drought in the northern part of the eastern States. What has the Government done? It has not even recognised it, made any noise about it or made preparations for the eventual result of that drought. We know it is there but we will not really feel it until the wheat payments and other grains payments do not come in next February. We have heard nothing from the Government even though we thought that there might have been further measures for the funding of RAFCOR, but, no, we have not heard that.

At least in Western Australia the Premier, Carmen Lawrence, undertook to have a GMP--a guaranteed minimum price--for wheat. She went it alone. I am a continual critic of the Premier of Western Australia, but not in this instance. The Government will not have to pay out because the price of wheat has improved. In Western Australia it gave the farmers confidence to plant a crop, and there is a good season. It gave the banks confidence to lend money to plant that crop. This Government, in one fell swoop, took away the GMP in 1988 and loaded on a wheat industry fund of 2 per cent, which is sitting there gathering minimal interest and doing nothing for the industry.

The GMP that had worked so well in various forms since 1947 went out the door and nothing has been done to replace it with a system for wheat marketing that will give farmers confidence to plant a reasonable crop every year. It is probably just as well--although I do not believe it is just as well to have a drought at any time--that there is a drought in the eastern States now. It has probably saved people from going further into debt if they have not planted a crop, but the better areas of this country are missing out on export income that we could do with.

TALK.START.PARA: —-We are not going to ask you to go and tell the people of Bourke that!

—-That is right. As I said, I never want to see a drought or a bad season anywhere because I have gone through plenty, and probably Senator West has seen some too. It is unfortunate that, in the areas where there has been a good season, a full crop was not planted so that we could earn export dollars.

SPEECH.PARA: My time to speak is coming towards an end. The Government stands condemned for bringing down a Budget which is doing nothing to get resource projects off the ground in Australia. It is doing nothing to get those one million people who are unemployed back onto the payroll in Australia. It is doing nothing like that. There was a March statement this year, the year before it was an April statement and the year before that it was in May, so next year there will probably be a February statement to try to turn around the mismanagement that there will be in this place because of the Budget that has been brought down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Debates in this chamber, indeed in the Parliament, centre very much on economic issues. In fact, the economy is the main topic for debate in this Parliament. We take the approach that the cure for the country's ills depends solely on the correct application of economic measures. We have just heard Senator Panizza and many of his colleagues before him address this chamber on the basis that, if somehow we can work the right economic levers, happiness will come out. I am not sure that that is correct or that economic rationalism--which is the policy the Opposition adopts--will deliver this country into happiness, contentment and fairness.

SPEECH.PARA: The sorts of terms that we have grown used to using in this chamber include `Budget deficit', `balance of payments', `monetary policy', `fiscal measures', `gross domestic product', `inflation' and `current account'. It is thought that if we debate in those terms we will pull Australia away from the problems that it presently faces. The difficulty with that approach is that it sometimes--indeed, all too often--tends to leave out the sorts of things that are important for a happy and cohesive society.

I do not think that by juggling economic concepts we will get a cure for our present ills, yet that seems to be the approach that is taken on the other side. It leads to all sorts of problems, of course. For example, the attitude taken to unions becomes a very unhappy one if we approach things on the basis of economic rationalism. Clearly, unions restrict the full effect of economic theory that is based on the concept that people are just another cog in the machine, that the only thing that is of worth in any particular person is the commodity he or she supplies--namely, his or her labour. That is a most difficult problem.

If we pursue that line too far we get to the situation that New Zealand now has where industrial legislation is such as to become a moral issue. I do not say that lightly. I am supported in that proposition by the New Zealand Catholic Bishops Conference, which on 19 April made a pastoral statement dealing with the legislation that has been passed in that country in respect of labour relations. The people who passed that are on a personal basis very decent people, but they have been led down the path that they have taken by adopting the theory of economists who have left out the human perspective of people and relied purely on economic rationalism. The legislation that has been passed in New Zealand has brought forth the condemnation of the Bishops Conference. I will quote from paragraph 6 of the conference's statement. It says that this legislative change in New Zealand in respect of the works contract there `is not simply a technical issue'. The passage continues:

It involves ethics and morality. The question must be asked what the new legislation does to people and society, to human dignity and the common good. As Bishops of New Zealand, we must speak against this proposed legislation as its underlying ideology is contrary to the social doctrines of the Church. Pope Paul VI teaches that, "All social action involves a doctrine. The Christian cannot admit that which is based upon a materialistic and atheistic philosophy". The underlying ideology of the new industrial legislation is unacceptable for two reasons: firstly, because it emphasises free choice without balancing this concept with concern for the common, that is the public, good; and secondly because it emphasises the rights of the individual without their accompanying duty to act in solidarity and without giving any corresponding rights to the group.

The legislation assumes that the free pursuit of his or her interest by the private individual automatically leads to the public or common good of society. As Bishops, guiding our people in faith and morals, it is our duty to reject this assumption for two reasons.
The bishops go on to give the two reasons. I will not read those because it would make the quotation too long.

It is interesting that the bishops condemn the actions based on the free choice of individuals without balancing this concept with the concern for the common matters of public good, and condemn legislation where it emphasises the rights of individuals, without their accompanying duty to act in solidarity and without giving any corresponding rights to the groups.

Madam Acting Deputy President, you sit in the chamber day after day and hear speeches to the effect that individuals should be given encouragement, with which I agree; and if that is to the detriment of other people, a concept with which I do not agree, I am sure you would agree that those concepts being put forward are a matter for concern. One illustration of that is the way in which unions, simply because they are unions, are condemned time and again in this chamber. If the unions go beyond what is reasonable they, like any other group, deserve to be criticised. But, where they are simply upholding the rights of the group as against the individual, they are worthy of praise rather than condemnation because they are acting in light of the concepts put forward by the bishops.

I notice that Senator Crane is in the chamber. Perhaps I may use as an illustration what is meant by a particular group, union or persons being condemned. If one looks at the reality of the situation, one sees that the union in question has been criticised not because in this particular case it has frustrated individual rights or ambitions but simply because there has been a wrong assessment of what has happened. The situation at the Camperdown meatworks has been much condemned. The Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, particularly the Victorian branch, has been condemned for not allowing the works to open. Today it is pointed out on page 6 of the Herald-Sun, in the right hand corner within a very small compass, that the reason the Camperdown meatworks has not opened is that it has failed to pass an Australian Quarantine Service inspection. According to that article, a list of safety and hygiene issues has to be settled before the meatworks can start work. It will be interesting to see whether the people who condemn the union still persist with the fact that the meatworks should open despite the fact that it has failed to pass the Australian Quarantine Service inspection.

If we approach economic activity on the basis that an individual should be able to do what he or she wants to do and the rest of us can go he, are we saying that the works should be open, and what does it matter if it does not meet the health requirements? In other words, are we saying that, if the individual's rights or wants are the only consideration, what happens to other people who may buy or eat that meat is irrelevant?

What I am trying to draw from all this is that, when we go around talking of individuals and of the rights of particular groups rather than looking at the community as a whole, we get ourselves into all sorts of difficulties. That concept has been realised more and more by people who observe these things. For example, I noticed in the Bulletin of 8 October this year, on page 86, an article by Evan Jones, a senior lecturer in the Department of Economics at the University of Sydney, where he has taught for 18 years. Mr Jones has written an article headed `Down with Economists'. He says in that article:

There is something about proximity to the engine room of government that has eliminated the academic uncertainties. In the process, a bizarre transformation has occurred. The purveyors of an utterly unreal vision have become major agents of the political process. Economists have parlayed intellectual nonsense into real processes through fusing with a social practice at odds with the vision they espouse so religiously. For all their worldly naivete, economists can unerringly develop an attachment to opinions which attract an elevated status and income.

The end result is far from savoury. Economists have become a plague as dangerous as rabbits, prickly pear or cane toads. Economists have become the cultural cane toads of Canberra, oozing over the landscape and endangering myriad indigenous species.

Not only the economy but also mental health would be greatly improved if we could lift the fog of obfuscation on things economic. The first step is to take economists from their pedestal and to see them as the curiosities they are.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Senator Cooney, this sounds very interesting, but I did not pick it all up. Perhaps you would like to read the quote again.

—-Madam Acting Deputy President, I will not repeat the passage, though I was getting a little far away from the microphone. I was getting a little concerned that these economists might hear me and come and deal with me as if I were a cane toad. I was saying that Mr Jones was making the point that as a first step one should take economists from their pedestal and see them as the curiosities they are. He concludes by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The first step to reducing their power is to reduce their legitimacy.

That sort of thing has been reiterated, in milder terms perhaps, in quite surprising places. For example, in the Weekend Australian of 12 to 13 October 1991, at page 30, John Hyde, who is known very much for his dry politics, has pointed out that economists who simply apply dry theory have become a problem. He has spoken of the need for morality to enter the game and for people to think in larger concepts than simply the economic terms of which they presently talk.

The order of the day is that none of us stay too long on our feet. I notice that Senator Crane is about to speak. I hope that in his speech he gives proper weight to the need for the group to act properly; for the unions to defend their workers against the reduction in conditions; for people to think in terms other than the simple dry economics that we have spoken about so far; and for him to realise that we as politicians have to give up simply repeating what economists say and start thinking for ourselves.

Economists are like all other experts: we are very suspicious of what they come forward with. There is nobody quite so confident in giving an opinion as an expert, and often there is nobody quite so wrong. What I would like to hear in the rest of this debate is the expression of the true views of people. We should certainly look to economists for help because economists are absolutely essential to the proper development of policy, but they are not the only ones we should be looking to. There are all sorts of other people we can refer to, including bishops. I suppose that I could have quoted statements from other great churchmen to support that proposition, but they are the sorts of people we should certainly be looking to.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Is this Aquinas or Marx?
—-Senator Parer has come in. I quoted the bishops and he thought they were the Marxists. This is what has happened. When I quote the bishops and these people of great morality--
—-I might have to give a personal explanation about this.
—-Is Senator Parer saying they were not Marxist?
—-I said, `Is this Aquinas or Marx?'.
—-I see; I am sorry. No, these are the bishops of New Zealand. I will quote the two archbishops of Melbourne--
—-You have started him again.

—-I will quote this and then I will sit down. Even Senator McMullan is now objecting. Senator McMullan is an economist deep down. When I first met Senator McMullan, he was an unconstructed economist, but since he has associated with me he has taken on a human face. I will just quote the archbishops of Melbourne. I hope all honourable senators pay proper attention to this. If they think that I have not quoted them properly, they can telephone Archbishop Frank Little on 667 0377 and Archbishop Keith Rayner on 653 4215 during the day in working hours. I am sure that is only on business days. This is what together these two great archbishops have to say:

SPEECH.PARA: We recognise that there are many honest and dedicated people in positions of leadership in politics and public life--
and I am sure they include Senator Parer and Senator McMullan--

and we want to encourage and support these people. There is a tendency to make scapegoats of our leaders for failures in which the whole community has some share. But this kind of scapegoating is both unfair and counterproductive. We do not want to focus on the past but to look towards the future.

We believe that as a community we have now to take those steps that will save us from becoming an embittered and divided community, with some of the `haves' getting richer and the `have-nots' suffering continued injustice. We wish to support all community efforts to develop a new sense of fair play and cooperation among all Victorians--
I am sure that the members of this chamber would substitute the word `Australians' for the word `Victorians'--
a new sense of responsibility for one another's welfare and a new sense of working together to lay the foundations of a genuinely just society.
We believe that in the challenge facing us we will have to renew our commitment to moral values. I hoped that everybody in the chamber would say,`Hear! Hear!' to that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise to speak tonight on the Appropriation Bills and the amendment moved by Senator Short. I have certainly listened with interest to what Senator Cooney had to say. I do not have a problem with people defending their position as long as they defend that position through the due processes of the law and do not start making the laws to suit themselves or abuse the laws when decisions do not go their way.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cooney particularly mentioned the Camperdown meatworks. When that issue was raised with me last week and I was informed of the reasons for the AQIS inspection, I said to the people who raised it with me that they would have to fix up that problem. The answer to Senator Cooney's problem is not to go screaming to the press or trying to create some sort of a fictitious situation. I will stand by that. I will also stand by the belief that those people in our society who belong to a union or an employer association, or do not belong to either, do not have the right to take the law into their own hands or abuse it. This has consistently happened in this country.

Before I get to my main points--and I hope that I have something constructive to say tonight--I want to comment on a couple of matters which were raised by previous speakers. I want to talk briefly about what has happened in the past eight years, because that is the relevant point. When a party is in government, it is in a position to do things to improve the economy and try to solve some of the problems that Senator Cooney raised. However, when a party is in opposition, it can only fiddle away at the edges of those issues.

Let us look at what I term the human tragedy that we have suffered as a result of the policies of the last eight years. First, I want to address unemployment, particularly youth unemployment, and quote a few figures to illustrate what has occurred over the last eight years as a result of this Government's policies. In Western Australia in the past 12 months there has been a 52 per cent increase in youth unemployment, from 18.1 per cent to 27.6 per cent; in New South Wales, a 69 per cent increase in unemployment from 15.7 per cent to 26.6 per cent; in Victoria, a 48.85 per cent increase; in Queensland, a 15 per cent increase; in South Australia, a 16 per cent increase; and, in Tasmania, a 26 per cent increase. Those figures demonstrate quite clearly what has happened as a result of the Government losing control of the economy.

If we go a little further and look at bankruptcies in the last 12 months, we find a very similar story--another human tragedy. In Victoria there has been a 71 per cent increase in bankruptcies; in Western Australia, 70 per cent; in New South Wales, 52 per cent; in Queensland, 52 per cent; and, in South Australia, 26 per cent. Another measure of the human tragedy, again as a result of this Government's policies, is the changes for those who have been forced onto unemployment benefit in this country in the past 12 months. I quote some figures from my home State of Western Australia. In Albany there has been a 78 per cent increase in unemployment; in Cannington, 64 per cent; in Innaloo, 72 per cent; and, in Midland, a 64 per cent increase. I could go on quoting figures, but I do not see much point in it.

Senator Sherry comes into this chamber and says that we in opposition have no policies. He would do himself a service if he had a look at the result of policies of the Government that he has been part of or that he has supported. In 1980-81, Commonwealth outlays were 26.7 per cent of GDP and in 1990-91, 27.3 per cent; but in 1984-85 they rose to 31.3 per cent. SPEECH.PARA: When we look at the revenue figures we find a similar story. When we look at net Public Service borrowings, once again, there is a similar story. It is irresponsible to select figures from these trends and quote them to suit one's own ends because the total picture shows that there are fluctuations from year to year and in different periods of time. In their speeches on this matter, Senator Sherry and Senator Maguire were endeavouring to defend the indefensible.

I wish now to comment on the farm sector, particularly with regard to wool and wheat. I support the comments of my colleague Senator Panizza. Both of these industries--which are very important for us as a nation in terms of being able to balance our budget--are in total collapse. Even though interest rates have been lowered, they are still a problem. Real interest rates are having an impact on our dollar. In Australia our real interest rate is 7 per cent, in the United States, against which our dollar is primarily aligned, the interest rate is 2 per cent. Until such time as we have policies in place which reduce our real interest rate to the same level as that of the United States, we will not see our dollar in a competitive position with the United States dollar.

It is very important that this aspect be addressed. From the information I can collect from economists and people who study these things, it is generally believed that our exports are best able to compete--whether it be wool and wheat, our mining industry or our export manufacturing industry--with the dollar somewhere between 70c and 72c. It is worth noting that each 1 per cent fall in the dollar is worth $150m to agriculture; a similar amount for mining; and approximately $75m for the export manufacturing industry.

If we had 2 per cent real interest rates--the same as the US--we could expect our dollar to be somewhere in the order of 70c to 72c, and that would mean $3 billion a year additional income to Australia. It would have a very big impact on our ability to address our current account problems, which were highlighted earlier in this debate. It would have a very big impact on our ability as a nation to overcome a lot of our unemployment problems and our bankruptcy problems. It would make an enormous difference to the infrastructure of rural and regional Australia.

In addition, we would see many more projects becoming internationally competitive. Senator Panizza mentioned resource development earlier tonight. We have debated Marandoo and Yakabindie in this place. I, and other speakers, have raised Robe River and its competitiveness. Robe River was able to achieve that competitiveness by doing two major things. Firstly, it re-organised its management and got rid of weak management; and, secondly, it got rid of an enormous number of crazy work practices.

I will give one example of the craziness that existed at Robe River prior to 1987. A car belonging to a member of the management would not start. Another member of management started his car with jumper leads. The electrical union found out the next day and demanded that management dismiss these two people, or the union would go on strike. As a result, three days work was lost because it went on strike. That is an example of the work practices which existed at Robe River that made it non-competitive. We now find that this company has stability in employment, has increased productivity by approximately 320 per cent and is operating at world best practice. It should be the target of all of us to get operations in this country to world best practice, then we will be competitive and can truly address the problems we have with unemployment and the other matters I have raised.

Another matter that I want to raise in this debate on the Appropriation Bills is that there have been allocations during the year to the Rural Adjustment Authority. I believe it is time that some lateral thinking was applied to the situation which exists with the Rural Adjustment Authority. It has got itself into a vicious circle. As each downturn comes, those who were efficient operators in industry are financed into taking those supposedly non-efficient people out of the industry. When the next downturn comes around we find that, because of the additional debt loading, suddenly they are at risk and considered to be inefficient producers and forced out of the industry.

Two things could be addressed in terms of assistance to ride out the current situation. The first one is a hard look at part B, which is the area which handles carry-on finance. This is funded 50-50 by the States and the Commonwealth. In my view it is not working, not because the Commonwealth has not put up the money, but because the States, by and large, have not been prepared to match dollar for dollar. Consequently, part B has virtually had its door shut. As I said in Estimates committee hearings the other day, I believe it is essential to look again at part B.

Another matter I wish to raise with regard to debt loading is whether there is a role for the Rural Adjustment Authority to be involved in mortgage insurance so that long term stability can be offered during these periodical downturns in agriculture. This is a very important issue and it needs to be extended to include small business that is directly related in the industry.

I shall now comment on the wool industry. Tragically, we have seen wool prices drop markedly over the past month. I believe much of this has been brought about by the fact that there has been an eagerness to sell wool out of the stockpile. Going back to the debate we had about the wool industry--I will certainly not go over it tonight other than to quote one figure--honourable senators will recall that we said there was provision to sell approximately $76m worth in the first year, but there should be no sales from the stockpile before Christmas.

That figure was exceeded in the first six weeks of this financial year. It has given the trade a belief that there would be a rush of wool onto the market from the stockpile. While I note that the Wool Realisation Commission has said that in the immediate short term, as from last Friday, it will not put any more wool onto the market, I believe that the horse has bolted and a decision needs to be made by the Commission that it has sold close to $1m out of the stockpile and that no more wool will be released from the stockpile until the market stabilises and the trade gets a feel for the market price of wool.

I have covered some detail in my comments tonight. However, some absolutely essential points need to be made alongside some of my previous comments. One concerns the reform of the taxation system to bring back incentive. It is essential that we get rid of the wholesale sales tax and substantially lower income tax rates.

I want to raise another anomaly that has come into the wholesale sales tax arena. That has come from the most recent ruling, No. 3005. It really is a crazy example. In relation to four-wheel drive vehicles for use by agriculturalists--the term has been extended from agriculture to agriculturalists and I assume that it includes shearers and service industries, but that has not yet been determined--a double-cabin utility with a tray qualifies, while a station wagon does not. We find that a truck with a tandem drive axle does, but one which has a lazy axle does not. It certainly appears from that ruling that a prime mover which pulls a trailer does not. I would be pleased to hear from anybody who can tell me the logic behind that decision and how to sort that little lot out, because I do not know what the logic is or and how it could be sorted out.

In conclusion, I say that the Budget lacks vision. There is no lateral thinking. It is more of the same, the same policies that have failed. Those failures must be laid fairly and squarely on the shoulders of the ex-Treasurer, Paul Keating, and Prime Minister Hawke. I support the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I intend to start my speech tonight by being non-controversial and bipartisan. Initially I want to comment upon the issue of the corruption of our overseas markets through the subsidisation practices that are carried out by other countries. It has saddened me a bit to find that the general public assumes that politicians never agree upon anything, that the disagreement, disharmony and argument portrayed in the media are what happens all the time. On this particular issue, that is not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: I was recently in Coonabarabran and was able to point out to a small group of people whom I met there who were from all political parties that their lower House member--their member in the other place--Senator Brownhill from the other side of this House and I had, on a number of occasions when we have had United States-Australia friendship meetings with members of the US Government or the US Embassy, very emphatically put the point of view for a change from the existing export enhancement program to a free market and to less subsidisation. This pleased these people, who have an interest in primary production and who live in a country town. For once, they were able to learn that politicians do not spend all their time criticising one another, carping and being argumentative. I would not want to attribute blame as to who is responsible for this particular perspective being portrayed, but the media should probably look very much at what they have contributed.

The massive subsidisation of farm products from those areas of the European Community and the United States of America is a major concern to all primary producers in Australia and to all Australians. This year the Parliament has seen two bipartisan groups go to both the USA and the EC to bring our concerns to the attention of the members of parliament and the administrations of all those countries.

These groups have also been accompanied by representatives of the farmer organisations so that it does not appear that just politicians are speaking; so that it is actually giving farmers a voice and an opportunity to have their point heard. I know that other politicians and some of my colleagues who have visited those counties have used every opportunity to raise that particular issue. I know that I did when I was in England in May this year, much to the squirming and discomfort, I think I would have to say, of some of the politicians there.

This support of Australia's membership of the Cairns Group is valuable and must continue. A positive outcome of the Uruguay Round of Multilateral Trade Negotiations and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is imperative. It is necessary that President Bush recognise the problems that the USA export enhancement scheme is having on Australian farmers. I know that the farmers' leaders will put their case well. I hope their message is heeded.

I have recently obtained a copy of a booklet entitled Are you paying too much? which has been produced for the Australian Government for distribution in Australian embassies in our European posts. It asks a number of very pertinent questions which have to be addressed by the Europeans. The first is whether, as consumers, they are paying too much for their food. The price of steak in various countries is listed. In Germany it costs #7.39 a kilo; in France, #8.49; in the United Kingdom, #11.63; in Italy, #8.35; and, in Spain, #8.52. In Australia a kilo of steak costs #4.73, proving that we are able to produce the product without the gross subsidisation that those countries go in for at half the price of the product in those countries.

We also have to look at the impact of this subsidisation on the food prices and the food bills of people in those countries. At least 19 per cent can be added to the food bill of the average household income in France. The common agricultural policy has impacted by adding 32 per cent to the food bill of the average household income in the United Kingdom. The impact on the low income households is magnified much more. In a Spanish low income household, the common agricultural policy has an impact of increasing the food bill by 52 per cent. I ask: what number of farmers in the EC is the common agricultural policy assisting? Of all farmers in the EC, 20 per cent are collecting 80 per cent of the subsidies. It is not true for the EC to say that it is providing income support and assistance across the board. Quite patently, it is not happening.

I know that visiting members of parliament from any of the participating countries in the CAP and the EC can expect to be questioned at length by Australian politicians about their policies and the reasons why their countries do not see any need to modify their practices.
