TALK.START.PARA: —-The Appropriation Bills before the Senate tonight deal with the expenditure for the forthcoming financial year. I wish to restrict my comments tonight to the Department of Defence and I will deal with one or two topics in that area. I have transferred what I can from the committee stage into the second reading debate in order to save time at the committee stage. I feel quite strongly that the purpose of the Estimates committees is to allow the exploration by the Senate of the Estimates in a dedicated setting and not to re-run the debate in the committee stage in the chamber wherever that can be avoided.

SPEECH.PARA: The first topic I want to talk about is one that we have already discussed in some detail in the Estimates committees, that is, the way the Government is proceeding to buy roughly 100 light armoured vehicles--the LAVs. A light armoured vehicle is a vehicle which has minimal armoured protection for the crew and the soldiers within it. It has some offensive and defensive fire power capability. It is generally used for reconnaissance, observation and transport--either troops or stores. Of course, once one has one vehicle in that role, it is usual to develop a series of other vehicles for more specialised roles using the same basic design for ambulances, stores transports, recovery vehicles, command post vehicles and things such as that.

One of the arguments that is quite strong in armoured circles is whether one equips these vehicles with wheels or tracks. The arguments on that are endless. Track vehicles, with a caterpillar track like a tractor, handle most rough terrain--not all--much better than any wheeled vehicle. When one is in closely timbered country, again, a track vehicle is much more handy because its turning circle is really quite tight. One can lock a track and the vehicle will turn, whereas most wheeled armoured fighting vehicles have a very prodigious radius and one needs something like an airfield to turn them around. That is a bit of exaggeration, but the important point from a tactical point of view is that concealment is better with a track vehicle.

Track vehicles do much better in wet conditions. They are usually better armoured. They are usually a bit more robust mechanically. The difficulty is that they are always slow. Track vehicles are limited to the low speed regime and the solution to that is to mount them on trucks and transporters and one can move them over quite large distances rapidly that way.

Conversely, wheeled vehicles are very fast on roads. Speeds in excess of 100 or 110 kilometres for modern generation wheeled armoured fighting vehicles are not uncommon. That is not much use on the battlefield, but from a reconnaissance point of view it does enable one to cover very great distances quite rapidly. A unit such as 2 Cavalry, which is deployed in barracks in the eastern part of Darwin, can deploy quite rapidly to somewhere like Kununurra and, of course, the vehicles can operate alone in that role. They provide a more comfortable ride for their crews. The disadvantage is that they all bog in the wet; they are really quite useless in wet conditions. They tend to be more vulnerable mechanically and not as robust as track vehicles.

My preference is for track vehicles because I think that if one is serious about using vehicles on the battlefield in all that debris and with all the variations in terrain, tracks are the only way to go. I do not deny that there is a place for wheeled fighting vehicles within the Australian Army.

Talking to members of the ADF and the Department of Defence at the Estimates hearings, I found it rather sad that there seems to be no institutional history in the Australian defence forces at the present time. They remember names like Gallipoli, Vietnam and the great battles of the past. But when one is talking to the present members of the Department, whether they are in uniform or in civilian garb, there seems to be no recognition that Australia has had some considerable experience over the past 40 or 50 years with wheeled fighting vehicles.

At the end of World War II we had Staghounds and in the 1950s and 1960s we had a range of British armoured fighting vehicles. The experience of those was all unsatisfactory. It was unsatisfactory because of tyre damage experienced once the vehicles got off roads and because of suspension and transmission problems. It is no coincidence that those same problems are plaguing, and are the dominant feature of, the trials that have been done on the current light armoured fighting vehicle that is under consideration at present.

How did we come to get these vehicles? They were foreshadowed in the Defence of Australia White Paper of 1987. Somehow or other that got translated into fact. There is now a requirement for the defence forces to have them. My own part in this is that in the Estimates Committee hearing of 10 October 1989 I noticed an appropriation of $25m for the purchase of 15 LAV25 vehicles. Having had a long experience with the Department of Defence and having followed its estimates for many years, I knew that there had been no prior appropriation. The one characteristic of the Defence Department is that it is extraordinarily ponderous in coming to a decision. There might be anywhere between 15 and 20 committees and a 10-year work-up time before a project gets approved. Yet the Department got approval for $25m with no prior warning at all in the previous Estimates hearings.

The truth of the matter was that the Minister of the day, Mr Beazley, had been in America, where he was given a ride in one of these vehicles and a very strong sales spiel about them. So we bought them, just like that. As I said at the time, my fear was not that $25m had been spent; my fear was that the purchase of these 15 vehicles would lead to the purchase of some hundreds.

Sadly, that has now come to pass because the current order is for around 100 vehicles at a project figure of $260m plus. It is worth looking at that because $260m-odd is a considerable sum of money and I think that by the time we finish with these vehicles it will be doubled or trebled. Furthermore, what we are buying here is something that the Australian defence forces are going to use for the next 25 years. More important than that, somebody might have to fight in them. That is why we buy defence equipment. So there is a good reason to think about what we are doing.

At the Estimates hearings, I asked a number of questions about the performance of these vehicles in the trials. The Minister was good enough to supply me with a full final report of the evaluation team. I am grateful for that. I do not propose tonight to introduce any material from that report, which is confidential. What I am saying tonight is material that I derived from inquiry at the hearings and it is all on the public record. I just want to emphasise some matters.

I summarise by saying about the armoured fighting vehicle that, first, the trials have shown that it is absolutely useless in wet weather. It bogs in the area in which it is going to be used, the northern Australian, Northern Territory area. It bogs because it has a very high wheel pressure on the ground. It is not good enough to say, as the Army does, that any enemies we might have operating in that area will also bog with wheeled vehicles. People with tracks will get by in a number of cases where no wheeled vehicle will move at all.

The second great disability with the vehicle is that it has very limited off-road capability. It is worth pointing out that driving around big cattle stations and sheep stations in the rural environment in passenger cars and in light four-wheel drive vehicles is quite a different matter from military operations. It is different for this reason: on a property one is nearly always driving on some set of tracks. It is a prepared road that might have been prepared with a grader 20, 30 or even 50 years ago, but there is always some sort of surface. The track will not be bituminised, curbed and channelled and all the rest of it, but at least it bears some semblance to a roadway.

When military wheeled vehicles are operated on rocky or broken ground, over areas that have been subject to bushfires or that have stakes and sticks and things like that, their tyres are enormously vulnerable to damage. Evidence was given to the Committee that 139 tyres were damaged in the trials. The interesting thing is that, while the gross mileage was quite high, the off-road mileage in which the tyres were damaged was really quite small. One is looking at a cost of about $600 per tyre. These vehicles have eight tyres each, so 140 tyres are enormously expensive.

The third significant feature of the vehicle is its habitability. Senator Collins would take a great interest in this, in being locked up in a little steel box in the Northern Territory. Evidence was given that ambient temperature within the vehicles was 55 degrees centigrade. I would not want to sit too long in a vehicle at 55 degrees, let alone all day and then have to get out and fight at the end of it. Not only are human beings in there at 55 degrees; all their food, all their ammunition, all their water and all their fuel is also at 55 degrees because the whole structure is heated up.

One of the characteristics of this vehicle was that it was built for NATO operations on the huge number of paved roads in the European theatre. Of course, it has heaters in it, not air-conditioners. The habitability of the vehicle in the circumstances we face with recorded temperatures of 55 degrees centigrade--which is about 130 degrees fahrenheit on the old scale--is beyond consistent human endurance.

The fourth and very significant feature of these vehicles is that, when they are fitted out the way the Army wants them, they exceed the designed all-up weight of the vehicle. On another important area, their armour protection is really quite minor, and one of the anecdotal stories about the trials is that a 7.62 round, which is the standard round of the SLR rifle, which is now going out of use in the Australian Army, pierced the upper deck of one of these trial vehicles. A witness at the Committee hearing confirmed that a round had gone through, although he could not confirm how it got through or what damage it did. The armour protection is quite minimal.

The good points are that the LAV is fast on roads. It will do 100 to 110 kilometres per hour. When the high temperatures are excluded, it is much kinder to ride in than the M113 that it replaces. The LAV25, which is the offensive LAV, has a very good weapon on it. The 25-millimetre gun was originally a Hughes Bushmaster gun; it is now a McDonnell Douglas gun. It is an excellent support weapon, but one does not have to buy the chassis that goes underneath it to buy the gun.

The problems with the vehicle do need solving. Habitability demands the installation of an air-conditioner, which would increase the weight by about 200 kilograms, as it would have to be a pretty sizeable conditioner. The wet weather problem will never be solved with a wheel design. The tyre problem, I believe, can be fixed. The problem with the tyres is that stakes go through the sidewalls. I do not think it would be beyond Australian industry capability, if no other tyres exist in the world, to design a tyre with adequate sidewall protection for that.

The matter of armoured protection cannot be dealt with simply, because again we get back to the all-up weight of the vehicle. The APC, the troop-carrying version of the LAV, does not have any protection for the machine gun. This is a vehicle that is not in a primary offensive role, but it does have to have some defensive capability and needs a turret, even if only to mount a 50 calibre machine gun. Putting on any kind of turret could increase the weight by 600 kilograms or more.

The gross vehicle operating weight is only 12,800 kilograms. More importantly, with its eight-wheel design, it has a maximum design load of 3,400 kilograms per axle. If that is increased, the possibility of structural failure is quite high. The increased all-up weight of the vehicle resulting from the provision of better armoured protection and things like the air-conditioning system that it needs would require a major redesign of the vehicle.

That is why the Estimates committee hearings are important. We are required to ensure that the Commonwealth gets value for money. The critical thing that came out of the examination of the Department of Defence on the LAVs was that the vehicle needs extensive modifications. My estimate is that between 60 and 70 modifications are required for that vehicle to make it fit for Australian service.

The second factor that arose from the inquiry was that there was no hurry. It turns out that just as Mr Beazley was an impulsive buyer of the vehicle when we bought the first 15, he also drove through the requirement to buy the next 100, to equip 2 Cavalry before it went to Darwin. It would be nice for 2 Cavalry to go to Darwin with the LAV, but it is in no sense essential. It could do the task in the present circumstance quite well with its M113s and with Unimogs. We could well afford to spend a year or two doing the modification program that will have to be done in any case.

The final question I put to the witnesses at the hearings was on Australian manufacture. I found the answers very interesting and they need to be tested. I am sure the answers were given to the Committee in good faith; I am not implying otherwise. However, the dismissal of the possibility of building these vehicles in Australia is misinformed. One of the decent things this Government has done has been to build what defence equipment it can within Australia. All services have a great desire to buy overseas and unload the gear off the ship and then put it into uniform under the Australian flag. It is much better for us to build what we can within Australia.

Perhaps the present Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) is a bit too trusting of the advice he gets from the Department on this vehicle. One of the great tragedies for Australian industry and one of the great mistakes of this Government, while it has been prepared to buy overseas, is the cancellation of Project Waler, which was to build an armoured fighting vehicle within Australia. It started under the Fraser Government, and millions of dollars were spent on it.

I have no doubt in my mind that if Waler had gone ahead, the first two, three or four versions of the Australian-built armoured fighting vehicle would have been failures. But I am sure that by the time we got to the fourth or fifth, we would have had a good vehicle, which would have been very useful in the Australian circumstance and, most importantly, would have created an armoured engineering capability within Australia.

An armoured engineering capability is not too common amongst the world's nations; only a handful of nations have it. If we are to operate armoured vehicles, which are necessary on the battlefield, it helps to have the capacity within the country to support them through their life. The cancellation of Waler was one of the great mistakes of this Government.

The other certainty is that while we are to buy roughly 100 LAVs in the first instance, the order could well expand to 200 or more over the years. I remember that when the M113s came in the initial buy was really quite small, and then it was extended over the years in dribs and drabs until, ultimately, we ended up with somewhere in excess of 860 M113s in the Australian inventory.

Evidence was given to the Committee that there was serious consideration given to the building of these vehicles within Australia. I can find no evidence at all that there was any consideration or consultation with Australian manufacturing industry about building them. It never went to advertisement. There was never a request for tender or a calling for expressions of interest. I do not believe the evidence that Australian industry was consulted on this.

The most damning evidence, though, was that there was a cost penalty of $45m on what was roughly a $250m contract for building them within Australia. The evidence was that there was a $10m licence fee, $20m to $25m for tooling and setting up and $15m for the prototype. I do not know about a licence fee, but I do not think General Motors, the manufacturer in Canada, is in much of a condition to bargain with us on licence fees.

We have already paid $25m for 15 vehicles--they are in the country. At the end of the day, the vehicle we are going to use will be similar to look at but totally different mechanically from those which we have been sold. We have a very strong hand in negotiating with General Motors, in that if it does not come to a reasonable agreement on licensing, we can go ahead and build the vehicle here ourselves. I do not see there is any problem with that.

I do not know how the figure of $20m to $25m for tooling up was arrived at. It is very high. However, we will have to buy a considerable amount of tooling to support this vehicle through 25 years of its service life. So that expenditure is inevitable. The final cost of $10m to build six prototypes is absolutely wrong. There is no need for us to build prototypes for this vehicle.

I would most strongly advise the Government to look at the possibility of building the LAVs in Australia. I believe that the technology involved is not beyond us. If we can weld submarine hulls, we can weld the hulls for armoured fighting vehicles. We have to do an expensive and extensive modification on them to fit them for Australian service. We might as well do that on the assembly line rather than try to do it later. If we build them in Australia, not only do we keep the money within the country but we also create an armoured engineering capability. We have to modify our M113s, which are a first generation APC, at a later date and the requirement is always with us to have armoured fighting vehicles.

The next topic I want to deal with is the Nomad aircraft. Recently, an RAAF Nomad on approach to Tindal became virtually uncontrollable and suffered severe structural damage. The Nomad fleets in the Army and the Air Force have been grounded ever since. The Nomad is an Australian-designed aircraft--designed nearly 20 years ago. Conceptually, it is quite a primitive design. It was not a success commercially when attempts were made to sell the civil version. Furthermore, the Australian Government had to make a substantial out of court payment to its North American agents as a consequence of contractual failures with respect to North American sales.

Briefly, it appears that this aeroplane has a significant aerodynamic problem. That is manifested by longitudinal instability whenever the airflow is interrupted over the main wing. In the particular incident at Tindal, it is said that either an engine cowl was cracked and partially lifted or the cowling was partially secured--I do not know. When the Nomad aircraft was in the landing configuration on the approach to Tindal, it developed its well known characteristic of longitudinal instability. It was pitching at a high frequency, allegedly to such a degree that the pilots could not read the instruments. It was virtually out of control. The pilots managed to regain control of the aircraft and landed it. The aeroplane suffered considerable structural damage.

The significance of this is that, from the date of the inception of Nomad, this aerodynamic problem, the longitudinal instability, has been known. There has been no fix aerodynamically for these shortcomings in the flight envelope. A modification program has been designed to beef up the structure so that when the high frequency pitching occurs the tailplane does not fail structurally. But that does not cure the aerodynamic problem.

It is high time that the Government evaluated the Nomad. It is time that the initial tests for the Aeronautical Research Laboratory of DSTO were made public. In the first place, we need to know whether there is a problem and, secondly, whether there is a fix. If there is no fix, let us withdraw the aircraft from service. It is grossly unfair that the Australian Army, which is the big user of the Nomad--it has 15 or 16 and is getting another 10--should be required to operate an aeroplane which has unsafe characteristics in parts of its flight envelope.

I emphasise that this aeroplane is not essential to us from a military point of view. It fulfils a basic, limited transport role which a number of other aircraft could fill quite well. While I am on the subject of other aircraft playing those sorts of roles, I am astonished that the Army is going to get rid of the Porter aircraft and keep the Nomads. The Porter is an extremely useful aircraft for the Army. It has a very robust airframe and an excellent engine. It is purpose-built for Army cooperation work. However, the evidence given to the Committee by the Deputy Chief of the General Staff with regard to the Porter was far from convincing.

I do not believe it is correct that lives should be put at risk by using non-essential equipment like that. In all the years I have been in the Parliament, I have believed that the equipment bought for the Services should not always be the most expensive, but people must have a chance of surviving with it if it is used in combat. I do not think lives ought to be put at risk in any way at all when alternatives which are far safer are available. From all of the evidence that has been put before the Parliament, there are far better aircraft around than the Nomad. As a matter of urgency, the Government should consider whether that aircraft ought to be retained within the Australian inventory.

The final point I want to deal with is a matter of policy. Over the last few years, the Government has been talking about closer links with New Zealand in the defence field. At the RUSI conference which was held in Canberra last month, the Chief of the Defence Force made a very worrying speech forecasting closer integration with the New Zealand defence forces. I am the first person to support defence cooperation in the form of regional alliances. I have said many times in the Senate that the security of Australia depends on the security of the region, not primarily on the strength of our own defence forces. Everything should be done, both diplomatically and through defence cooperation programs, to ensure the regional support, alliances and interoperability of our defence forces with those of our neighbours.

But there is a world of difference between cooperation and integration. I am quite sure that the CDF was motivated and pushed into this by Government policy. What the CDF is saying when he says that the Australian defence forces will integrate with those of New Zealand is that the Government policy outlined in DOA 1987--the White Paper entitled Defence of Australia which is the guiding light for this Government--is now a total failure. It is a clear statement that the Government is now unable to fund Australian defence as defined in DOA 1987. We have run up the white flag on funding for the Australian Defence Force as a consequence.

This is really a very stupid decision. New Zealand is not Australia. It is a different country; it is different ethnically, culturally and industrially. It has an outlook on the world and a place in the world that is totally different from that of Australia. It has an extremely insular view. New Zealand broke its defence alliance with Australia, in the form of the ANZUS treaty, some years ago and it has not made any attempt to re-establish it. I think it is absolutely nonsensical, as well as being highly dangerous, for Australia to integrate our Defence Force with that of New Zealand.

By all means let us cooperate and have interoperability; let us have an understanding of how we would both work in an emergency. But let us not transfer the security of Australia to a second country, even if it is one of our close neighbours like New Zealand. New Zealand does not value its own defence. It spends far less on it, as a percentage of its GDP, than we do. The proposition advanced by this Government--that somehow we can make one Defence Force out of two defence forces by incorrectly and inadequately funding the separate defence forces in each country--is nonsense and it ought to be condemned out of hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise in the adjournment debate tonight to enlarge on a couple of matters which I raised in the matters of public interest debate last Thursday with respect to Robe River. In doing that--and in leading up to the dates that were given in this chamber by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in terms of hearings and dismissed hearings and in answer to questions asked both by Senator Crowley and I--I reiterate that the reason I am doing this is purely and simply that I made a very serious charge against the Minister last Thursday in that I claimed that the Minister had misled the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: There were two major factors in the lead-up to the dispute: first, weak management and, secondly, what I would term the abuse of union power. I shall give an example of what led to some of the problems at Robe River. I will not mention names because I do not want to denigrate or bring individuals back into the matter, but it is important that accuracy in what is said be maintained in this place.

A matter which led to the blow-up was a power house superintendent, who was a staff man and not a member of the union, finding an electrical fault caused by an alternator trip. It resulted in the loss of power to the community. It was assumed that it occurred as a result of a lightning strike. Mr Knapp simply pressed a switch which reset the circuit breaker and restored power to the community. Under one of the restrictive work practices that then existed, only ETU tradesmen were entitled to reset a circuit breaker. However, on this day the ETU was taking part in a 24-hour strike as part of a national ACTU protest day for a 2.5 per cent wage increase and 3 per cent superannuation.

As a result, considerable delay would have been experienced in restoring power to the community. All that Mr Knapp did was in fact press the switch and set the power back into the town. There was a demand that Mr Knapp be disciplined with a five-day suspension for performing wages work. The company conceded to the ETU's demand and suspended Mr Knapp for two days. The ETU went on strike for six days, claiming that the suspension was inadequate. In raising this matter, I am highlighting the point that there was a very serious situation at Robe River then. I guess it was like land on a very hot day when everything is tinder dry and someone drops a match.

The other point I want to make is that there is more to the matter than just an appeal being lodged or a day being nominated. I emphasise quite clearly that the answers to the questions are, among other things, a misuse, an overuse or a vexatious use of the appeals process or the processes which then existed through the Industrial Relations Commission. It is worth noting that in most of the cases, in the call for hearings, the applications, the stay of proceedings or the appeals, the unions and the company just about ran a line ball. There has not, in my view, been an overuse of the powers of the Industrial Relations Commission by either party towards the disputes that existed.

It is worth noting that the appeal, resulting from a hearing on 5 May 1989, was lodged on 13 June 1989. That was the first case that the Minister mentioned. The hearing was brought by the AIMPE and was a claim for reinstatement of a particular employee. There was a further hearing in the matter, once again brought on by the AIMPE, for the reinstatement of this gentleman on 15 May. On 13 June the appeal was lodged by CLS. The appeal--the one that the Minister claimed was dismissed--was heard finally on 26 September 1989. At that time the appeal was withdrawn. It is worth noting that the appeal was withdrawn at that time with the consent of the union. It was not dismissed, as the Minister claimed.

The other matter that I wish to raise tonight concerns the appeal which related to the particular case that the Minister chose not to mention. That case began as a result of an award made by Commissioner Fogarty with regard to the same employee in the employ of CLS. The decision brought down reinstated that gentleman. The case was heard on 21 July 1989.

We then move to 28 July 1989, to the appeal that was lodged by CLS against the decision of Commissioner Fogarty. A stay was granted on the award brought down on 21 July, which enabled a later date to be set down for the hearing. We finally get to 26 September--the appeal was heard on the same day as the previous case I mentioned--when the decision, by leave of the Commission and, with the consent of the unions, the award was set aside and therefore there was no point in continuing the case.

In outlining these cases and the position which existed at Robe River, although it was a tinder box situation--there had been some stupidity, some weak management--it is most important to point out, having regard to the charge that I raised against the Minister last week, that the 13 June 1989 date was withdrawn, and the case which the Minister chose to ignore, by leave of the Commission, and with the consent of the unions, the reinstatement award against the appeal was lodged, was set aside.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I wish to speak in this debate not on a matter of mean-spiritedness as did the previous speaker, but to pay tribute to Aung San Suu Kyi, the leader of the Burmese opposition party who today was awarded the Nobel peace prize for her efforts in trying to achieve democracy through peaceful means in her country of Burma.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think that there is a more fitting person in the world today to receive the Nobel peace prize than Aung San Suu Kyi. I had the opportunity to meet her briefly when I visited Burma in early 1989. I may well be the only member of the Australian Parliament to have met her since she returned to Burma in 1988. It was only a brief meeting, but she certainly impressed me as a person of extraordinary moral courage, great political ability and considerable charisma. Obviously she is the outstanding leader in her country.

Aung San Suu Kyi is the daughter of the founder of modern Burma, General Aung San, who was tragically assassinated in 1947 just as Burma was about to become independent. She lived much of her life outside Burma as a result of the military coup in the early 1960s and only returned to Burma in 1988 as her mother was dying from cancer. It was during that period that the massive demonstrations took place in Burma in which the Burmese people demanded democracy. For several months it looked as though they would succeed in their demands for the establishment of democratic rule, but the Burmese Army conducted a coup and, in a wave of oppression in which several thousand people were murdered during the middle of 1988, the democracy movement was crushed.

Aung San Suu Kyi continued the campaign for democracy, despite the military coup. On some occasions she addressed rallies in Rangoon, which estimates indicate that more than a million people attended. She quickly became the recognised leader of the National League for Democracy, the main opposition party. During the several months she was allowed freedom in early 1989, she campaigned all over Burma and received mass support from the Burmese people.

Aung San Suu Kyi made serious and quite correct criticisms of the military junta that ran the country which led in July 1989 to her being placed under house arrest in her own home in Rangoon and cut off from contact with members of her own party, family friends, and international diplomats. The military junta thought that, with her imprisonment, the National League for Democracy would wither away and that the promised free elections would mean that the party it supported would sweep in at the elections.

The elections were held in May 1990 and, to the astonishment of the military junta, the people overwhelmingly in a landslide result elected the National League for Democracy with something like 400 of the 470-odd seats in the National Assembly. Because the result was so overwhelming, the junta has since refused to accept the legitimacy of the result and has kept not only Aung San Suu Kyi under house arrest but has arrested most of the remaining leaders of the National League for Democracy and anybody else who dares criticise its rule.

It is now estimated by Amnesty International and other human rights organisations that many thousands of people are held as political prisoners on trumped up charges, or sometimes even without charges. There are reports of the appalling use of torture and of the general mistreatment of prisoners. Throughout all this period--now over two years--while under house arrest, Aung San Suu Kyi has refused to give in to the military junta. She has consistently made it clear to the junta that she will not leave the country. Members of the junta have made offers to her that they would let her leave the country quietly, but she said she would not unless all political prisoners were released and she had an opportunity to make a major statement to the Burmese people.

Aung San Suu Kyi has also suggested quite cleverly that if she is to leave the country, she wants the right to walk from her house to the Rangoon airport before she departs. Members of the junta know as well as she does that during that walk most of the people in Rangoon would turn out in support of her. That may be the catalyst for the overthrow of the military junta by the people. It is interesting that one person who nominated Aung San Suu Kyi for the Nobel Peace Prize is one of the other great democrats in the world today, the Czechoslovakian President, Vaclav Havel, a person who fought for many years for the restoration of democracy in Czechoslovakia.

I believe that this Parliament should pay tribute to Aung San Suu Kyi. I do note that previously in this chamber the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has consistently raised the issue of human rights abuses in Burma and made it very clear that the Australian Government does not support the present junta; has raised the issue in the United Nations of human rights abuses; and has raised the issue with ASEAN and other countries to put pressure on the Burmese regime to recognise the legitimately elected government, that is, the National League for Democracy.

I must also mention that this is a bipartisan approach. The Opposition in this Parliament has also made its views known very clearly in support of Aung San Suu Kyi and the restoration of democracy. Senator Hill and I share the distinction that both of us have been refused a visa to visit Burma in the past 12 months because both of us have made statements in this place in favour of democracy and human rights. I hope that tomorrow or in the next few days the Senate could carry a unanimous resolution of congratulation to Aung San Suu Kyi on winning the Nobel Peace Prize today. She joins an illustrious company of great human beings in the last half century who have won the Nobel Peace Prize, such as Desmond Tutu and Martin Luther King--all of them dedicated to the issue of democracy, human rights and freedom.

Aung San Suu Kyi, who may not be very well known in this country, is one of the great champions of democracy in Asia. Her success today in winning the Nobel Peace Prize will be an enormous morale boost to the people of Burma when they hear the news. Though I suspect that the military regime will make every effort to hide from the Burmese people the news that she has won the prize, the word will spread through international short wave radio, such as Radio Australia, Voice of America, the BBC Overseas Service, and Radio India. The fact that she has won the prize will be an enormous blow to the prestige of the Burmese Government for, as low as that prestige may be, it is a very significant step for the Burmese people on their long struggle for democracy. I hope that in the near future members of this Parliament will be able to recognise Aung San Suu Kyi openly as the democratically elected Prime Minister of her country with the full support of her people. It is a great night for democracy in the world that Aung San Suu Kyi has won the Nobel Peace Prize.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 6 August 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the cost and how many people are employed on the plan to reform Australia's road/rail system.
(2) How many committees have been established and what associated costs have been incurred since 1983.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Land Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Reform of land transport is a continuing process rather than a finite project or plan. It covers a range of issues including vehicle and road user regulation, road use charging, road and rail infrastructure funding, rail organisation and management and the relationships between Federal, State and local government.
Managing change in land transport is a major component of the Land Transport Program in the portfolio. There has been significant activity in this area over recent years including:
passage and implementation of the Interstate Road Transport Acts
passage and implementation of the Motor Vehicle Standards Act
refinement of road funding arrangements under the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Act 1985 and the Australian Land Transport Development Act 1988
recent Premiers' Conference agreements to establish the National Rail Corporation and the National Road Transport Commission and a new national road transport regulatory and charging framework.

The objective of the Land Transport sub-program is to provide a policy, regulatory and operational framework for the achievement of a safe, efficient and innovative land transport sector. The majority of its resources are used in the continuing reform process. In the 1991/92 Budget the sub-program has been allocated $4,491,000 and 82.6 staff years for running costs.

(2) There have been numerous committees established since 1983 at both Commonwealth/State and inter-departmental levels to deal with various aspects of change in land transport. These have varied from very significant undertakings such as the National Road Freight Industry Inquiry, the Railway Industry Council, the National Rail Freight Initiative Task Force and the Overarching Group on Land Transport Reform, which supports the Special Premiers' Conference, to relatively short-term ad hoc groups to deal with specific issues.

A detailed enumeration of these committees and their costs would not be worth the resources involved in undertaking the task. The outcome of the major ones, including those mentioned above, is a matter of public record. The costs involved on such processes are undoubtedly significant but the potential long term gains from land transport reform have been estimated by the Industry Commission at over $6 billion a year in increased GDP.

Funds were provided from land transport trust funds to support research for the Railway Industry Council ($183,000), and the National Rail Freight Initiative Committee ($193,000). The National Freight Initiative Task Force was allocated $2 million for research and professional advice, of which $673,000 had been spent by 30 June 1991.

Other costs such as salaries and administrative expenses (including travel) associated with these and other land transport reform initiatives were shared by the Federal and State Governments, unions and private enterprise. For the Commonwealth these costs are included under (1) above.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business and Customs, upon notice, on 2O August 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: What action, if any, has been taken to implement the recommendations of the Beddall Report in relation to the following: (a) the introduction of roll-over provisions in the capital gains tax on the sale of a business where another business is acquired in its place; (b) reducing the cost and complexity of tax compliance (both direct and indirect) of small business; (c) addressing the problems faced by small business in the timing of tax payments; and (d) reviewing the threshold of commencement of various regulatory provisions and tax levies, for example, training guarantee legislation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Small Business and Customs has supplied the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The introduction of Capital Gains Tax (CGT) rollover provisions for small firms raises complex questions about the consistency of the Government's approach to taxing different forms of income and the possible extended deferral of taxation liabilities.

The Government as a matter of principle believes that no group has any stronger claim to exemption from CGT than the rest of the asset-owning community, since all groups benefit from capital gains they accure. Further research is required into how rollover provisions might be implemented without providing increased opportunities for tax avoidance and evasion and potentially creating inefficiencies through the accumulation of CGT liability, stemming from the tax deferral.
These issues are under consideration by the Small Business Council Tax Group.

(b) Considerable progress has been made since the release of the Parliamentary Committee Report on reducing tax compliance costs. The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) is currently undertaking a comprehensive market research project to more clearly identify small business information, education and service needs and examine more closely where compliance costs may be reduced. The ATO has also produced an information kit which features a series on simplified reporting and compliance requirements, general tax information and cash management tools. It has created specialist small business advisory units in Branch Offices in Adelaide and Penrith.

For example, in the 1990 Budget the Government announced that it would undertake a broad review of the wholesale sales tax system with the aim of further improving the efficiency of the system by reducing compliance costs for the community and the ATO. The review is currently underway and is expected to be completed in the latter half of 1992.

Further progress in reducing the cost and complexity of tax compliance (both direct and indirect) will also be made as result of a joint ATO and Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce study into the cost to small business of complying with tax legislation.
The study will provide assistance in the ATO's efforts to streamline the administration of the tax laws, improve client service and foster a climate conducive to voluntary compliance.

The first stages of the study (concentrating on small business) will be undertaken by the University of Newcastle under the direction of Mr Ian Wallschutzky, Associate Professor in Taxation. The study has the full support of the thirty industry associations represented on the Small Business Forum.
(c) The major recommendation in the Beddall Report regarding the timing of tax payments related to the payment of Wholesale Sales Tax (WST).

In the 1990 Federal Budget the Government announced that the WST would be altered on 1 August 1991 to allow businesses whose WST liability is $50,000 or less to pay WST quarterly, rather than monthly. The amendment has benefited approximately 80 per cent of WST taxpayers.
The reduction in the frequency of payments of sales tax meets, in part, the intent of the Beddall Report recommendations.
To protect the threshold from erosion by price increases and to ensure that the new system continues to benefit small WST taxpayers, the threshold will be adjusted annually in line with the CPI.

(d) On 1 April 1991, the threshold for exemption from quarterly payments for fringe benefits tax payers was increased from $1,000 to $3,000. Over 70,000 small businesses will benefit by being able to make annual payments. Since 1 July 1990, group employers with annual PAYE tax remittances of less than $10,000 have been able to remit PAYE tax on a quarterly rather than monthly basis. This change was of assistance to approximately 200,000 existing group employers and up to 190,000 tax stamp employers during the last financial year.

Employers are subject to the Training Guarantee if their annual national payroll exceeds the threshold amount. The Training Guarantee threshold for 1991/92 has been increased from $200,000 to $214,000. The threshold is indexed annually to Average Weekly Earnings.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 3 September 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that current payments under Family Allowance Supplement (FAS) are based on taxable income for the 1989/90 financial year.
(2) Is it also a fact that if a person's current income is at least 25 percent less than their income in the 1989/90 financial year, they are entitled to new FAS payments or increased FAS payments.

(3) Is it also a fact that if a person's income is now less than it was in the 1989/90 financial year but is not less by 25 percent or more, that person is not eligible for FAS payments even though they may otherwise be eligible.

(4) Does this mean that some families who need FAS and who are eligible in relation to their income and assets, cannot receive this payment; if so, does the Government believe this is acceptable; if not, could the rules be changed to protect those who are in this situation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Payments of Family Allowance Supplement (FAS) in 1991 are initially calculated on the combined parental taxable income in the 1989/90 financial year (the base year).

(2) Sometimes there are significant changes in a family's financial situation, such that the expected combined taxable income in a full current financial year is at least 25 percent below the income in the base year or below the income free area applicable to the family. In this situation, the Social Security Act 1991 allows FAS entitlements to be calculated on the expected taxable income for the current financial year.
This may provide an entitlement where none previously existed or may provide an increased entitlement.
(3) If the expected taxable income for a current financial year does not meet the reduction rules set out in (2), entitlement in 1991 continues to be based on 1989/90 taxable income.
(4) The legislation sets out the eligibility rules. Those families whose income does not meet the income test requirements are not eligible.
The FAS income test is designed to assist families experiencing a major longer-term reduction in income or those whose incomes fall below the threshold (currently $18,000 for a one child family).

Families who have a fall in weekly income have a regular opportunity to request a fresh assessment in July and January each year when new financial years begin or base years change. Most affected cases succeed in having FAS entitlement adjusted on this basis.

The same provisions apply also to increases in income so that increases in income of less than 25 percent of the base year income do not affect entitlement until they are incorporated in a new base year assessment. This protects low income families against immediate loss of FAS from increases in income occasioned by, for example, earnings from periodic overtime or small amounts of part-time earnings of a secondary earner in a family.

Alternative income test arrangements based on current income alone would improve the responsiveness of FAS rate adjustments for a small minority of families whose incomes increase by amounts of less than 25 percent but at the expense of reducing entitlements for many more whose incomes increase by small amounts from time to time. Such arrangements also would add significantly to the costs of administering FAS and to the notification requirements for FAS families. Arrangements similar to the alternative were in force under the original FAS income test arrangements and the precursor to FAS, the Family Income Supplement Scheme, and were found to be highly unsatisfactory in terms of the difficulties outlined. It was for this reason that the Government decided to revise the FAS income test to operate as it does currently. The Government believes that the existing income test arrangements are preferable, assisting as they do some 200,000 low income families currently compared with a peak of about 150,000 families assisted under earlier arrangements.

The functional review of SAAP, which was recently completed, was established as part of this process. The SAAP functional review report was considered by a meeting of Commonwealth, State and Territory Health and Welfare Ministers on 6 September 1991. Ministers agreed to recommend to the Special Premiers' Conference in November that, in recognition of the joint national interest in homelessness and domestic violence, involvement of both the Commonwealth and the States is required to address the complex causes of homelessness and domestic violence and provide adequate opportunities for movement towards independence.

At this stage, no decisions have been made regarding future SAAP arrangements. The functional review report will be considered by the November Special Premiers' Conference. It should be noted that, at their October 1990 meeting, Heads of Government agreed that the fundamental objective underlying any change to SAAP or other programs would be to improve the existing system delivery of programs and services in the interests of Australian citizens.

The Commonwealth has a strong commitment to the advancement of the needs of SAAP clients, as expressed in its social justice activities. The Government will wish to see this commitment continue within any new arrangements that may result from this review process.

(8) The Australian Council of Social Service held national consultations on the overall review of commonwealth/state relations involving from all States representatives from service-provider and consumer groups. These groups included special interest groups and local, state-wide and national organisations. Two rounds of consultations were held with these groups. The last round of meetings was on 5-6 August in Sydney and 2 September in Melbourne. These meetings covered issues relating to the SAAP Functional Review.

Between the two rounds of meetings, participants consulted with their constituencies on the main issues arising out of the first meeting. State based discussions and consultations were also sponsored by each of the State Councils of Social Services.

In considering the SAAP review report, the meeting of Commonwealth, State and Territory Health and Welfare Ministers agreed to its public release. Community groups can obtain copies of the report from the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. The report canvasses a number of possible options together with a critique of each option by the functional review group. Copies of the report have already been provided to members of the SAAP Ministerial Advisory Committees (MACs) in each State for consideration. These Committees may choose to undertake further consultations. In the case of the South Australian MAC, this could involve the sector groups representing South Australian SAAP service providers.

A process of further consultations would, of course, occur prior to the implementation of any change, but in the absence of the outcomes of the November Special Premiers' Conference it is not possible to speculate on what this may involve and what the timing might be.
